HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: THE WHITE HOUSE; 
Bush Welcomes Slower Approach to North Korea

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 

 BODY:
The White House sought today to defuse a worsening confrontation with North Korea, applauding the International Atomic Energy Agency's decision to condemn North Korea's nuclear activities but delay taking the issue to the United Nations Security Council for sanctions.
 President Bush repeated three times this afternoon that he had no intention of attacking North Korea -- an effort, it seemed, both to give the North a security guarantee and ease a diplomatically embarrassing difference with South Korea and Japan over how to handle the crisis. 
 "I'll repeat that," Mr. Bush told reporters after a cabinet meeting today to start off a new year of domestic and international initiatives. "We have no intention of invading North Korea." 
Only a week ago, as Mr. Bush vacationed in Texas, his aides were saying they would support the atomic energy agency in taking the issue straight to the Security Council, which would then consider economic penalties.
Now that approach appears to have been reconsidered. In recent days, some senior officials have warned that penalties could prompt a military response from the North -- just as the administration is preparing forces for the Persian Gulf.
Tonight, as Tuesday unfolded in North Korea, its government warned of exactly that. "Sanctions mean a war and the war knows no mercy," the official Korean Central News Agency said. "The U.S. should opt for dialogue" with North Korea, it added, "not for war, clearly aware that it will have to pay a very high price for such reckless acts." The statement echoed a similar warning to the Clinton administration in 1994.
Despite the apparent shift in approach by Mr. Bush, his aides said he would not budge on his refusal to talk to North Korea until it readmits inspectors and refreezes its nuclear programs.
A senior South Korean official criticized that approach today, saying: "Talk is essential here. How do we know what the North will say until there is some dialogue with the United States?"
North Korea is only one of a number of issues that the president confronts as he approaches his second anniversary in office. 
Israel's announcement that it would bar Palestinian officials from traveling to London for talks on the Middle East later this month complicated his effort to show that some progress is being made on those issues even as he heads toward a military confrontation with Iraq.
Pakistan continued its arguments over whether American forces could pursue suspected members of Al Qaeda into its territory, once again calling into question the administration's claim that the country has been a full partner in its effort against terror.
While Mr. Bush planned to use the next few weeks to make the case for action to remove Saddam Hussein of Iraq from power, one leader of the inspection teams admitted that nothing incriminating had yet been found -- and some allies began to question whether there was enough evidence yet to build a coalition for military action. "We haven't yet seen any smoking gun," the head of the atomic energy agency, Dr. Mohamed ElBaradei, said in Vienna. He said laboratory tests of samples taken at sites visited by his inspectors -- presumably guided by some American intelligence data -- "have not raised any eyebrows."
Such assessments only complicate the issue for Mr. Bush, as he faces the question of how -- and whether -- to make the case in the Council in the next few weeks that Iraq remains in violation of its resolutions, and that military action is required.
North Korea's actions in recent months have been far more provocative than Iraq's. In October, it acknowledged a secret program to enrich uranium, violating its 1994 agreement with the United States. The Bush administration and its allies responded by cutting off oil shipments. And in December, the North disabled cameras, broke seals and ejected inspectors at a nuclear plant capable of producing weapons-grade plutonium.
Its flagrant violation of its nuclear commitments has put Mr. Bush in the position of arguing that Mr. Hussein, who is letting inspectors move freely even as he rails that they are gathering "intelligence," poses a more imminent threat to world security than North Korea. The North is believed to already possess two nuclear weapons and could reprocess its stockpile of spent nuclear fuel rods to produce enough plutonium for five or six additional nuclear weapons by this summer, the Central Intelligence Agency estimates. 
"Part of the reason that we don't want to get North Korea's problems in front of the Security Council too quickly," one senior official suggested today, "is that the other Security Council members will be overwhelmed by too many problems at once. And these problems are different enough that you don't want one polluting the other."
At the United Nations, American diplomats say Mr. Bush has not yet decided whether to return to the Security Council to seek a second resolution authorizing war against Iraq. They concede, as Dr. ElBaradei seemed to suggest today, that the weapons inspections in the country are not yet far enough along to produce evidence that would convince skeptical Council nations that Iraq cannot be disarmed peacefully. Even Jack Straw, the British foreign minister, suggested today that it would be helpful to secure broad Security Council support for any military action -- though he stopped short of saying that should be a prerequisite for a strike. 
France, China and Russia, three of the other four permanent veto-bearing members of the Council, insist on a second debate and vote before they will support any military action against Baghdad. They contend that this second step is laid out in Resolution 1441, which was adopted unanimously in November to start the weapons inspections.
Top State Department officials are inclined to go for a second vote, one official there said. In December Secretary of State Colin L. Powell denounced the omissions in Iraq's declaration of its arms programs as a "material breach" of Council resolutions. But if the weapons inspectors do not uncover any secret weapons programs, American officials have little choice but to wait for a broad progress report that Dr. ElBaradei and Hans Blix, the chief United Nations inspectors, will give the Council on Jan. 27.
Mr. Bush plans to make the case, aides say, that the inspectors' failure to find evidence only proves Mr. Hussein's cleverness as an adversary -- that he has spent the past four years hiding evidence of his weapons of mass destruction. Today Mr. Bush pressed his case anew, describing Mr. Hussein as "a threat to our friends and neighbors in the Middle East," though he did not describe Kim Jong Il of North Korea as a threat to American allies in Asia.
Over the next few days, the White House's diplomatic focus will shift back to North Korea. At a meeting planned for Tuesday among senior Japanese, South Korea and American officials, South Korea is expected to present a compromise proposal under which the United States and North Korea would make reciprocal moves -- the former toward a nonaggression pact and aid, the latter toward nuclear commitments.
But today, Ari Fleischer, Mr. Bush's spokesman, said the issue was not who moved first, but the North's track record of going back on its agreements. "South Korea was in the midst of its 'sunshine policy,' " he said, "when North Korea was setting the sun on its word."

HEADLINE: Silver Says Only U.S. Aid Is Likely to Stop a Tax Rise 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 6 

 BODY:
As the governor and lawmakers waited to see what help President Bush might offer the state in his speech to the nation on Tuesday, the Democratic speaker of the Assembly said that unless Washington comes to the rescue, the state is likely to have to increase taxes to close a giant shortfall in next year's budget.
 Republicans in control of the State Senate immediately rejected the idea of tax increases of any kind, but Gov. George E. Pataki, who has been tightlipped about his budget plans, did not rule them out. He said the public would have to wait until his annual address to the Legislature on Wednesday for a clue to his plans. 
 "I think suspense is a good thing," he said.
One possible reason for Mr. Pataki's reticence is uncertainty over what aid the state may be getting from Washington. President Bush plans a major address on Tuesday in which he will propose cutting taxes to stimulate the economy and providing about $10 billion in aid to financially troubled state governments.
What that means for New York State remained unclear this evening. Members of the state's Congressional delegation said the president's aides have not told them precisely how the $10 billion will be divided among the states or where it will come from. Among the ideas under discussion is changing the formulas driving Medicaid and highway grants, to direct more money to the states.
New York faces at least a $2 billion gap in this year's $89.6 billion spending plan. The shortfall next year will be at least $8 billion and perhaps as much as $10 billion, according to Senate and Assembly legislative aides, as well as independent budget analysts.
The Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, said such a large gap could not be closed without either raising revenue, gaining more money from the federal government or cutting education and health care, two areas he vowed he would not allow to shrink. He said that a temporary income tax surcharge on the wealthy or on corporate income would be a good choice, if a tax increase proved necessary. He also said he favored lifting a cap on state borrowing, to weather the crisis.
"Tax increases are not out of the question here regardless of the rhetoric you may hear from some people," he said. "I would like to avoid it, like everybody else, but I also, specifically, do not want to cut education aid."
The Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, however, said he and his Republican colleagues would kill any proposal for a broad-based rise in taxes. "The speaker's knee-jerk reaction is always raise taxes, just raise taxes, and that's how you settle your problems, and it just doesn't work that way," Mr. Bruno said in a radio interview.
Mr. Bruno maintained that the state had lost hundreds of thousands of jobs under Gov. Mario M. Cuomo because of the state's high tax rate. "We are not going back to those days, I can tell you that," he said. "The speaker can talk all he wants about raising taxes. That's not on our horizon."
For his part, Governor Pataki said he was still shaping his plan for closing a budget gap for the fiscal year starting on April 1 and would not even know the size of the shortfall until the middle of January, when December tax revenue is counted and people with large investment incomes make partial tax payments.
During the election, the governor successfully avoided saying how large the deficit in the coming fiscal year would be, and in recent days he has only referred to the state's straits as "a crisis" or "enormous challenges." Today he edged closer to quantifying the shortfall, saying, "We are facing perhaps as much as a $2 billion gap in this fiscal year, and many times that in next year's budget."
Mr. Pataki promised to lay out his plan in broad terms in his speech to a joint session of the Legislature this week, but he said the details will come on Jan. 29, when he presents his budget to lawmakers. "We will be late, as late as we can, to see what the numbers look like," the governor said.
The governor has been lobbying the White House to provide federal assistance to help the state government make up for plummeting revenues ever since the terrorist attack on Sept. 11, 2001, his senior aides said.
Senator Charles E. Schumer said he had not been informed how much aid New York might expect from President Bush's proposal, but if the federal government allocated $10 billion according to population, the state would get approximately $700 million. "My guess is this will be done on a per capita basis, because they don't want to reward states with deeper deficits," he said.
Representative John E. Sweeney, a Rensselaer County Republican, said White House officials were keeping details of the proposal under wraps, though he had been told the Medicaid and highway grants were being considered as a vehicle for increased state aid.
"We haven't seen anything yet," he said. "I don't know yet that it's settled. Our job is to try to make sure New York gets its fair share."

HEADLINE: Fund Manager to Meet His Irate Investors in Court 

BYLINE:  By LANDON THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
Kenneth Lipper, money manager to the stars before his hedge fund collapsed a year ago, will try to persuade a judge today that he can pay his investors back -- most of their money, at least. But many of the investors are furious, saying that the plan favors some clients over others.
 Among hedge fund failures, his is a memorable one. Mr. Lipper startled the financial industry when he announced last February that his Lipper Convertibles Fund had lost $315 million, or 40 percent of its value. The fund was full of telecommunications and energy bonds that plummeted in value for much of 2001, though he says the real damage was obscured until a couple of his leading managers left early last year. 
 Mr. Lipper cuts an unusual figure for a hedge fund manager. He was a deputy mayor in the administration of Edward I. Koch and a Hollywood figure who advised Oliver Stone on the filming of "Wall Street." He produced and helped to write the screenplay for "City Hall" in 1996 and, as a co-producer, won an Oscar in 1999 for "The Last Days," a Holocaust documentary. 
Early on, he seemed to have an eye for the bright lights. Mr. Lipper was always on the periphery of fame and celebrity, but never quite able to achieve it.
He grew up in the South Bronx with Al Pacino in the 1950's, was a Salomon Brothers partner with Michael R. Bloomberg in the 1970's and early 80's, and pitched movie projects to Steven Spielberg in the 1990's.
The clients in his fund included Michael D. Eisner, Julia Roberts and Mortimer B. Zuckerman, and spanned the upper reaches of society in Hollywood and in New York.
While their losses may seem like pocket change to celebrities, Mr. Lipper is losing a lot more. His funds have been shut down, his clients have left him and he is expected to be liable for what is sure to be many millions of dollars in legal and restitution payments. Most painful to him, his friends say, is the evisceration of his reputation in Hollywood and on Wall Street.
Though there is one investor lawsuit against him, Mr. Lipper is presenting a petition in court today to distribute the remaining money in the fund. Mr. Lipper, not normally camera-shy, is expected to let his lawyers speak for him in court.
While he has cultivated an array of identities over the years -- Hollywood producer, screenwriter, book publisher, patron of the arts and deputy mayor -- he is, at root, a product of Wall Street. As a scrappy young banker at blue-blood Lehman Brothers in the early 70's, Mr. Lipper made the important social and financial connections that would lay the base for his eventual hedge-fund career. As a Salomon Brothers partner in 1982, he made the big money that would help finance his evolution into a Renaissance man of sorts.
In quick order, he became a New York deputy mayor, and in 1985 he signed on as a technical adviser to Mr. Stone in the filming of "Wall Street."
"Ken doesn't get to Oliver Stone without Lehman Brothers," said Michael M. Thomas, a former Lehman Brothers partner who hired Mr. Lipper in 1969. "Hollywood is tricky. I think Ken tasted one drop too much of the nectar, and that drop was the difference between balance and intoxication."
While the collapse of Mr. Lipper's fund may seem to some like a captivating morality tale, its dissolution is not so unusual. The hedge fund industry, unlike its mutual fund counterparts, is largely unregulated. Hedge funds are predicated on the notion that well-heeled investors are ready to take on higher risk for higher returns.
With Mr. Lipper's convertibles fund, for example, clients had to invest at least $1 million to become a partner. Implosions, especially in today's volatile markets are common. According to Tremont Advisors, of the 1,797 hedge funds it followed at the start of 2002, one-fifth had ceased operations by the end of this year.
Like many such funds, Mr. Lipper's was a kind of mom-and-pop shop. Working in one of his offices was James Atlas, who edited a series of brief biographies that Mr. Lipper was supporting financially. A daughter, Daniella, worked as an analyst for the funds, and his No. 2, Abraham Biderman, is a longtime friend from his days in the Koch administration. While the fund employed a compliance officer and was audited every year, the internal controls were lax enough to allow Mr. Lipper's portfolio managers to misprice securities for a six-year period.
But a question remains: Did Mr. Lipper have any hand in the mispricing of the securities or did he simply take his eye off the ball? 
Convertible arbitrage investing is meant to be low risk, with a built-in hedging mechanism. Mr. Lipper's fund, though, suffered as its holdings of telecommunication and energy bonds collapsed in 2001.
According to Mr. Lipper's version of events, he discovered that something was amiss only a year ago when Edward Strafaci, the portfolio manager for the convertibles fund, abruptly resigned on Jan. 14. Mr. Strafaci also oversaw a smaller offshore fund, which suffered similar losses and has since been liquidated.
Mr. Lipper quickly determined that holdings of convertible securities had been mispriced, meaning that the fund's value had been artificially inflated. Many of these securities -- bonds convertible into stocks -- are thinly traded, if at all, and determining a market price can seem like a subjective exercise.
In a Feb. 20 letter to investors, Mr. Lipper attributed the 40 percent loss that the fund would suffer in 2001 to fallout from the Enron debacle, the decline of telecommunications companies and the economic losses from the attacks of Sept. 11. In a subsequent letter he announced that the fund would be closed and that the remaining assets would be returned to investors. Investors would not be able to withdraw funds until he had completed a top-to-bottom re-evaluation of the fund.
Recently, Mr. Lipper has begun to suggest that it is his portfolio manager, Mr. Strafaci, who is at fault for the mispriced securities. Mr. Strafaci could not be reached for comment and has not been the subject of investor lawsuits. 
On Dec. 12, Mr. Lipper sent investors a summary of a report conducted by the law firm of Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson. The report concluded that the securities in the Lipper convertibles fund and the smaller offshore fund were mispriced by their managers, resulting in the distorted valuations, and cited Mr. Strafaci.
In an accompanying letter, Mr. Lipper stated: "You may be aware that the United States attorney's office is conducting an investigation into the funds. We are advised that none of the current directors, officers or personnel of Lipper Holdings or the funds is either the subject or target of the investigation." 
In the same letter, he outlined his plan to pay back his investors. It is this plan that a New York State Supreme Court judge, Karla Moskowitz, is to rule on today. For a start, Mr. Lipper plans to revalue the remaining assets based on an examination by the accounting firm BDO Seidman.
According to Mr. Biderman, the plan aims to return to investors, on average, 83 percent of their invested funds. "We are working to redistribute the money to whom it belongs," Mr. Biderman said. "We just want to do what is right. So far, 65 percent of our investors support the plan."
Mr. Lipper declined to comment.
The remaining 35 percent or so are opposed, some vehemently so. These partners are among the early investors in the Lipper funds and, in a brief filed to Judge Moskowitz, they state that the Lipper plan discriminates against them, in favor of investors who came on board in 2000 and 2001, when much of the fund's money was raised.
"You can't rewrite history," said Mark P. Ressler, a lawyer representing these investors. "The plan violates the partnership agreement. Plus, based on these mispricings, Lipper took in $40 million in performance fees. If he is going to revalue the capital account, he should revalue his performance fees."
A number of investors, both in support of and against the plan, are planning to sue Mr. Lipper on grounds of negligence and fraud, lawyers say.
Those that worked with Mr. Lipper on Wall Street say his strength was as a relationship banker, and he was not an expert in arcane areas like convertibles arbitrage. Without an acute understanding of these investment fields, it is all the easier to lose money.
Mr. Lipper's supporters say they find it hard to believe that he would be involved in an attempt to distort the fund's value. After all, he had much of his own money at stake, along with that of his four daughters and his former wife, Evelyn Gruss. 
"I've known Ken for more than 30 years; we joined up at Lehman Brothers in 1969," said Roger Altman, a former deputy Treasury secretary in the Clinton administration and the chairman of Evercore Partners, an investment bank. "Ken always had a natural aptitude for finance, and I know him to be an honest person."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Commercials for the Super Bowl return to the tried and true.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
JUST as the identities of Super Bowl XXXVII's two foes become clearer with each playoff matchup, so, too, do the plans of marketers for running commercials during the game, the biggest advertising event of MMIII.
 The traditional formula followed by advertisers -- sponsoring spots that are replete with stars, humor, surprises, music and animals -- is back in style after the recent spate of dot-com hyperbole and post-9/11 patriotism. 
 For instance, a prominent victim of the taxman, the singer Willie Nelson, will appear in a commercial for the tax preparer H&R Block. And PepsiCo and its agencies are enlisting the shilling skills of the Osbourne family and Michael Jordan to sell two beverage brands, Pepsi Twist and Gatorade, respectively.
Only a half-dozen of the 61 half-minute commercial slots in the game remain to be sold on the ABC broadcast of the National Football League championship game, to be played on Jan. 26. "We're right where we should be at this time," said Ed Erhardt, president for customer marketing and sales at ABC Sports and its sibling, ESPN, both part of the Walt Disney Company. 
"We're better than 90 percent sold today," Mr. Erhardt said yesterday. "We expect good demand for what's left, and there's not a whole lot left." Fox, which broadcast the game in 2002, had sold slightly less commercial time at this point last year.
The commercial time remaining in this year's Super Bowl is in the third and fourth quarters, which typically sell more slowly than spots in the first half. Usually, Super Bowl viewing does not significantly drop off as a game goes on, unless the score is tremendously lopsided; if the score is close at the end, as it was last year, the ratings often grow.
Though Mr. Erhardt declined to discuss prices for Super Sunday spots, agency and media executives say they are paying or being asked to pay an average of $2 million to $2.2 million for each 30 seconds. That represents a nice increase from the estimated average of $1.9 million charged for Super Bowl XXXVI in 2002.
Even in a difficult economy, "a leader demonstrates a desire to lead, to grow the company," said Robert Hanson, president for the Levi's brand at Levi Strauss & Company in San Francisco. Levi Strauss will run a commercial in the second quarter to introduce the Type 1 line of jeans.
"It's the Super Bowl of advertising, too, so running a commercial makes a statement," he added, "asserting our stature as a category leader for a product launch that's the most important in Levi history."
The commercial, by the New York office of Bartle Bogle Hegarty, will provide the final clue in a contest now under way on the Levi Strauss Web site (www.levi.com) to win a package valued at $150,000, for the 150 years the company has been in business. The spot, which features a stampeding herd of buffalo to salute the Levi Strauss Western heritage, carries the theme "Bold since 1853," which morphs into an updated promise of "Bold since 2003."
Speaking of updated, the commercial for Gatorade uses special effects to depict the present-day Michael Jordan being challenged to a game of one-on-one basketball by a 1987 version of himself. The spot, which began running last week during the college football bowl games, ends when a college-age Jordan seeks a chance to play. While Gatorade is seen each year on the sidelines during the game -- and on the field if a team carries a barrel into dousing range of its coach -- the spot is the brand's first appearance as a Super Bowl advertiser.
"It's a very purposeful choice," said Dennis Ryan, chief creative officer at Element 79 Partners in Chicago, the Gatorade agency, which is part of the Omnicom Group. "Gatorade is coming off its most successful sales year ever, and we want to build on that momentum."
The commercial was produced with digital effects from Digital Domain and directed by Joe Pytka, who has worked with Jordan on many commercials.
Another reason for Gatorade's Super Sunday foray is that it is now owned by PepsiCo, which acquired its former parent, Quaker Oats, in August 2001. "PepsiCo has done well by this media venue," Mr. Ryan said, referring to the popularity of spots for snacks sold by the Frito-Lay division as well as soft drinks sold by the Pepsi-Cola division.
Two soda brands -- Pepsi Twist, a lemon-flavored version of Pepsi-Cola, and Sierra Mist, a lemon-lime rival to 7Up -- are to be advertised during the game. Last month, a Pepsi Twist commercial with the Osbournes was filmed at the family's Los Angeles home, and that spot is expected to turn up during the Super Bowl. Executives at Pepsi-Cola and its agency, the New York office of BBDO Worldwide, part of Omnicom, declined to discuss their Super Bowl ad plans.
Also mum on specifics of their Super Sunday strategy are H&R Block and its agency, Campbell Mithun in Minneapolis, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies. The agency gained attention for a spot during the Super Bowl last year using a re-recorded version of the Beatles song "Taxman." All that Richard Goldsmith, a spokesman for H&R Block, would say is that the commercial would be humorous and feature "a well-known and appropriate celebrity."
That celebrity, according to Promo magazine, a trade publication, will be Mr. Nelson, the country singer who had to pay the government after his home and other assets were seized in 1990 by the Internal Revenue Service for nonpayment of $16.7 million in taxes. The commercial is part of an advertising and promotional campaign to pitch a service from H&R Block called Double Check, which reviews a customer's previously filed tax forms.
(Mr. Nelson's appearance will evoke a commercial for a brokerage firm around three decades ago featuring the boxer Joe Louis, whose tax and financial difficulties were notorious, in which -- if memory serves -- Louis asked, "Edwards & Hanley, where were you when I needed you?")
Other advertisers returning from last year include the two job-search Web sites that will have faced off for five consecutive Super Bowls: Monster, formerly Monster.com, part of TMP Worldwide, and HotJobs, formerly HotJobs.com, part of Yahoo.
"It's our Christmas, if you will," said Marc Karasu, vice president for advertising at HotJobs in New York, as job seekers pursue New Year's resolutions to find better posts and companies firm up hiring plans.
"Marketers are constantly striving to find a way to reach the right person with the right message at the right time," he said. "And here we have people receptive to our message who are actually looking for commercials, because people watch the Super Bowl as much, if not more, for the commercials as for the game."
HotJobs and its agency, Brand Architecture International in New York, part of the TBWA Worldwide division of Omnicom, are still discussing plans for their spot, Mr. Karasu said, which is likely to run in the third quarter. Monster and its agency, Arnold Worldwide in Boston, part of the Arnold Worldwide Partners division of Havas, declined to reveal their Super Bowl ad plans.
Other advertisers that are buying commercials in the game include Anheuser-Busch, FedEx, General Motors and Visa.

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK; 
Farewell, Sauteed Foie Gras, It's Time for Steak and Spuds

BYLINE:  By William Grimes 

 BODY:
LET'S open the menu and see what looks good to eat in the New Year. I see a juicy sirloin steak at Savannah Steak. I'm sure you could get a baked potato with that. There's a New York strip steak at M. J. Grill, an offshoot of Mark Joseph Steakhouse, and plenty of the same at Frankie & Johnnie's. Terrance Brennan, of Picholine and Artisanal fame, has just opened a seafood and chops house, where, lo and behold, one cannot help noticing the filet mignon, porterhouse and other big-shouldered members of the beef family. Just for variety, there's the 48-ounce steak at Shula's Steak House in the Westin New York, where the menu is written on a football.
 Tender steaks for tough times. That's the forecast. It's doubly glum, because the spoiled diners of this overindulged city were living in a culinary paradise through the late 1990's and well into last year. Never have so many been so gloriously fed, even as the economic storm clouds gathered. Year after year, in unfeigned amazement, the Zagat Survey reported an abnormally high number of openings and a low number of closings. In an industry notorious for its near-lethal failure rate, opening a first-class restaurant in New York almost made sense. 
 A confluence of trends helped ensure that the restaurants that did open were, by any standard, of very high quality. The honor roll, in just the last couple of years, is extraordinary, with restaurants like Ilo, Pico, 71 Clinton Fresh Food, Town, Alain Ducasse, Craft, Atelier, Fiamma Osteria and L'Impero. Wall Street money and a booming tourist economy encouraged restaurateurs to roll the dice. Daniel Boulud calculated, correctly, that New York could handle a $29 hamburger. With a little hemming and hawing, the city even adjusted to the almost insolent prices at Alain Ducasse. 
The steady improvement in the city's fortunes, and safer streets, made the city attractive to tourists as never before. Making up for lost time, developers built hotels. Each of those hotels had a restaurant. In fact, there seemed to be an unwritten law that a hotel, to rate as chic, had to have a first-rate restaurant. It might be French, but not necessarily. These prestige showcases allowed a new generation of American chefs -- the successors to the likes of David Burke, Charlie Palmer and Larry Forgione -- to step forward. They turned out to be a nervy, highly talented bunch. 
The city's rising fortunes made formerly fringe neighborhoods ripe for colonization. Just as the Flatiron district lured forward-looking restaurateurs a decade ago, the meatpacking district and the Lower East Side in Manhattan, and Smith Street in Brooklyn, attracted chefs and backers with big ideas and limited budgets. Wylie Dufresne, operating out of a space the size of a coat closet on Clinton Street, established the model for a new kind of restaurant, a supercafe with tiny tables, no decor to speak of and huge ambitions in the kitchen. With the Red Cat and the Harrison, Jimmy Bradley created a new kind of American brasserie, and the long-suffering Upper West Side got its fair share of quality restaurants, led by the splashy Ouest. 
New Yorkers never had it so good. But last year, the luck ran out. The city's restaurant economy, already dealt a stunning blow by the attacks on the World Trade Center, succumbed to the inevitable, as bad economic news became routine. Yes, there were fine restaurants. Italian food got a classy setting and a top-notch chef, Michael White, at Fiamma Osteria. Scott Conant, who labored valiantly at City Eatery on the Bowery, turned up at L'Impero in Tudor City, of all places. His cleanly executed, powerfully flavored cooking, a kind of Italian-Mediterranean hybrid of his own creation, put him in the first rank of younger New York chefs, and Rick Moonen, after an abrupt departure from Oceana, worked the old magic on a new cramped stage at RM. 
I had a few quibbles with Atelier when it opened, but I also sensed enormous potential and genuine daring in the refined, herb-based cuisine of Gabriel Kreuther. This is the restaurant I most want to revisit in the coming year. I suspect it is the last truly brave restaurant New York is likely to see in quite a while.
If anyone needed a tip-off that the dining climate had changed, the sudden disappearance of Cello provided it. Opened to universal acclaim three years ago, it epitomized the late 90's spirit in Manhattan. It was expensive, exquisite and highly dependent on the kind of money that was simply not being spent in the last couple of years, especially by the Wall Street companies that make the wining and dining of clients a multimillion-dollar subindustry in New York. Restaurants that seemed to be doing brisk business night after night were often dying a slow death, as their highly profitable private dining rooms remained unbooked. If Cello, one of the finest restaurants to open in the last decade, could not survive, what hope was there for serious dining in New York? 
Downtown, David Bouley's imperial vision also came to grief. His grand plans for a combination cooking school, Asian restaurant and all-around culinary Xanadu in the Mohawk Building had to be abandoned after the attacks on the World Trade Center forced Bouley Bakery and Danube to close for months. 
For entirely different reasons, the Russian Tea Room limped to an ignominious end three years after Warner LeRoy tried to remake it in his gaudy image. It was a doomed effort. The Tea Room was always more and less than a restaurant. It served as a kind of social club and business center for the agents, performers and power brokers in the cluster of entertainment businesses that grew up around Carnegie Hall over the decades. The business changed. The old agents and moguls died off. The Russian Tea Room lost its reason for existence, and its soul. Nothing could have brought it back to vigorous life, but the idea that the old place could become a golf museum is shocking.
I suspect that 2003 will shape up as the year of living timorously. Already, restaurants all over town are simplifying their menus, dropping their prices and trying to present themselves as bistros, brasseries or diners. Guastavino's has refashioned itself as an American brasserie, and Pico, a restaurant that by rights should be turning away business, has opened a cafe up front. Increasingly, the smart money seems to be flowing toward restaurants that serve the dual function of restaurant and lounge, like Theo, Hudson Cafeteria or Meet. The food may or may not be good at such establishments, but it can get away with being truly bad, as Hudson Cafeteria and Tao have shown. Food is present, but it is not the point. The way it looks is often more important than the way it tastes.
There are points of light on the horizon. The smallest may be the brightest, WD50, Mr. Dufresne's economically named follow-up to 71 Clinton Fresh Food, up the block on Clinton Street. Expectations could not possibly be any higher. Jean-Georges Vongerichten, the last chef on earth who needs to open another restaurant, plans to open one anyway. This one, in TriBeCa, called 66, will be devoted to the cuisine of Shanghai.
Alain Ducasse, perhaps the only chef who can make Mr. Vongerichten seem lacking in get-up-and-go, plans to open a populist dining spot called the Mix, at 68 West 58th Street. Jeffrey Chodorow, who brought New York Hudson Cafeteria and Tuscan Steak (soon to be reborn, with the help of Rocco DiSpirito, as Tuscan), is Mr. Ducasse's partner in this venture, as yet only hazily defined. Mr. Ducasse has given Paris macaroni and cheese. Now let's see what he can do with a root-beer float. Mario Batali is on the verge of opening Otto, at 1 Fifth Avenue, his attempt to show New York what pizza should be. 
Yes, 2003 looks like the year when New York holds its breath for a pizza parlor. Meanwhile, the hapless AOL Time Warner has a corporate palace ready to open on Columbus Circle, just as its stock is flirting with single digits. Naturally, as if the recession never happened, there will be no shortage of budget-breaking restaurants to marvel at. Gray Kunz, at loose ends ever since leaving Lespinasse, looks ready to raise the curtain on the third act of his career. Thomas Keller, perhaps the most critically celebrated chef in the United States, will open a branch of the French Laundry. Masa Takayama plans a Manhattan version of his brutally expensive Los Angeles sushi restaurant, Ginza Sushi-Ko. And the inescapable Mr. Vongerichten is scheduled to chime in with -- what else? -- a steakhouse. 
I'll bet you can't get a baked potato with that.

HEADLINE: WINES OF THE TIMES; 
1998 vs. 1999 Cabernets: Call It a Draw

BYLINE:  By FRANK J. PRIAL 

 BODY:
WHEN we think of Bordeaux, we think almost automatically about vintages. When someone observes, "The 2000's may be the best since the 82's," no one has to ask, "Whose 2000's?" Bordeaux enthusiasts can recite the names of the great vintages -- and the poor ones -- back into the 19th century. 
 California's best wines, taking their cue from Bordeaux, are also vintaged. But there the similarity ends. For all its fame, Bordeaux is a marginal area for growing grapes, and its destiny is controlled by the weather. California's weather patterns can be challenging too but, in the end, it will almost always be more conducive to grape growing and winemaking than Bordeaux's. 
 The 1998 and 1999 vintages in California, which underwent the scrutiny of the Dining section's tasting panel, have emerged in the shadow of a huge 1997 harvest that produced a large quantity of rich, beautifully balanced wines, especially among the cabernets and cabernet-based wines. Both 1998 and 1999 were years in which difficult weather conditions, and El Nino, decreed that winemakers had to work hard to produce good wines from yields that were substantially smaller. 
In spring 1998, heavy and continuous rain made it look for a time as if the vines would never flower, which meant that many grapes would never ripen. The result: a short crop of less than fat, juicy fruit. Spring was laggard in 1999, too, but the fall was sunny and kind to those who waited to pick. Two problematic years that, in fact, turned out better wines than they should have. And, taking their cues from the high-priced '97 wines, winemakers probably set prices higher than they should have been for these less successful vintages. 
Since critical opinions have differed in the last two or three years over which of these two vintages was the best, our tasting panel looked at '98 and '99 California cabernet sauvignons to see just how much, from the consumer's point of view, the vintage designations mattered. As it turned out, very little. In putting together our Top 10 list, there were five each of the '98 and '99 vintages. The panel consisted of three regulars, Amanda Hesser, Eric Asimov and me, along with David Gordon, the wine director of Tribeca Grill, a New York restaurant. 
California produces cabernet from one end to the other, from almost the Mexican border all the way to Oregon. To impose some order on our sampling we concentrated on wines from the premium cabernet growing region in the state, the Napa Valley, with a few Sonoma wines added for contrast. There were 15 pairings of 1998's and 1999's, three of them from Sonoma. Prices ranged from a high of $100 a bottle to a low of $20, with the average just over $43.
Our overall impression was one of consistently good if not outstanding quality, but we sought in vain for any characteristics that defined either vintage or any particular winemaker. As Mr. Asimov noted, "There's consistency here, not individuality." From the least to the most expensive among these 30 bottles, there was a similarity of style that belied so many claims by growers and their advertising agencies that they produce something unique. Napa, I have found, is like Detroit, where they change the door knobs and leave everything else the same.
That said, we did have our favorites. And in those that we preferred we found depth, lushness, a lovely rich fruit aroma and a touch of elegance. Those qualities -- along with the word "expensive" -- certainly fit our top two cabernets, each of which received three stars: one from Sonoma, the 1999 Chateau St. Jean Cinq Cepages ($70), and one from the Napa Valley, the 1998 Grgich Hills ($55). 
The Chateau St. Jean was a big rich wine for a 1999, apparently the result of severe selection. For Mr. Gordon, the wine's structure was formidable, with the tannins and fruit melding into a delicious wine. Mr. Asimov thought it was a "full wine, with a good cabernet aroma."
The Grgich had good body, too, along with the beautiful cabernet bouquet that has been a Mike Grgich signature. Mr. Asimov appreciated its "softness" and its "herbal qualities" and Ms. Hesser its "freshness."
Our best value, the 1999 Honig from the Napa Valley, was rated at two and a half stars and cost $28 -- or $15 less than the average price for the tasting. Ms. Hesser thought it was smooth and elegant, and I thought it was a well-knit, fairly complex wine. 
There were few other wines in our tasting that sold for less than $30, and the least expensive of them all, the 1999 Franciscan Oakville Estate, from Napa, at $20, made our Top 10 chart with two stars, while its 1998 vintage, barely missed. Both Mr.Gordon and Ms. Hesser called the '99 easy to drink. "Very quaffable," they both said.
Two other wines to garner two and a half stars were the 1998 Robert Mondavi from Napa, at $27, and the 1998 Stag's Leap Wine Cellars Napa at $95. Stag's Leap's 1999, at $100, also barely missed the Top 10. I liked them both as big, California superripe wines.
A note on prices: One might have hoped that the wine glut and the economy would have combined to lower some of these cabernet prices. An average price of $43 means that the average price of these wines in good restaurants would be more than $60. In these obviously leaner times, that is unacceptable. What's more, in almost every instance, the '99 cost more than the '98, sometimes considerably more.
True, these were both relatively small crops, a factor that might justify increases in better times. But retailers across the country are reporting growing interest in moderately priced wines, meaning $20 or less. Italy, the South of France, Australia and New Zealand, to name a few sources, are producing better wines every year and selling them at attractively low prices. It's time for American producers to take heed. 

Tasting Report: Some Like It Lush and Intense, Others Soft and Restrained

Chateau St. Jean $70
*** rating: three stars
Sonoma County Cinq Cepages 1999
Frank J. Prial summed it up as rich, complex and intense. Eric Asimov called it dense with a long finish. Amanda Hesser said it was nicely fruity, and David Gordon liked its richness. The '98, which was judged lighter and greener, received one star.

Grgich Hills $55
*** rating: three stars
Napa Valley 1998
Firm, rich and dense, Gordon said. Asimov called it fruity and easygoing with enticing aromas, while Prial and Hesser liked its freshness and harmony, with Prial saying it had a true cabernet flavor. The panel liked the '99, too, but felt that it had slightly less depth, giving it two stars.

BEST VALUE
Honig Napa Valley 1999 $28
** 1/2 rating: two and a half stars
The '99 edged the '98, which received two stars. Hesser called the '99 smooth and elegant, and Gordon agreed, saying it was more elegant than the '98. Prial said it was complex and well made, and Asimov preferred the concentration and balance of the '99.

Robert Mondavi $27
** 1/2 rating: two and a half stars
Napa Valley 1998
No question here, the panel clearly preferred the '98, finding it more substantial, intense, lush and fruity than the '99, which received one star. For Gordon, the aromas were too earthy, and Prial said it was too vegetal.

Stag's Leap Wine Cellars $95
** 1/2 rating: two and a half stars
Napa Valley S.L.V. 1998
The panel was split on these big wines; the '99 got two stars. Asimov chose the more restrained '98, finding the '99 overripe and almost syrupy, but Prial voted for the fruitier '99. Gordon called the '99 a fruit bomb, but found more similarities than differences, while Hesser found the '98 more pleasing.

Mount Veeder $40
** rating: two stars
Napa Valley 1998
Another very close call, but the '98 squeaked by the '99, which also got two stars. The panel noted the consistency of the two vintages, but was surprised to find that the more closed-in of the two turned out to be the '98, which opened up with exposure to air. Hesser found the '99 luscious and soft.

Turnbull Napa Valley $37
** rating: two stars
Oakville 1999
Another narrow victory, with the '99 overcoming the '98, which received 1 1/2 stars. Asimov found the '99 rich but soft, and judged the '98 as fleeting. Gordon preferred the fruitiness of the '99 over the vegetal '98, but Prial found the '98 more powerful and rich. Hesser liked them equally, calling the '99 more subtle and the '98 clean with a nice finish.

Franciscan Oakville Estate $20
** rating: two stars
Napa Valley 1999
The '99 scraped by the '98, which also got two stars. Gordon liked the longer finish of the '99, found it easy to drink, while Asimov found it more reticent than the obvious '98. Hesser thought that the '99 was a big wine, but needed more follow-through. Prial preferred the easygoing '98, detecting barnyard qualities in the '99.

Jordan Sonoma County 1999 $48 ** rating: two stars
Asimov and Prial both liked the fruitiness, complexity and long finish of the '99, compared with the '98, which was rated at 1 1/2 stars. Asimov called the '98 simple, and Prial said it was flat, but Hesser preferred the '98, calling the '99 watery. Gordon, who judged the two evenly, found the '98 bigger and the '99 more polished.

Napanook Napa Valley 1998 $38
** rating: two stars
The '98 melded in the mouth, Hesser said. Asimov found the '98 closed but with more potential than the harsh '99, which received one star. He speculated that the '99 would improve with age. Gordon called the '98 dense and the '99 light, while Prial preferred the flowery '98 over the strong '99.

Ratings reflect the panel's reaction to the wines, which are tasted with names and vintages concealed. The panelists this week are Frank J. Prial, Amanda Hesser, Eric Asimov and a guest, David Gordon, wine director of Tribeca Grill. While the number of wines tasted will differ depending on the category, they will represent the selection of wines generally available in good retail shops and restaurants. Prices are those paid in wine shops in the New York region.

HEADLINE: Korea Feeling Pressure as China Grows 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 7 

 BODY:
Half a century ago, the waves of Chinese coming to Korea were soldiers pouring over the Yalu River to impose Communism. Today, the waves of Chinese are delegates to trade and investment conferences or are other foot soldiers for capitalism.
 With Japan, Asia's largest economny, stagnating, South Korea, No. 3 in Asia, is experiencing extraordinary growth in trade and investment with China, which is No. 2. 
 "In five years, we built a route network in China that took us almost 30 years to develop with Japan," said Kim Yong Jin, the manager for Korean Air Lines at Incheon, Seoul's $5.6 billion airport, where China traffic is jumping 20 percent a year. China, already the largest destination for South Korean investment, is now South Korea's largest export market, based on sales, which expanded 29 percent in 2002.
But as China has become South Korea's largest economic partner almost overnight, it has also become a threat. 
"For years, Korea has long been the low-cost, high-efficiency producer, but now Chinese labor is eating into the South Korean margins," said Scott Snyder, Korea representative for the Asia Foundation, a research group partly financed by the United States government. "The Koreans have to run faster -- they are starting to feel the warm breath of China on their backs."
Korea's leading exports to China last year were cellphones and computers, displacing steel and petrochemical goods. By 2010, the Korean government forecasts, China will be on a par with Korea in such major industries as cars, semiconductors and shipbuilding. In other industries, the gap is measured in months.
South Korea's shipbuilders, the world's largest, are turning to building liquefied natural gas carriers and other value-added vessels, since China's shipbuilding industry is already focusing on the market for simpler vessels.
In 2000, Korea's $53.4 billion in information technology production amounted to 5 percent of world production, below China's 6 percent.
And Korea's information technology production is not growing as fast as China's, several recent studies warn.
China has already outstripped Korea in desktop production, printed circuit boards, semiconductors and videotape recorders.
"China is going to, sooner or later, compete with us and catch up in all sectors," said Lee Jung Hoon, a Yonsei University international relations professor.
By 2007, South Korea's industrial hollowing is expected to spread to such technology-intensive industries as electronics and automobiles, as production lines may start moving to China.
Already, almost half of the major production companies around Seoul have moved lines offshore, largely to China. In 2001, for the first time, South Korea recorded an absolute drop in manufacturing workers, a loss of 45,000 jobs.
"Thank God, Mao Zedong gave us a 20-year head start," Song Hee Yhon, dean of the College of Northeast Asian Studies, said, referring to the founder of modern China's low-growth Communist economics. "In three to five years from now, Korea could face the same difficulties as Japan."
Already, Korea is experiencing trade skirmishes with its new biggest economic partner.
China, dismayed by its large trade deficit with Korea, has imposed restrictions on 16 types of Korean products, while Seoul did the same with 6 of China's. Last year, most famously, Beijing put tariffs on South Korean mobile phones to retaliate against Seoul's tariffs on Chinese garlic.
Still, China seems destined eventually to overtake other countries' economic presence here, including that of the United States.
There has already been some shifting. In finance, for instance, American banks like Bank of New York, Bank of Hawaii and Fleet National Bank are closing South Korea branches, as are the Japanese banks Fuji and Asahi. At the same time, branches are being added by two Chinese banks -- the state-owned Industrial and Commercial Bank of China and the Hong Kong and Shanghai Banking Corporation unit of HSBC Holdings.
"The U.S. is still extremely important because of the investment we have here, the technology we bring here -- we have 40,000 Korean students in the states," said Tami Overby, executive director of the American Chamber of Commerce in Korea. 
But in a decade, Korea's economic ties with China will eclipse those with the United States, a majority of 51 future leaders of South Korea, age 30 to 49, predicted when they were interviewed a year ago by Gallup Korea for a project commissioned by the National Defense University in Washington.
Koreans, who love surveying themselves, give clear signs of making an unchecked investment stampede into China.
In one study, almost 7 out of every 10 Korean overseas investors chose China as their destination, according to the Korea Chamber of Commerce and Industry. (A Federation of Korean Industries report calculated that the average price of land and the average wage in China are, respectively, one-fourth and one-eighth the levels in Korea.)
In a survey of executives at South Korea's 50 largest business groups, 56 percent said they planned to expand investments in China this year. None planned to reduce investments, according to the Federation of Korean Industries, which released the poll last week.
The pace of deals announced here is dizzying.
Last month, the Hyundai Motor Company, South Korea's largest car company, started producing cars in China, the first step in a planned $1.1 billion investment to produce 500,000 cars there by 2010. Initial sales have been so promising that Hyundai just doubled its 2003 sales target to 50,000.
As evidence of the increasingly two-way flow in investment, the Shanghai Automotive Industry Corporation, China's No. 3 carmaker, announced in October that it was investing $60 million in a partnership with General Motors to revive three Daewoo auto plants.
In November, Shinsegae, South Korea's largest retailer, announced plans to invest $400 million in China, starting with two supermarkets in Shanghai next year. At the same time, the SK Group, South Korea's third-largest conglomerate, announced plans to increase its investment in China eightfold next year, to $100 million.
In the last decade, the Samsung Group, South Korea's largest conglomerate, has invested $2.5 billion in China, creating 10 sales subsidiaries and 26 production companies, employing a total of 42,000 people. Aiming at China's growing middle class, Samsung produces double-door refrigerators, automatic washing machines and liquid-crystal-display televisions there, and is considering passenger cars, notebook computers and LCD computer screens.
With Seoul a 90-minute flight to places in Northeast China where there are large populations of ethnic Koreans, South Korean companies are studying the possibility of moving offshore Korean-language back-office units like call centers and data processing.
South Koreans are setting up two industrial parks in Chinese cities near North Korea: one in Shenyang, the other in Dandong.
Speaking Chinese has become as valuable a skill as speaking English. "The number of member companies seeking Chinese-speaking employees increased fivefold last year," according to Lee Kwang Seok, president of Incruit, an Internet-based employment agency.
Outside a Chinese-language institute in Seoul, Hwang Chung Tae, a high school junior, gave his thumbnail view of Northeast Asia: "South Korea is such a small country, and the population is way too high. Japan is dying now. But China is getting to be a big star. We like China."
Travel agencies have been offering discount tours to China, and an estimated 1.8 million South Koreans, or 4 percent of the population, visited there in 2002.
Korean Air Lines and Asiana Airlines, the nation's two largest airlines, now have competing route networks, with each airline flying from Incheon to 13 cities in China and to 13 cities in Japan. Korea is midway between much of Japan and eastern China, and Incheon hopes to become the regional hub.
Seong Y. Park, honorary chairman of the Kumho Group, which owns Asiana, also has great expectations. "I see big opportunities in China," he said. "I can imagine one billion passports."

HEADLINE: Minolta and Konica Plan to Merge by Endof 2003 

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 7 

 BODY:
It is a two-front war of Napoleonic proportions: battling against bigger, more cash-rich rivals at home while trying to fend off leaner, hungrier competitors overseas. 
 Konica and Minolta, two major Japanese makers of cameras and office equipment, found themselves in similar strategic straits, trying to squeeze out profits on crowded commercial battlefields dominated by the likes of Canon, Ricoh and Sony. So they have decided that the answer is to band together: they announced today that they would merge by year's end. 
 At first glance, the combination, to be called Konica Minolta Holdings, seems to be as synergistic as they come. Konica's strengths are in film and lenses, while Minolta is best known for cameras and printers. Together, they will rank fourth in Japan's precision equipment industry, which includes photographic equipment; they said today that they hoped to increase sales by 18 percent and to more than double profit, to 150 billion yen ($1.25 billion), by March 2006. 
"We should win a large share in the fields we think are valuable," said Yoshikatsu Ota, president of Minolta. "I don't think we will lose out" to bigger rivals.
But like many Japanese merger partners, the two companies are choosing to bulk up and butt heads with their opponents, rather than focus more narrowly on the most profitable parts of their businesses. The pattern is a ritual in nearly every industry that matters in Japan, from airlines to banking to construction. So is the usual outcome: the combined company typically controls more of its market but ekes less profit from it than before, its stock price falls and its debts mount.
The Konica-Minolta combination will be big, starting with sales of 1.1 trillion yen ($9.2 billion) and nearly 39,000 workers, but not big enough to displace Canon, Fuji Photo Film or Ricoh. Those three -- the precision equipment industry's top three spots -- have a 90 percent lock on the copier market in Japan. 
The picture is even more challenging overseas, where Minolta makes four-fifths of its sales. In the United States, the companies are up against Hewlett-Packard, Xerox and Kodak; in Asia, they face Samsung and other manufacturers operating in countries where wages and other costs are much lower than in Japan.
"Globally, the Japanese are still technology leaders, but there are too many competitors," said Carlos Dimas, an analyst at West LB Securities in Tokyo. "The market for digital cameras and office equipment is flooded, regardless of whether they are Chinese, Korean or Japanese."
The companies said they would eliminate about 4,000 jobs, or 10 percent of their combined work force, over the next three years to reduce costs. But executives offered few details about debt, saying only that they would continue the two companies' current restructuring plans, which began three years ago.
Cutting costs is crucial, particularly at Minolta, which has debts equal to more than five times equity, making it one of the most deeply indebted in the industry. It has lost money for the last two years, and Moody's Investors Service rates its debt at B2, five notches below investment grade.
By contrast, Canon is expected to report a record profit for the current fiscal year, and both it and Sony are generating extra cash from their businesses.
Minolta is also losing out as the camera industry increasingly turns digital. Global sales of digital cameras are expected to grow 25 percent in 2003, according to the InfoTrends Research Group. Canon, Sony, Matsushita Electric Industrial and other Japanese makers are inundating the market with cheap models that consumers have a hard time telling apart. But they are draining sales from one of Minolta's mainstay businesses, analog single-lens reflex cameras.
Konica has a much healthier balance sheet than Minolta, and has done well selling film in China, Russia and other emerging economies. But it has never gained much traction in the world's most lucrative film market, the United States, where Kodak and Fuji Photo Film dominate.

HEADLINE: Carnegie's Season, With More to Come 

BYLINE:  By ANNE MIDGETTE 

 BODY:
The Berlin Philharmonic's first American appearances under Simon Rattle and a new Perspectives series with Emanuel Ax, Michael Tilson Thomas and Dawn Upshaw: these are some of the offerings on the 2003-4 schedule at Carnegie Hall, announced on Tuesday.
 The formal introduction of the season's biggest innovation, though, the opening of the new Zankel Hall -- a 650-seat performance space beneath the present building -- has been put off to a separate occasion in April. 
 While its concerts remained tantalizingly unannounced, Zankel Hall still made its presence felt on Tuesday. All four new works commissioned by the Carnegie Hall Corporation, for example, will have their world premieres in the hall. 
These include chamber pieces by Marc-Andre Dalbavie, Kaija Saariaho and Steven Stucky, all involving Mr. Ax. Mr. Ax's Perspectives series focuses on Debussy, and these three new pieces are all based on Debussy's plan for a set of six sonatas, left incomplete at the composer's death. The fourth world premiere is a work for soprano and ensemble by Osvaldo Golijov, to be performed by Ms. Upshaw. 
Because of the programming for Zankel Hall, Carnegie is also presenting some 20 fewer concerts in its two other halls, the Isaac Stern Auditorium and Weill Recital Hall. The number of presentations overall will be higher. 
"This season we have managed the institution within the fiscal realities," said Robert Harth, the hall's executive and artistic director, alluding to the straitened circumstances faced by all arts organizations in the current economic client. "I still believe passionately that classical music is alive and well."
In September John Adams is to assume the Debs Composer's Chair, a three-year position. Two of his works -- "My Father Knew Charles Ives" and "Guide to Strange Places" -- will have their New York premieres in the course of the season.
Opening night, on Oct. 1, will be the first of three concerts by the Kirov Orchestra under Valery Gergiev, with the violinist Maxim Vengerov as soloist in Lalo's "Symphonie Espagnole." Mr. Vengerov will return later in the season, performing Bach's solo partitas and sonatas. 
The Berlin Philharmonic's three November concerts range from two Haydn symphonies to the American premieres of a piece by Henri Dutilleux for soprano and orchestra (featuring Ms. Upshaw) and a piece by Heiner Goebbels.
Sir Simon will also lead the Philadelphia Orchestra in the New York premiere of Hans Werner Henze's 10th Symphony.

HEADLINE: REGIONAL MARKET: 14th Streeet; 
Building Gets Face-Lift As Area Turns Upscale

BYLINE:  By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
The 70,000-square-foot two-story retail building at 25 West 14th Street, empty of tenants since 1990, has been given a face lift in the last two and half years by a new owner who hopes to capitalize on the neighborhood's continued revival. 
 A spa is operating in 25,000 square feet of the top floor of the building. Negotiations continue with several prospects for the remaining space, according to the owner, Mark Holdings, in partnership with Apollo Real Estate Advisors L.P., which frequently focuses on redeveloping properties. Apollo has earmarked $250 million to invest in redevelopment opportunities in New York, including Lower Manhattan, said Richard J. Mack, an Apollo partner. 
 Mr. Mack said the partners bought the 14th Street building, between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas, in April 2000 because of its location in a re-emerging retail area with favorable demographics. He said data from several retail brokers showed there were more than 100,000 students in the surrounding area.
Another reason for the $14 million purchase was the opening of Urban Outfitters, a youth-oriented apparel and housewares chain, at Avenue of the Americas and 14th Street. That store "created an anchor from Fifth to Sixth Avenue and a transition from mom-and-pop stores to higher-end retail," Mr. Mack said. He added that the Apollo project would continue the street's transition to more upscale retail tenants from the cut-rate stores that now dominate much of the block to the west. 
Karen H. Shaw, the executive director of the 14th Street-Union Square Business Improvement District, said the area's revival was moving from its eastern and western edges to its center, and 25 West 14th Street was part of that.
The 1920's building has had several uses and owners, including New York City, which in the 1980's occupied the top floor as an employment center while bargain shops filled the lower levels. Subsequent owners neither leased nor renovated the building, which became tattered.
The current owners invested some $5 million to give the building, with 75 feet of frontage on 14th Street, a new facade, replete with large windows. 
Robert K. Futterman, a Manhattan retail broker, said the revival of the street as a shopping destination, which he said began in 1987, had been slowed by "the uncertainty surrounding other big sites in the area." Most of those sites have since been redeveloped or filled, he said. The former 14th Street Armory, between Seventh Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas, has been replaced by an apartment tower that also houses a Y.M.C.A. At the old Bradlee's site on Union Square, he added, Whole Foods, the grocer, and Forever 21, the women's clothing chain, have leased some of the available space.
Rents in the area of 25 West 14th Street are $75 to $100 a square foot a year, compared with $125 to $200 on 14th Street between Fourth and Fifth Avenues, Mr. Futterman said.
Mr. Mack said rents at his building were $85 to $90 a square foot for the ground floor, $25 to $30 for the lower level, and "in between the two" for the top floor. The spa, which is named Clay, leased that floor in January 2001, 18 months before the renovation was completed.
As for the rest of the space Mr. Mack said, "we spent a long time negotiating with one tenant for the bottom two floors only to fail to sign a lease." He said the partners could have leased the space to small users but continued to look for national and local tenants needing large blocks of space, which are scarce. 
Luring such tenants to midblock sites has, however, been difficult. Patrick Breslin, a senior managing director at GVA Williams, a commercial brokerage firm, said that "except for corner sites, 14th Street west of Fifth Avenue hasn't grabbed the attention of national tenants."
Apollo's 14th Street redevelopment was part of the $530 million the company has invested in New York since 1993, most of it in redevelopment projects, totaling 12 million square feet of office, retail, industrial and residential space. Mr. Mack said now was a good time to invest $250 million more in part because his company believed that the economy would cause some corporations to sell real estate to raise capital.

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE; 
RAND vs. Santa Monica: the New Headquarters

BYLINE:  By MORRIS NEWMAN 

DATELINE: SANTA MONICA, Calif. 

 BODY:
When it is completed in the fall of 2004, the RAND Corporation's five-story, elliptical-shaped, 309,000-square-foot building may soon become a local landmark. More important to city planners, perhaps, is that the start of RAND's long-awaited project opens the door to the redevelopment of the Santa Monica Civic Center, an area where RAND, a prestigious research institute, was a major land owner until a few years ago. 
 But what may be most remarkable is that anything is built at all, given the history of 20 years of dashed plans and impasses between RAND and the Santa Monica city government. 
 At issue has been an oceanfront site that looked like an unparalleled opportunity in real estate but turned out to be nearly impossible to develop. The major figures in the story were RAND, a scholarly institution that made its decisions with plodding care, and a city with land-use controls so stringent that its name has become a synonym among developers for slow growth. 
RAND is a private, nonprofit organization that divides its research between military matters, its traditional strength, and other public policy issues including health and housing policy. Currently, it is consulting "with nearly every agency of the federal government," its executive vice president, Michael D. Rich, said. Previous board chairmen include Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld and the former Treasury secretary, Paul H. O'Neill.
RAND has occupied the coveted oceanfront site in Santa Monica since the early 1950's, when it began acquiring land near city hall and the municipal auditorium. By the end of the 1970's, RAND had accumulated nearly 15 acres and a sprawling building of 285,000 square feet.
By the early 1980's, the limitations of the building were becoming apparent. Electricity and plumbing were frequently interrupted, and in January 1994, the Northridge earthquake damaged the building.
A lack of air-conditioning caused average indoor temperatures to rise six degrees in the last 20 years, according to Mr. Rich. The second floor became so uncomfortable that people routinely began wearing shorts or working at home. RAND distributed free frozen fruit bars to staff members when the outside temperature exceeded 85.
Starting in the early 1980's, staff members prepared numerous studies on upgrading the existing building (with at least five different approaches) as well as on the benefits of constructing a new headquarters.
"It's not surprising that a research institution would take as long as this" to make a major facilities decision, said Iao Katagiri, a RAND deputy vice president. "The first, knee-jerk reaction here to any question is to make a study." 
RAND had some complex problems to solve. It viewed the Santa Monica property as its real estate nest egg, and hoped to pay for the new headquarters from either a land sale or a development deal.
The property was a rare asset near Southern California's densely developed coast. In the half-century since RAND settled in the city, Santa Monica had grown from a small town of summer cottages and storefronts -- the model for the seedy Bay City in the detective novels of Raymond Chandler -- to an affluent community favored by high-technology companies and the entertainment industry, among others. 
A flood of projects, together with skyrocketing land values, made some residents think they were under siege from developers. Starting in the 1970's, the Santa Monica City Council imposed many limits on commercial construction.
"The city prides itself on being tough on developers," said Dale Goldsmith, a partner in the law firm of Greenberg Glusker Fields Claman Machtinger & Kinsella of Los Angeles, who represented RAND in land-use negotiations with Santa Monica officials. "On a scale of difficulty from 1 to 10, the city gets at least a 12." 
During the mid- to late 1980's, RAND negotiated with three developers at different times to build an addition on a portion of the site. But in 1988, Santa Monica reduced by two-thirds the density that could be built on the site, as part of a sweeping down-zoning of the city. 
In hopes of obtaining more generous development terms, RAND took part in a three-year process to create a new plan for the civic center. The final version increased the density slightly, allowing as much as 500,000 square feet for a new RAND building, 250,000 square feet of commercial office space and 350 housing units. But even with the density increase, developers said they were having trouble coming up with financially feasible projects under the city's growth restrictions. Nearly three dozen developers reviewed and turned down the possibility of building on a site abutting the Pacific. 
Every proposal that developers brought forward "was too large for the community but not large enough to be financially viable" for developers, Mr. Rich said.
This rare asset was beginning to look like a white elephant until 1999, when the city manager at the time, John Jalili, broke the stalemate by persuading the City Council to buy about 11 acres of the RAND property for $53 million. 
"With public ownership of the land," said Mr. Jalili, who is now retired, "the city has more control." The revised plan calls for 330 housing units and new parks on former RAND parking lots. 
Hurdles remained. The city's planning commission turned down RAND's initial proposal for the site in 2000, in part because officials wanted the institute to allow beach-bound pedestrians to walk through the lobby of the new building.
But public access is anathema to an institution that cordons off much of its space from people without security clearances. Santa Monica officials relented only when RAND threatened to leave the city altogether, according to Mr. Rich. The Council approved the present project in November 2001.
The new headquarters is being built on a 3.7-acre site just south of the old building, and will be flanked by 300 housing units and 20,000 square feet of retail space. The old building will eventually be razed and its land converted to a park, in accordance with the new civic center plan, which emphasizes open space. 
If the long gestation of the RAND headquarters had its frustrations, the wait also allowed the staff ample time to determine what was most desirable in a new headquarters. 
Despite its sculptural form, which some people compare to a fish and others to a football, the design of the building was impelled by RAND's organizational and functional needs, said the architect, Paul Danna, a principal at DMJM Design of Los Angeles. "The issue of equality is a constant theme," Mr. Danna said. Accordingly, virtually all offices in the building are identical, measuring 10 feet by 14 feet.
RAND management also sets high value on chance meetings among people from different disciplines and the potential for intellectual cross-pollination. In the computer age, Ms. Katagiri said, "there is a disturbing tendency for researchers to isolate themselves."
Mr. Danna recalled a conversation with James A. Thomson, RAND's president, who said the perfect building would be a circle, "because it had no corner offices or dead ends." 
While a circle would be impractical, according to the architect, the designers arranged the floor plan in the form of two arcs, somewhat like two slices of cantaloupe facing each other. Courtyards on the first three levels connect the opposite wings of the building, while sky bridges on the upper two levels are expected to be lively social areas as well as corridors.
The design of the new building, Ms. Katagiri said, "creates reasons for people to get up from their chairs and meet face to face."

CORRECTION-DATE: January 15, 2003

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day last Wednesday about construction of the new headquarters for the RAND Corporation in Santa Monica, Calif., misstated the year in which the city council approved the project. It was November 2000, not 2001.

HEADLINE: California Curbed 

 BODY:
The decision by Interior Secretary Gale Norton on New Year's Day to reduce water flows from the Colorado River to farmers in California's Imperial Valley and 17 million urban consumers in Southern California was right on the mark. Though Ms. Norton could have found ways to delay the order, doing so would only have encouraged California to continue its undisciplined and unfair diversion of water to which a half-dozen other states also have rightful claim. 
 Some Bush administration critics called the decision political payback for California's support of Al Gore in the 2000 presidential election, as well as for the state's running quarrel with Washington over environmental and other issues. This argument is beguiling but untrue. Secretary Norton was simply following a path charted by her predecessor Bruce Babbitt. She was also responding, properly, to the wishes of six other states along the Colorado and its headwaters whose explosive population growth has created a thirst for Colorado River water as compelling as California's. 
 These states have been insisting that California start living up to an agreement it signed more than 70 years ago stipulating that it would divert no more than 4.4 million acre-feet of Colorado River water per year. During its long period of rapid growth, California routinely took more than its allotment. Nobody complained until the 1990's, when the other states started expanding too. So Mr. Babbit brokered a complex deal, a "soft landing" that would give California 15 years to break its water habit and return to its original allotment. He told the various parties to work out the details by Dec. 31, 2002.
A key part of the deal called for the farmers of the Imperial Valley -- who use nearly three-quarters of the allotment to begin with -- to sell some of their water to the coastal cities. But the farmers could not agree among themselves, the deadline passed, and Ms. Norton had little choice but to start reducing the flow.
These reductions will cause no immediate harm to either the farms or the cities. But a long-term solution is necessary, and is likely to involve transfers from the farmers to the cities. That will not kill off the farming economy, but it may mean switching to less water-intensive crops. More broadly, though, it will mean that a state that has always had a hard time living within limits will learn some valuable lessons about doing so.
