HEADLINE: POLITICS AND THE ECONOMY: THE OVERVIEW; 
BUSH UNVEILS PLAN TO CUT TAX RATES AND SPUR ECONOMY

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Jan. 7 

 BODY:
President Bush proposed a big and swift new round of tax cuts for individuals and small businesses today, formally presenting a plan that he said would help the economy recover but that Democrats said was largely made up of fiscally reckless and unjustified breaks for the wealthy.
 The plan would cut personal tax rates this year, give an additional $400-per-child rebate to many families, end the taxation of most stock dividends and provide incentives for small businesses to buy equipment. 
 Its unveiling in a speech here by Mr. Bush set the stage for another round of ideological battles over whether tax cuts should go mostly to the wealthy, who pay most of the taxes, or to lower- and middle-income people, who many Democrats say need it more. By the end of the day, the two parties were trading accusations of class warfare, with the White House saying the government should not punish success and Democrats saying the administration had put aside fairness. 
The proposal, laid out in general terms by Mr. Bush with details released by the White House during the day, is sure to dominate the early months of wrangling over domestic policy in the new Congress, which convened today. The plan's outlines have already renewed the long-running debate over how to address the sluggish economy at a time when the federal budget deficit is rising, financial markets are jittery, international tensions are high and consumer and business confidence is shaky.
"We cannot be satisfied until every part of our economy is healthy and vigorous," Mr. Bush said. "We will not rest until every business has a chance to grow and every person who wants to find work can find a job." Excerpts, Page A14. 
The centerpiece of the plan is the immediate elimination of taxes on stock dividends, a provision the administration said would put $364 billion in the hands of investors over the next decade, making it the plan's biggest component. Many large corporations that do not now pay dividends said the proposal would not lead them immediately to make a change. Business Day, Page C1. 
Democrats said the White House was already on the defensive about the plan's heavy emphasis on tax cuts for investors and people with high incomes, and for good reason.
"Now that we see the president's proposal, we understand why he would be talking about class warfare because his proposal is an assault on the middle class to the benefit of the wealthy," said Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York.
The White House said the plan would cut taxes by $670 billion over the next 10 years, and just under $100 billion in this calendar year. If passed by Congress, the plan would bring total tax cuts enacted since Mr. Bush took office two years ago to more than $2 trillion over a decade.
The plan seeks to balance the conservative belief in tax cuts as an economic cure-all against the political reality that a package of tax cuts seen as primarily for the wealthy may be politically unpalatable even in a Congress in which Republicans control both chambers. To that end, the package includes components that allow the White House to argue that its benefits would be spread widely.
"These tax reductions will bring real and immediate benefits to middle-income Americans," Mr. Bush said.
Aside from the ending the dividend tax, the other main provision is a call for immediate enactment of lower personal income tax rates and other individual tax cuts that had been scheduled to take effect gradually between now and 2009 under the $1.35 trillion tax cut Mr. Bush signed into law in 2001. The income tax provisions amount to a reduction in revenues of $261 billion over 10 years.
The lower individual tax rates, which would top out at 35 percent, down from the current top rate of 38.6 percent, would be retroactive to the beginning of this year, as would a proposed expansion of the 10 percent bracket, the lowest, to higher income levels. The plan would also raise the child credit that can be claimed by all but upper income families to $1,000 from $600, and the government would send $400 per-child checks to eligible families this year to put the money in their hands right away. In addition, the plan would immediately provide married couples with a tax break that they would not have started receiving until 2005 and would not have been in full effect until 2009.
"By speeding up the income tax cuts, we will speed up economic recovery and the pace of job creation," Mr. Bush said. "If tax relief is good enough for Americans three years from now, it is good enough for Americans today."
To encourage more investment by companies, the proposal would triple, to $75,000, the amount that small businesses could write off each year for the purchase of new equipment, though it would not offer any new tax breaks to big corporations.
To address the problem of rising unemployment, Mr. Bush proposed providing as many as 1.2 million people who are receiving unemployment benefits and meeting certain other tests with up to $3,000 each to defray job retraining, child care and relocation costs. The president also called on Congress to act immediately to extend unemployment benefits, which lapsed for about 800,000 people last month. The Senate approved the measure today, extending benefits for an additional 13 weeks, and the House is expected to approve a similar measure on Wednesday.
Mr. Bush's address here to the Economic Club of Chicago came at a time when his attention is increasingly on the confrontation with Iraq and the growing tension with North Korea.
But the size of his proposal -- far bigger than had been expected on Capitol Hill or on Wall Street even a week ago -- reflected his administration's determination to reassert at regular intervals that Mr. Bush is highly sensitive to rising joblessness and other economic problems. Republicans in Washington said Mr. Bush is intent on avoiding the political mistakes that dogged his father's losing re-election campaign in 1992: losing the support of his conservative base by failing to be aggressive on taxes and allowing Democrats to cast him as out of touch with the economic concerns of working people.
Even as he talked today of helping people cope with rising debt burdens and tax bills, Mr. Bush repeatedly brought his presentation back to jobs. The White House's Council of Economic Advisers estimated that Mr. Bush's plan would create 2.1 million jobs over the next three years. 
Democrats attacked the plan as an ineffective way of giving the economy an immediate lift and a recipe for assuring that the budget deficit will grow for years or even decades to come.
The Tax Policy Center, a research organization, said 28.3 percent of the tax cuts proposed by Mr. Bush today would go to the top 1 percent of the population by income. The bottom 80 percent would receive 22 percent, the group said.
In the wake of last year's corporate accounting scandals, there has been little appetite in either party to grant tax breaks to large corporations. But Mr. Bush's plan would help them indirectly through the dividend tax cut, which could make it more attractive for companies to raise money in the stock market.
Despite widespread news reports that the president had expanded the size of the package in recent days, White House officials said he had discussed the broad outlines of the plan, including the proposal for elimination of the tax on dividends, at a White House meeting in November and had settled on them by early December.
But Ari Fleischer, the White House spokesman, told reporters on Air Force One this morning that Mr. Bush had made the final decisions on some smaller aspects of the plan, including the proposal to provide some unemployed workers with up to $3,000 in assistance, only on Monday.
Among the main challenges Mr. Bush's new economic team will face is explaining why the administration is pushing for expensive new tax cuts at a time when the budget deficit is growing rapidly.
They said the best way to eliminate the deficit was to spur more economic growth, and that tax cuts were the best tool available to do that. Mr. Bush said that deficit reduction efforts should also be focused on reining in the growth of government spending outside of the increases he has sought for the military and for domestic security.
The early reaction on Capitol Hill suggested that Mr. Bush would have trouble getting all that he wants from the Senate, where the rules give Democrats some leverage over the outcome.
Senator John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana and a centrist who often works across party lines, said he had "real concerns" about aspects of the plan, especially the elimination of the dividend tax, which he said was too expensive. He said there was room for bipartisan compromise, but that it would require to White House to give up some proposals, especially those that do not give the economy an immediate boost.

HEADLINE: An OPEC Move To Lift Output Of Oil Is Seen 

BYLINE:  By NEELA BANERJEE 

 BODY:
In an effort to scale back high oil prices, the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries appears likely to meet in Vienna as early as this weekend to discuss increasing production by up to two million barrels a day, or 8.7 percent, a senior OPEC delegate said yesterday.
 Oil prices, which are about 45 percent higher than they were a year ago, have climbed particularly steeply over the last month because a general strike in Venezuela against President Hugo Chavez has virtually shut down oil production there. The price fell sharply yesterday on reports of the possibility of an emergency meeting, with crude oil for February delivery declining $1.02 cents, or 3.2 percent, to $31.08 a barrel in New York. 
 "With regard to the price, there is an agreement from all the countries that the price should not go any higher than $28 a barrel," said one senior OPEC delegate, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. A production increase, he said, is driven by "our strong commitment to have enough oil on the market at all times and not to let a shortage take place." 
But oil industry analysts and traders pointed out that any additional oil exported by OPEC would not reach the United States soon. As a result, they said they expected the price of oil in the United States to remain above $30 a barrel. Those high prices, in turn, have pushed up retail prices in the United States of gasoline, heating oil and jet fuel.
"The global oil markets are losing two to three million barrels a day because of Venezuela, so an increase by OPEC of about 1.5 million barrels a day is still a far cry from what the markets need," said Philip J. Flynn, senior energy analyst at Alaron, a Chicago futures brokerage firm. "It's a classic case of OPEC trying to jawbone the market down. And the market is believing it, because the market is a very, very fickle animal right now."
In December, OPEC agreed to curtail rampant overproduction within its ranks as members took advantage of high oil prices by pumping more than their official quotas. But that decision was quickly rendered moot by the disruption of oil supplies from Venezuela, the fifth-largest oil producer in the world. OPEC officially produces 23 million barrels a day.
Instead, OPEC began publicly to consider the possibility of a production increase a few weeks ago, after oil prices climbed above $30 a barrel. The 10 voting members of the group have a loose agreement to confer about production changes if the average price of several kinds of crude oil falls below $22 a barrel or exceeds $28 a barrel for 20 consecutive trading days, or about one month. They consider prices in that range high enough to produce robust revenue without pushing the global economy into recession. In the past, OPEC has cut or increased production by 500,000 barrels a day.
But with the prolonged loss of Venezuelan exports and no end in sight for the strikes, OPEC may have to make more drastic production increases, or risk prices that are so high they could choke global demand for oil, analysts said.
Yet OPEC's intervention may not be enough to push prices down near $28 a barrel. Even if the cartel votes for an increase of two million barrels a day, the actual rise could prove smaller. Of the 10 members, only 3 have spare production capacity: the United Arab Emirates, Kuwait and, with the most, Saudi Arabia. No oil producers outside OPEC have any spare capacity, either. 
Together, they may produce an additional one million barrels a day, estimated Lawrence J. Goldstein, president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation. The Reuters news agency reported that oil shippers said the Saudis had already leased extra tankers to take additional crude oil to the United States, starting at the end of this month.
Even if OPEC brings new production on stream quickly, tankers need 45 to 50 days to bring oil from the Persian Gulf to the United States, where the shortfall of Venezuelan oil is being felt most acutely. It took about five to seven days to ship oil from Venezuela, which was the fourth-largest exporter of crude oil to the United States. Since the strike, American refineries have been scrambling to find crude oil, and when supplies have fallen short, they have cut their output. Refiners may still have to resort to such steps as they wait for OPEC oil to arrive, Mr. Goldstein said.
"They will not have enough supply in the system and will have to cut refinery runs," he said. "That means higher prices, not only for now but in springtime."
Mr. Goldstein pointed out that January is when oil companies start building inventories of gasoline for the spring.But if refineries are cutting output, stocks of gasoline may be less than in the past, which could push prices higher at the pump.

HEADLINE: Bush Economic Plan Has Little for New York 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 7 

 BODY:
President Bush's plan for stimulating the economy offered little help to Gov. George E. Pataki and New York lawmakers struggling to close a giant shortfall in the state budget.
 In a much anticipated speech in Chicago, the president did not propose $10 billion in grants to financially troubled states to help them make up for falling revenue, as some in New York's Congressional delegation had been told he would. 
 Instead, Mr. Bush proposed a $3.6 billion grant program to pay for job training, day care and other needs of the unemployed.
Senior administration officials said the president had decided not to cushion the deep spending cuts or tax increases that states like New York must enact to balance their books in the teeth of a national recession.
Mr. Bush's stimulus package focused almost entirely on cutting taxes for consumers and investors.
"The states will have to make their own decisions about what to do with their tax bases," said a senior administration official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
Governor Pataki, a Republican who has been lobbying the president for more federal aid, had little to say today about Mr. Bush's proposals. He remained closeted with aides going over his annual speech to the Legislature, to be delivered on Wednesday.
"We are still reviewing the president's plan," said Kevin Quinn, a spokesman for the State Budget Division.
The impact of abolishing the federal tax on dividends, as Mr. Bush proposed, on state tax revenue was unclear. The state might still be able to tax dividends, though legislative action might be required, legislative aides said.
Budget officials and state lawmakers were still puzzling over the details of Mr. Bush's proposal last night.
Aides to the State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, said the state collects about $550 million a year by taxing dividends.
United States Senator Charles E. Schumer, a Democrat, said he was told the president dropped the idea of direct grants to states at the last minute.
Mr. Schumer said the Democratic minority in the Senate would fight for more federal aid to states in the final economic stimulus bill.
"I'm disappointed that this was so low a priority that it was taken off the list at the eleventh hour," Mr. Schumer said. "It's something that is desperately needed to provide a shot in the arm quickly."

HEADLINE: POLITICS AND THE ECONOMY: NEWS ANALYSIS; 
A Bold Plan With Risks

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Jan. 7 

 BODY:
President Bush opened a second front in his 2004 re-election campaign here with an economic plan far bigger and bolder than many expected.
 Politically, his proposal today is a daring move intended to show a wartime president battling on the domestic front to pump new vitality into a sagging economy, a lesson learned from his father's loss of the White House. 
 It is also a risk that could cause soaring deficits and do little in the short term to stimulate the economy. And the plan has reignited the battle between Republicans and Democrats that traces back to the Reagan tax cuts of the early 1980's and that flared again in Mr. Bush's first year in office when the president began his bold tax cutting. 
But despite the storm that the $674 billion plan will generate (and the prompt Democratic attacks on it as irresponsible, ineffective and ideological show that it will be of hurricane force), Republicans hailed Mr. Bush as a leader who understood the political power of a big idea and the critical need to tend to his conservative, tax-cut loving base.
"This president is not going to be subject to the criticism that he didn't want to do anything," said Vin Weber, a former Republican congressman from Minnesota who is close to the White House. 
Mr. Weber, a member of the House leadership in the administration of President George Bush, recalled that he was in the middle of the Republican "debacle" when Mr. Bush's father raised taxes in an ailing economy as a way to fight deficits.
"It wasn't just that the country didn't see President Bush as having a bold economic agenda to lift us out of the recession," Mr. Weber said. "Beyond that, his own base thought he was doing the wrong thing. So this president has turned that inside out and around. It puts him in the opposite position that his father found himself in."
Mr. Bush's most conservative supporters bathed the president in adoration today for the plan and even hailed it as a "moral" choice that would entirely eliminate the tax that individual investors pay on stock dividends.
It is unfair, conservatives said, to "double-tax," first by taxing corporate profits and then the money sent to shareholders. But administration officials said as recently as Christmas that they were pushing the president for only a 50 percent cut in the dividend tax. 
"If you go with a 50 percent exclusion, it sounds like you're giving a special favor," said Daniel J. Mitchell, a tax economist at the conservative Heritage Foundation. "I think they've been brilliant about deciding to go bigger. I had no idea they were going to be this bold and aggressive, and that's an enormously progressive surprise."
Mr. Bush's plan was also striking in that it provided nothing for big corporations, a tainted constituency since last summer's corporate scandals.
Business leaders noted, however, that the dividend tax cut could help corporations by encouraging more investment and making it easier for them to raise money. Overt favors to corporate America, they said, were at the moment untenable for the White House.
"Economically, it doesn't matter whether you provide the tax relief to the corporation or the individual," said Mark Bloomfield, the president of the American Council on Capital Formation, a corporate-financed group that advocates tax cuts. "But politically it matters."
Mr. Bush made his case to a friendly crowd of 2,300 entrepreneurs and business leaders invited to a ballroom of the Sheraton Hotel and Towers by the Economic Club of Chicago, a civic group founded in 1927. He chose a Democratic city with a Democratic mayor in an important heartland state that went soundly for Al Gore in the 2000 presidential election, but that the White House thinks Mr. Bush can win in 2004.
"This is one of America's great cities," Mr. Bush said in a speech intended to appeal beyond conservative tax-cutting orthodoxy to an "investor class" that encompasses both political parties. "And one of the reasons why is because you have a great mayor in Richard Daley," he said.
Mr. Bush got warm but not always wildly enthusiastic applause from an audience with a heavy representation from Chicago's affluent North Shore suburbs, including some who questioned the financial practicality of his plan.
"How are we going to pay for security and a war when we flood all this money back to average Americans?" said Ann Rahn, 49, a Republican from Lake Forest.
Democrats spent the day attacking the plan as a beautifully wrapped gift for the nation's wealthiest citizens. According to an analysis by Bloomberg News, Mr. Bush himself would have saved $44,500 in income and dividend taxes on the $711,000 in taxable income he reported on his 2001 return had today's plan been enacted last year. Vice President Dick Cheney would have saved $326,555 on 2001 taxable income of $4.3 million, according to Bloomberg. Mr. Bush's plan calls for an immediate start to all personal income tax cuts now scheduled for 2004 and 2006, with the greatest gains going to the most well-off Americans.
"This is a pig that even a Republican python might not be able to swallow," said Robert D. Reischauer, the former director of the Congressional Budget Office, who is now president of the Urban Institute, a centrist research center. "It's breathtakingly large, considering the deficits and the political pressure to spend more on defense, security and prescription drugs for the elderly. Dividend tax relief is like putting frosting on an unbaked cake."
The White House was clearly ready for such criticism. Today a steady chorus of Republicans close to the administration sounded a remarkably similar theme, as if part of an organized campaign, that the Democrats had called the Republicans the party of the rich and tried to fan the flames of class warfare for more than two decades with little effect. "That argument exists with or without this plan," said Bill McInturff, a Republican pollster.
Republicans said that the plan's extension of unemployment benefits and a child tax credit were indisputably geared to ordinary Americans, and that Mr. Bush himself had taken care in his language to reach out to the anxieties of the middle class.
"Many Americans live in constant and increasing personal debt, with credit card bills so heavy they often cannot pay much more than the monthly minimum," the president said. "Millions of citizens spend their entire adult lives living paycheck-to-paycheck, never getting a chance to save for their children's education or their own retirement."

HEADLINE: POLITICS AND THE ECONOMY: THE ACTION; 
Senators Vote to Extend Benefits for Unemployed As House Elects Speaker

BYLINE:  By CARL HULSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 

 BODY:
The 108th Congress convened today under Republican control, and the Senate quickly adopted an unemployment benefits extension after a partisan debate that some saw as a prelude to the next two years.
 After 11 new senators were sworn in by Vice President Dick Cheney and Senator Bill Frist of Tennessee, the new majority leader, took his place, the Senate sought to resolve the first of the issues left over from the last session, a $7 billion plan to keep unemployment checks flowing this week to about 800,000 people. 
 Republicans had hoped to use the measure to demonstrate that the abrupt change in their leadership caused by the ouster of Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi would not stymie their ability to move legislation. But Democrats, pushing for a more generous plan to cover those whose benefits had expired, stalled the proposal for a few hours. 
 "We are leaving over one million people who have absolutely no recourse, have no assistance whatsoever because their benefits have expired," said Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader.
The unemployment plan, similar to one adopted by the Senate in November but blocked by the House, would extend through May compensation for those who have used up their state benefits. The House is expected to pass it Wednesday, allowing President Bush to sign it before the end of the week.
Fifty-four new House members were sworn in, giving the Republicans a 229-205 advantage after a net gain of six seats in the November elections. The Senate is effectively divided 51-49 in favor of Republicans.
In the House, J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois was assured re-election as speaker, given the Republican majority. The formal vote, along party lines, was 228 to 201 (one Republican was absent) over the new Democratic leader, Nancy Pelosi of California, the first woman to be nominated by her party for the post. 
Three conservative Southern Democrats -- Ralph M. Hall and Charles W. Stenholm of Texas and Ken Lucas of Kentucky -- voted present, registering their philosophical differences with Ms. Pelosi, who has a liberal background. Gene Taylor, Democrat of Mississippi, voted for John P. Murtha, Democrat of Pennsylvania.
 The House had a partisan fight of its own as Democrats opposed changes that critics say will weaken restrictions on travel and food paid for by outside groups. The rules, adopted on a 221-to-203 vote, also lift a four-term limit on the speaker imposed by Republicans after taking over the House in 1994.
"Republicans are returning to that which they criticized bitterly in 1994," said the new Democratic whip, Steny H. Hoyer of Maryland, referring to earlier complaints about Democratic rule. "They said they were going to reform the House, make it more democratic, make it more open."
Despite the early battles, Republican leaders in both the House and Senate said they wanted to work with their Democratic colleagues to reach some legislative compromises.
"We are going to have our fair share of disagreements, because that is the nature of our two-party system," Mr. Hastert said, addressing Ms. Pelosi, "But together we must always find ways to make America a better and more secure place."
Dr. Frist, the former heart transplant surgeon elevated just a few weeks ago by his colleagues, said he hoped to be able to work with Democrats on what he called the nation's challenges: a fight against terrorism, a troubled economy and crises in health care. And, in an apparent reference to the furor over the racially tinged remarks that cost Mr. Lott his job, Dr. Frist also added "ensuring our agenda is inclusive of all Americans" to the list.
"It is my hope in this Congress that we will be defined by achievement as well as a cooperative spirit," Dr. Frist said.
Opening day came with the usual pomp and ceremony associated with the arrival of new members, many of whom had fought in bruising campaigns to win their seats. Hundreds of family members were on hand for the official Congressional business and scores of receptions. Children roamed the floor of the House, and Tom DeLay of Texas, the tough tactician who is the new majority leader, cuddled his 5-month-old grandson.
With a presidential election next year and Democrats already criticizing Mr. Bush's proposed economic plan as too costly and generous to wealthy Americans, the Congressional session is certain to have its share of fights. Republicans and Democrats are also divided on proposals like Arctic oil drilling and how to provide older Americans with prescription drug coverage. And President Bush resubmitted two judicial nominations today that had been the center of partisan fights last year.
 Democrats promised to press the Republican leadership to follow through on a promise to reconsider some provisions in a domestic security measure passed last year. And Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York, introduced legislation to reinstate the draft, saying the move "is necessary to achieve a full sharing of the sacrifice which will be required of the American people if the president chooses to invade Iraq and pursues military options elsewhere." At the Pentagon, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld emphatically opposed the idea.
Dr. Frist, in his first Senate floor action, got a taste of the opposition he faces when Democrats balked at the unemployment proposal. He did not hide his displeasure, saying it had been his understanding that both parties had agreed to back the measure. "I guess that is what I can come to expect," Dr. Frist said.
Other Republicans accused Democrats of grandstanding, saying they had helped write the proposal they were contesting. "Let's not play politics out of the box with this," said Senator Rick Santorum, Republican of Pennsylvania, who said the expanded coverage sought by the Democrats would not pass the House.
 Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York, who helped work out the unemployment package, said she and other Democrats would continue to press for the expanded coverage.
Some newcomers to the Senate said they were surprised by how quickly the partisan tone surfaced. "If this is the way things are going to be, I should bring my Bible every day," said Lamar Alexander, Republican of Tennessee.
In the House, Republican officials defended the disputed rules changes, saying that allowing House offices to accept food from outside groups was simply a way to help overworked, underpaid staff by allowing them to accept pizza on late nights in the office. They said another change allowing charity groups to pay for travel by lawmakers to golf tournaments and other events would be restricted to those groups that direct most of the proceeds to charity.
Fred Wertheimer, president of Democracy 21, a watchdog group, called the changes irresponsible, particularly coming on the first day of the new Congress.
 Representative Joel Hefley, Republican of Colorado and chairman of the House Ethics Committee, said the food rule might have to be revisited because it could allow situations where lobbying groups provide dinner for whole committees meeting late. "I think it looks bad," Mr. Hefley said.

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: ASIAN ARENA; 
U.S., in a Shift, Is Willing to Talk With North Korea About A-Arms

BYLINE:  By STEVEN R. WEISMAN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 

 BODY:
The Bush administration, shifting its approach on North Korea under pressure from allies in the region, expressed willingness today to talk with President Kim Jong Il's government about its nuclear weapons program, while still refusing to offer incentives for the program to be dismantled.
 The administration's new position, negotiated during two days of meetings with envoys from South Korea and Japan, was included in a statement from the three nations. The statement also supported continuation of a separate "dialogue" with the North by South Korea and Japan. 
 Since the surprise disclosure of North Korea's nuclear weapons program in October, President Bush and administration officials had maintained that North Korea would have to dismantle the program before Washington would even talk with the North. Today's statement changed that stance. 
"The U.S. delegation explained that the United States is willing to talk to North Korea about how it will meet its obligations to the international community," it said. "However, the U.S. delegation stressed that the United States will not provide quid pro quos to North Korea to live up to its existing obligations."
The joint statement seemed to represent an effort by the administration to defuse a confrontational atmosphere marked by increasingly strident denunciations from the North and a disagreement on negotiating strategy between Washington and Seoul. The abrupt shift also showed an administration apparently scrambling to draft a coherent policy to deal with North Korea's revitalized pursuit of nuclear arms.
 On Wednesday, South Korea lauded Washington's offer to talk, but the official North Korea news agency said the United States was "working hard to bring a holocaust of a nuclear war to the Korean nation." 
 "There is an increasing danger of a nuclear war on the Korean peninsula due to the U.S. criminal policy" toward North Korea, the Korean Central News Agency said. It accused the United States of "deliberately spreading a false rumour" about the North's nuclear program "in a bid to vitiate the atmosphere of inter-Korean reconciliation and unity and foster confrontation among Koreans." 
In the last 48 hours, the administration has sought to lower the temperature on a number of fronts. At a cabinet meeting on Monday, Mr. Bush repeated several times his statement of America's peaceful intentions. The United States also decided to delay taking the issue to the United Nations Security Council, a step that administration officials had said they would push for rapidly.
An administration official maintained that the statement today was more of a shift in emphasis than a policy change. "We are putting more emphasis on talking now," he said.
Nevertheless, diplomats welcomed the statement as a new iteration by an administration that has been seen as changing its policy toward North Korea many times.
Representatives of Russia, China, Australia, Canada and the European Union were briefed on the statement this afternoon at the State Department. One diplomat later called it "a very positive development."
South Korean officials, especially, have said that although they have supported the basics of American policy in demanding that North Korea abandon its nuclear ambitions, they are worried about the situation getting out of hand. The president-elect of South Korea, Roh Moo Hyun, who takes office next month, is said by some advisers to see himself as a potential mediator between Pyongyang and Washington.
An administration official said the joint statement was transmitted to North Korea through its mission at the United Nations. 
It was not clear which country would be the next to test North Korea's reaction. One diplomat said the North and South Korean foreign ministers were scheduled to meet next week in Seoul, which could provide the first opportunity. 
Also uncertain was exactly what North Korea and its interlocutors would talk about, given that the statement today confined the proposed discussions to how North Korea could "meet its obligations to the international community" -- language that an official said referred to its commitments over the years to refrain from making nuclear weapons and to allow inspections.
Mr. Bush's national security aides insisted that any conversation with the North would be limited to freezing and ultimately dismantling its two nuclear projects: a plutonium program at Yongbyon and a hidden effort to develop a weapon by enriching uranium.
At the State Department, Richard A. Boucher, the spokesman, said that for all the language inviting talks with the North Koreans, "they have to end the programs for anything real to happen." Asked about benefits that might accrue to the North, he said a package of aid had been prepared by the administration earlier last year, before the current confrontation. This "remains on the table," he added, but only if North Korea moves toward dismantling its nuclear projects. 
Mr. Bush spoke in Chicago today to outline his economic proposals but demonstrated that the quickening tempo of the North Korea situation was not far from his mind. After renewing his demand that Saddam Hussein disarm in Iraq, Mr. Bush said the United States would "confront" the threat of North Korea, but differently from the way it is dealing with Iraq.
"In this case, I believe that by working with countries in the region, diplomacy will work," he said. "We have no aggressive intent, no argument with the North Korean people."
Yet in a gesture to those who argue that a show of strength is also useful for the North, he added that the United States "will not permit any regime to threaten the freedom and security of the American people or our allies and friends around the world."
The three-nation meeting today involved envoys who have been wrestling with the problem of North Korea for months. The American delegation was led by James A. Kelly, assistant secretary of state for Far Eastern and Pacific affairs. His counterparts were the deputy foreign minister of South Korea, Lee Tae Sik, and Mitoji Yabunaka, the Japanese Foreign Ministry's director of Asian and Oceanian affairs.
Their handiwork, a statement of about 800 words, addressed several contentious side issues that had arisen in recent days with North Korea, according to an administration official.
For example, North Korean officials have said repeatedly that the United States could solve the current confrontation by signing a nonaggression pact. The statement today emphasized that Japan, South Korea and the United States "reaffirmed" their commitment to a 1991 accord between the North and the South that included a nonaggression pledge.
The policy adjustment today is the latest of several shifts by Mr. Bush. At first embracing the Clinton-era policy of negotiation, he then conducted a re-evaluation that ended up with a policy that somewhat resembled President Bill Clinton's. Last year, after disclosures that North Korea had cheated on its 1994 pledge not to make nuclear weapons, the administration's position hardened.

HEADLINE: MAKING BOOKS; 
Spiking Up Flat Landscapes

BYLINE:  By Martin Arnold 

 BODY:
Where is the next "Lovely Bones" when it's so badly needed? Publishing people returned to their offices this week after their year-end holidaying to wintry fields of unsettling news. Book sales were flatter than desired. Just as forlorn a note was the news that one of the most important and admired independent bookstores in the country had laid off nearly 10 percent of its staff. So there was a chill on the new year before it even started, as publishers looked to a midwinter of heavy returns and less-than-hefty cash register activity.
 That's the bad news. The good news is that publishers are an optimistic lot, and many have their own equipages to cope with the bad as they try to concentrate on the good. 
 For instance, Susan Petersen Kennedy, president of Penguin Putnam Inc., is looking for new ways to market, using the Web not only to research where potential buyers for a particular book might be, but also to reach those buyers. Irwyn Applebaum, publisher of the Bantam Dell Publishing Group, said that "in good times or bad people are going to wake up and want to read a good novel." That's why, among other things, he is counting heavily in gloomy days on the less expensive mass-market paperbacks to have "the greatest entry price to bring readers back" and get them headed once again to the shelves that carry his large hardcover list. "It doesn't matter whether the reader comes to us through mass-market or trade paper or hardcover," he said. "We've got to have the capacity to bring that reader to an author."
When the book people returned from their seasonal break, the first news that gave them the quavers was the awful announcement that Denver's Tattered Cover bookstore, the independent immune from the chain-store syndrome, had laid off 27 of its staff of 300 or so, the first time in its 28 years that employees were let go because of the economy. 
A single bookstore, but one considered a bellwether, even a charm of sorts for the industry. Many a best-selling novel got its blastoff not from a chain, but from the word-of-mouth generated by the independents, making their importance often far greater proportionally than their size.
Other troubling happenings: Colorado Springs's Chinook Bookstore hasn't replaced four employees and has cut wages, and the Oscar Wilde Bookshop in Greenwich Village, the oldest gay and lesbian bookstore in the country, announced it was closing by the end of the month.
So, yes, everyone is asking where is the next "Lovely Bones" (Little, Brown), Alice Sebold's first novel, which has been the surprise runaway of the year. But Laurence J. Kirshbaum, chief executive of the AOL Time Warner Book Group, said: "We also must be realistic. What we need is a lot of singles and doubles rather than home runs." Perhaps it's easy for him to feel that loose, since "The Lovely Bones" is his book and is still churning out money. He added: "If you keep thinking of big books, it can lead to a lot of overpromotion for something that doesn't sell that well."
Still, all the houses have their hopefuls. A few: Alfred A. Knopf is trying to make John Burdett's thriller "Bangkok 8" a big breakout book this summer with a first printing of 100,000 copies, and has sent advance reader copies to 2,500 booksellers accompanied by the usual all-promising letter from its publisher, Sonny Mehta. Warner Books is pushing "Derailed" by James Siegel, a suspense novel, with a first printing of 125,000 copies and advance copies accompanied by a letter from Mr. Kirshbaum; its sister publisher, Little, Brown, has an upcoming Pete Hamill novel, "Forever."
Ms. Kennedy's group is looking to "The Kite Runner" (Riverhead) by Khaled Hosseini, a coming-of-age novel set in Afghanistan, and Caroline Alexander's "The Bounty: The True Story of the Mutiny on the Bounty" from Viking. At Grove Atlantic there will be a big fall push for Frances Itani's "Deafening," a World War I novel centered on a woman who lost her hearing because of scarlet fever.
One must have faith to succeed in producing books. "The great thing about publishing is that we all believe in the next hit -- it's coming," is the way Morgan Entrekin, the Grove Atlantic publisher, described the ethos, adding: "The book publishing business is as soft as I've seen it for a long time. You can tighten your belts but you need new books."
In times like these the romance of publishing doesn't disappear, but the emphasis is on the courting rituals. Ms. Kennedy said, "It's nice to know that among all we publish, lightning can still strike." Nonetheless, publishers, like other gamblers, cut the cards. "We now take a book apart," she said, "and think of all the different types of people who might buy it, and then try to reach them. It's a more sophisticated use of the Web. Three years ago we were paying little attention to that science."
An example: For "The Bounty," the house will use the Web to find readers interested in the mutiny's era (the late 18th century), interested in boats and boating in general, and fans of the several movie versions of "The Mutiny on the Bounty" and bombard them with sales pitches. "In the old days, we had to depend on network television and Time magazine and Vanity Fair to reach customers," Ms. Kennedy said. "We still do, but now there's also this research and communication tool, the Web, for every kind of book. Its a way of reaching even more people." 
Everyone is trying something. HarperCollins has announced what it calls its Invite the Author program, through which reading clubs can have authors take part in the club's book discussions by telephone. Only HarperCollins books allowed, obviously.
Anything that may move books is worth a try. The thought of authors and readers burning up the telephone wires with a bit of confutation is giddying. Check back in 12 months and we'll see if any of this worked. Which book will have been the "Lovely Bones" everyone was hoping to discover? Will there even have been one?

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Still Sees 3.7% Growth This Year 

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Jan. 8 

 BODY:
An International Monetary Fund official said here today that the organization was sticking with its optimistic forecast that the world's economy would grow 3.7 percent this year, with much of Asia doing even better.
 The official, Thomas C. Dawson, the I.M.F.'s director of external relations and top spokesman, said that the forecast made last autumn would not be revised before the next meeting of the fund's top officials, in April. But he did acknowledge that "the pace of recovery is rather tepid, and downside risks appear to predominate." 
 The three biggest risks, he said, in a speech at the Foreign Correspondents' Club here, are a sustained increase in oil prices, terrorist attacks and further economic deterioration in Japan. 
The International Monetary Fund, like many foreign governments and private economists, has been urging the Bank of Japan to expand the money supply more aggressively, and Mr. Dawson reiterated this today. Doing so would most likely drive down the value of the yen and would tend to increase competitiveness and the volume of Japanese exports to the United States, a possibility that has concerned some American officials.
The I.M.F. is predicting that the Chinese economy will continue to grow this year at its recent rate of 7 to 8 percent annually, while the economies of Hong Kong, Korea, Singapore and Taiwan will expand 3.5 to 6 percent a year, with Hong Kong at the lower end of the range, Mr. Dawson said. For the larger economies in Southeast Asia, notably the Philippines and Indonesia, the fund sees a slight acceleration in growth, to around 4 percent, he added, while it anticipates growth of close to 6 percent in India.
The I.M.F. forecasts are somewhat more optimistic than most private forecasts. Huang Yiping, a regional economist specializing in China, Hong Kong and Taiwan at Salomon Smith Barney, said that the investment bank was predicting global growth of 2.5 percent this year, led by China, with an increase there of 7.6 percent.
But Mr. Huang agreed with Mr. Dawson that "the risk is more in the geopolitical factors" and in the possibility that the Japanese economy may deteriorate further.
After the terror attacks of Sept. 11, some private economists predicted a sharp deterioration in the global economy in 2002 and perhaps even a recession, although Salomon Smith Barney predicted growth of 2 percent. But the I.M.F. forecast that the international economy would expand 2.4 percent, buoyed partly by the continued strength of China.
Mr. Dawson said today that the fund's best estimate now for global growth in 2002 was 2.8 percent.
His long speech today was part of a recent effort by the fund to become more open after being bitterly criticized in Southeast Asia for its secrecy in formulating responses to the region's financial crisis in 1997 and 1998.
Defending the I.M.F.'s actions then, Mr. Dawson said that the organization had realized earlier in the crisis than it had been given credit for that there were benefits in allowing larger government deficits. 
He was critical of Argentina, another economy where a currency board arrangement was undone by huge budget deficits, saying that the country might have been able to sustain its currency peg through the crisis if it had done more to balance its budget or finance its deficit in noninflationary ways.
"It was not a technical inability -- it was a political failure," he said.
I.M.F. officials will probably send a mission to Buenos Aires soon to discuss how the economy's continued difficulties should be addressed, Mr. Dawson said, adding that the fund wants to see a budget surplus and more stable monetary policy.
Mr. Dawson praised Hong Kong's currency board, which has kept the Hong Kong dollar pegged at 7.8 to the United States dollar despite several years of weak economic performance here.
By preventing devaluation and keeping Hong Kong one of the world's most expensive cities in which to live, the currency peg has been widely blamed here for contributing to the territory's severe deflation and rising unemployment. But the peg has preserved the territory's reputation as a safe place to invest with little worry about currency fluctuations.
"There's every reason to believe they will be able to continue" with the peg, Mr. Dawson said. "Markets respect track records, and there's a track record here to respect."

HEADLINE: The World Still Watches America 

BYLINE:  By Neal Gabler; Neal Gabler, author of "An Empire of Their Own: How the Jews Invented Hollywood" and "Life the Movie," is writing a biography of Walt Disney.

DATELINE: AMAGANSETT, N.Y. 

 BODY:
Once again, we are told, America's cultural hegemony is cracking. The latest proof: American television programs, which had dominated prime-time viewing in Europe and Asia for decades, are now being consigned to the late-night fringes of the schedule.
 One European TV executive was quoted as saying that you can no longer win a prime-time slot with an American show. In markets as diverse as Malaysia, France and Latin America, where "Dallas" and "Baywatch" were once blockbusters, locally produced soap operas and crime shows rule the ratings. Today, "C.S.I.," the top-rated show in this country, cannot attract even 3 percent of the viewers in South Korea. 
 Explanations for the decline range from general anti-American political sentiment to growing resentment of American cultural influence to the rising cost of American shows. There is also the privatization of the old state-run networks, which has resulted in increased competition and greater demand for programs to fill expanded schedules, even as, paradoxically, the popularity of each individual show plummets.
Still, one shouldn't mourn the end of American cultural domination quite yet. There will always be the movies. And the truth is, American movies, not TV shows, are the truly potent examples of our cultural imperialism. 
Films are far more costly than television programs and also face increased local competition, yet American movies don't seem to be suffering a similar diminution in popularity -- they continue to rake in nearly 80 percent of the film industry's worldwide take. Even in France, where sensitivity to alleged American bullying and belief in native cultural superiority may be stronger than anywhere else in the world, Hollywood movies continue to account for 50 percent to 70 percent of box office receipts every year.
All of which leads one to suspect that the reason American television shows are losing popularity has less to do with resentments or economics than with fundamental differences between American television and American film. Movies are universal, TV is not.
In the United States, the film exhibition industry erupted in the early 1900's in working-class urban neighborhoods and movies were regarded, in the words of The Nation magazine in 1913, as a "democratic art" intended specifically for the masses. 
By the 1920's, however, film became the medium of the middle, cutting a wide swath through every demographic group. The studios, which owned the theaters, had made a concerted effort to broaden their films' appeal -- making them longer and better, using marketing to establish the first heartthrobs and sirens, and erecting lavish movie palaces that would elevate the movie-going experience. By decade's end, 90 million Americans were attending the movies each week, three attendees for each American household. 
It was the ability of the movies to appeal to people of all ages, religions, ethnicities and regions that enabled Hollywood to export them. Already by 1925, 30 percent of the studios' profits came from overseas. (Today it is around 60 percent.) Part of this universality was aesthetic. Even after the silent era ended, the scale of American films, their speed and their action made them accessible to anyone. 
Part of the attraction was ideological. American films, concentrating on stars framed in close-ups, promoted the centrality and the efficacy of individual action -- a world that conformed to our vicarious will. Taken together, the artistry and the values made movie-going an otherworldly experience. Movies may be the medium of the middle in the composition of their audiences, but they are the medium of the exceptional in the way they grab those audiences.
Though television arrived in this country in the late 1940's amid fears in Hollywood that it would usurp film's audience, those concerns obviously proved ungrounded. Television couldn't have been more different a medium. Whereas the movies were made to mesmerize hundreds gathered in the dark, television was pitched to families huddled in their living rooms and dens. Whereas the movies emphasized the extraordinary, television relied on the familiar. 
From its inception, television was a medium not of the intrepid or the glamorous individual but of ensembles, and it required an understanding of group dynamics that was not always easily translatable to other cultures. A German colleague of mine told me that "ER" is virtually unintelligible (and unwatched) in his country because Germans don't understand the easy camaraderie between different races and classes on the show. 
To this aesthetic barrier was added a sociological one. Since it was sponsor-supported, television pitched itself to clusters of viewers -- potential buyers -- rather than to the undifferentiated mass. It tried to attract what one might call a vertical audience rather than the large horizontal audience for which the movies aimed. 
While Hollywood didn't tailor its product to blacks or Catholics or children, television always has. In its early days there was "The Goldbergs," about a Jewish family living in a Bronx tenement, "Beulah," starring Ethel Waters as a black maid, and "Life Is Worth Living," a prime-time religious program featuring Bishop Fulton Sheen. (Although there is more of a niche market in movies these days, no studio depends on movies of, say, black interest or religious appeal to hold up the bottom line.)
Television now reaches almost every household in America, but it has never lost its narrowcast mindset. It is still demographically driven, with programs aimed at slices of the audience. The result is that television has a kind of clubbiness, using references, gestures and attitudes that don't always cross our country's demographic lines, much less international borders. 
Indeed, the American shows that have traveled best around the globe are those that deal in the basics -- sex ("Baywatch") and melodrama ("Dallas") -- and even with these shows part of the appeal for foreign markets was that they reinforced the stereotype of American vulgarity. 
The decline of American shows around the world, then, should be seen as a fulfillment of television's destiny, a destiny that had only been postponed until local markets gained the know-how, the money and the corporate structure to make their own programs for slices of their own audience. It also reflects a technological advance -- the new panoply of cable and satellite channels that are breaking TV audiences down into niche groups -- that perfectly mirrors what has been happening in America for the last three decades. 
Our movies continue to be universal, exporting the primal aesthetic of excitement and individualism. Our TV shows continue to be domestic. And the rest of world is likely to continue to be divided between the American movies they love and the American television shows they don't really understand and, more and more, don't really care to watch.

GRAPHIC: Drawing (Stephen Savage)

HEADLINE: Alcoa Posts Unexpectedly Large Quarter Loss, and Its Shares Fall 

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Alcoa, the world's largest aluminum producer, reported a wider-than-expected fourth-quarter loss yesterday, hurt by weak demand for aluminum and charges for an overhaul that will include the elimination of 8,000 jobs and the sale of struggling divisions. 
 Alcoa is moving to cut costs as aluminum prices are under pressure from oversupply and poor demand from companies that use it in aircraft and gas-turbine components. 
 Shares of Alcoa fell $2.53 yesterday, to $21.85, after the company surprised Wall Street by reporting a fourth-quarter net loss of $223 million, or 27 cents a share. In the period a year earlier, when it also took a charge for restructuring, the company had a net loss of $142 million, or 17 cents a share. Even without special items, the quarterly results were lower than the 20 cents to 32 cents a share expected by Thomson First Call. 
As part of its overhaul, Alcoa, based in Pittsburgh, will eliminate 8,000 jobs, or about 6 percent of the work force. Most of the job cuts will occur this year and come from Alcoa smelters in the United States and businesses serving the aerospace, gas-turbine and automotive industries. To account for the job cuts and the corporate overhaul, Alcoa took a fourth-quarter charge of $95 million. 
A weak United States economy, including the effects of the terrorist attacks, is hurting big aluminum customers like airlines and utilities. New plane orders are lower, and orders for generators like gas turbines are being canceled or delayed as power companies suffer from relatively low wholesale prices for electricity and from credit problems. 
Alcoa also took a fourth-quarter charge of $221 million for the planned sale of some businesses, including specialty chemicals and specialty packaging equipment, that generated about $1.3 billion in 2002. Proceeds from the sales will be used to repay debt. 
Excluding charges, the company had a profit of 16 cents a share, down from 17 cents a year earlier. Sales fell to $5.06 billion from $5.10 billion.

HEADLINE: Consumer Borrowing Report Shows Steep November Drop 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 

 BODY:
Consumer borrowing in November had the biggest decline in 11 years, the Federal Reserve reported today, an indication that Americans are becoming more wary of taking on debt.
 The Fed reported that borrowing through credit cards and other types of loans decreased at an annual rate of 1.5 percent, or $2.2 billion, the first drop since January 1998 and the biggest since October 1991, when the total decreased at a rate of $2.4 billion. 
This follows an increase of $1.5 billion in October. 
 "Households continue to use debt with great caution because of worries about sluggish job markets and an already high debt burden," said Steven Wood, principal economist at Insight Economics in Walnut Creek, Calif. "Although consumers can be tempted to borrow when interest rates are very low, they are growing their nonmortgage debt more slowly."
Economists had expected consumer credit to rise at a $3.8 billion annual rate in November.
The figures are often volatile and previous declines have been revised away in subsequent months.
Last February, the Fed initially reported December consumer borrowing had fallen by $5.1 billion. That figure was revised the next month to show a $3.7 billion gain.
Borrowing by consumers totaled $1.7 trillion in November, the Fed said. The Fed's report on consumer credit does not include loans that are secured by real estate, like mortgages and home equity lines of credit.
Credit card and other revolving debt fell at a $1.6 billion annual pace in the month, after a $2.4 billion increase in October.
Nonrevolving loans, which include those for cars, fell at a $600 million rate in November after dropping at a $900 million pace the previous month.

HEADLINE: Panel Clears Harsher Terms In CorporateCrime Cases 

BYLINE:  By ERIC LICHTBLAU 

 BODY:
The United States Sentencing Commission approved an emergency plan yesterday that would lengthen prison sentences for corporate criminals, rebuffing Justice Department officials who contended that the new guidelines did not go far enough.
 The guidelines, which grew out of the rash of frauds and corporate scandals last year at Enron and other major corporations, increase the penalties faced by corporate offenders in many federal cases by 25 percent or more, officials said. 
 A person convicted of securities fraud who had faced up to six and a half years in prison can now be sentenced to as much as eight years under the new guidelines, officials said. If the offender was an officer or director of a publicly traded company, the sentence could grow to 10 years. 
The commission approved the new guidelines by a vote of 5 to 0. The emergency plan, which creates a new sentencing formula that federal judges are expected to follow in imposing sentences, goes into effect later this month and will last at least through November. The commission expects to come back with a refined and permanent plan in April, which Congress then has the power to review. 
Congress ordered new sentencing guidelines last year when it passed a corporate cleanup measure, known as the Sarbanes-Oxley Act, which was intended to help restore consumer confidence after the exposure of widespread accounting scandals in publicly traded companies. 
"The message of today's amendment is very simple: If you do the crime, you'll do the time," said Ruben Castillo, a member of the commission. "Crimes in the suites will be treated the same, if not more seriously, than crimes in the streets."
But the vote brought sharp criticism from both federal prosecutors, who said the plan was too soft on some types of crime, and defense lawyers, who deemed it an overreaction to public pressure.
"These guidelines are extremely harsh," said James Felman, a defense lawyer in Tampa, Fla., who serves on an advisory panel to the sentencing commission. "This is like a nuclear bomb dropped on anyone who has anything to do with any of these offenses. Some people will be facing life in prison."
But officials at the Justice Department, which prosecutes federal white-collar crimes, objected to the plan for just the opposite reason, saying that the new guidelines largely ignore corporate offenders in smaller-scale offenses that involve smaller amounts of money or fewer investors.
Eric H. Jaso, a Justice Department official who is a nonvoting member of the commission, said that the commission had the authority from Congress to "raise penalties across the board." 
"Many smaller-scale frauds cause devastating harm across the country," he said. He added that the department was "tremendously disappointed and frustrated" with the plan and that it "sends the wrong message" to corporate criminals and to the public.
The Justice Department is considering whether to propose toughened legislation in Congress to effectively correct the deficiencies in the sentencing commission's plan, he said.
But commission members defended their plan, saying that it is not clear that the penalties for low-level fraud that the Justice Department was seeking were even authorized by Congress. 
They said that Congress called for stiffer penalties for "serious" offenses, and that the penalties sought by the Justice Department did not fall into that category. "The law says 'serious' fraud cases," said a commission member, William K. Sessions. "We have to do what Congress says." 
The chairwoman of the commission, Diana E. Murphy, said, "There isn't clarity for some in what the term 'serious' means in Sarbanes-Oxley."
In opposing the demands from the Justice Department, the commissioners also said that enacting stiffer penalties for all fraud cases could strain law enforcement resources and add to prison overcrowding. 
Mr. Castillo called for studies on the impact on prisons of the Justice Department's plan. "We must be careful about how we use investigative and prison resources," he said.
He also said that one problem with the department's recommendations was that it could put offenders in prison and prevent them from earning the money to pay back victims. "If they go to jail and they are employed, you take away their ability to make restitution," he said. "Victims, more than anything else, want their money back."
One commissioner, Michael E. O'Neill, said he wished Congress had not requested that the amendment be passed on an emergency basis because it did not give the members enough time to study the issues. "We're not exactly sure what the proper course is," he said.

HEADLINE: POLITICS AND THE ECONOMY: REPUBLICANS; 
Frist Points to Racial Inequities in Health Care

BYLINE:  By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 

 BODY:
Bill Frist, the new Senate majority leader, vowed today to reduce racial disparities in health care as a means of repairing his party's standing with minorities.
 Joining other senior Senate Republicans in presenting the first outline of their priorities for the Congressional session, Dr. Frist did not mention the remarks, widely viewed as racially insensitive, that led to the downfall of Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, his predecessor as Republican leader. But he maintained that it was time to address forthrightly issues of racial reconciliation that, he said, many in and out of his party have tried to avoid in the past. 
 To that end, he said, the Republican-controlled Senate will try to increase spending on historically black colleges and will add money to the election overhaul effort that began last year to improve access to voter rolls and polling places.
But Dr. Frist, a physician, also called for intensifying the fight against the spread of H.I.V. in Africa and improving the health care of blacks and other minorities at home.
"For reasons we don't fully understand, but we've got to face and we've got to elevate, we know that African-Americans today do not live as long," he said, flanked at a news conference by six other members of the Senate Republican leadership. "They don't have the same access, and the doctor-patient relationship in some way is colored by the medical training. And that's something I began to address a long time ago and will continue to address."
But the leaders, taking a break in the midst of an all-day Republican strategy session at the Library of Congress, did not list those issues as among their top five legislative priorities. That agenda, as described by Senator Rick Santorum of Pennsylvania, begins with passage of President Bush's tax-cut proposal, followed by improvements in domestic and national security, adoption of prescription drug coverage for the elderly, financing of the Bush education program enacted last year and approval of an energy bill that features new oil exploration in the Alaskan wilderness.
The list offered no details of new legislative initiatives, many of which will apparently have to wait for the president's State of the Union address on Jan. 28.
Although the government is already facing large deficits, the Republican leaders said they did not fear that the president's tax-cut proposal, amounting to $670 billion over 10 years, and new spending would add to fiscal strains. They said that once the economy began to grow, the red ink would disappear.
"I think the president's been very, very clear that in a time when you're in a recession and a time when you're at war, you have to focus on, No. 1, winning the war, and No. 2, trying to get this economy up and going," Mr. Santorum said. "And I think if you look at the history, that if the economy is strong, deficits go away. We saw that in the 1990's. Spending was historically very, very high, yet the deficits went away and we went into surplus."
Dr. Frist, a Tennessean in his second term, seemed reluctant to get into many specifics. He tried to have other senators provide answers but was repeatedly called to the microphone by reporters, who had not been able to question him since Senate Republicans elected him their leader two weeks ago.
He became more focused in discussing his plans to restructure Medicare and address problems in the private health care system as well. He said he wanted to find a way to bring health care to the uninsured, though he did not explain how he hoped to do so.
"Health care disparities, minority versus nonminority populations, is something I feel strongly about," he said. "So you'll see that elevated. So when we say Medicare, prescription drugs, which is what everybody thinks about, let's not forget that there are many health care challenges, which I would call crises, out there today."
While in the Senate, Dr. Frist has generally advocated a stronger role for private insurance companies in helping provide prescription drugs through Medicare, a position at odds with the Democratic plan to have the government pay for the drugs. He spoke today of his frustration at writing thousands of prescriptions over the years knowing that many would not be filled because they were not covered by Medicare.
"Medicare today, because it has been outdated -- it hasn't changed very much since 1965 -- needs to be strengthened, and it needs to be improved," he said. "And I'm committed to do that, and as a part of that, I very much, based on what I just said, think that a prescription drug benefit needs to be a part of Medicare as part of that strengthening process."
Health care and education spending are the top priorities of Senate Democrats, as outlined this week by their leader, Tom Daschle. But the parties differ sharply on both issues.
Democrats will in many cases be able to prevent the enactment of Republican priorities, and Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the Senate Republican whip, acknowledged today that his party, holding 51 of the Senate's 100 seats, would often have to depend on a few Democratic votes.
"We're realistic," Mr. McConnell said. "I mean, clearly, here the American political system is about as tight as it has been in our history, with the possible exception of the 1880's. We know what the numbers are, and we know that the only way we're going to be able to advance our own agenda and the president's agenda is with cooperation across the aisle."
Several Democrats signaled today that they would begin trying to rescind various pro-business provisions that were inserted by Republicans late last year in the bill that created a Department of Homeland Security.
A group of parents who say a vaccine preservative may have caused their children's autism held a protest rally on Capitol Hill today, urging that one such provision, giving vaccine manufacturers immunity from lawsuits related to the issue, now be removed from the Homeland Security law, as Republicans have promised.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Wall St. Journal Is Considering Putting Out Issue On Saturdays

BYLINE:  By FELICITY BARRINGER 

 BODY:
Executives of The Wall Street Journal and its parent, Dow Jones & Company, are exploring the addition of a Saturday paper to its weekday schedule, as they seek to become more competitive journalistically and to broaden an advertising base heavily dependent on business-related advertising. 
 Several Journal and Dow Jones executives who have been briefed on the undertaking said that there was no set timetable for the project and that the new issue might prove unworkable. 
 But they added that the moment might be right to put into effect an idea that has percolated for years around the corridors of the newspaper's office in the World Financial Center in Lower Manhattan.
The advertising recession, which has hit The Journal harder than other newspapers because of its disproportionate dependence on the hardest-hit advertising categories like financial services and technology, has underscored the need for the newspaper to attract more advertising aimed at consumers. In terms of news coverage, The Journal's Monday-through-Friday publication schedule puts it at a competitive disadvantage with the business sections of seven-day-a-week newspapers. 
The newspaper's new publisher, Karen Elliott House, and the new chief operating officer, Richard F. Zannino, are both known for aggressively pursuing avenues that could expand the company's business and journalistic reach.
But starting a Saturday paper could be a complex and costly undertaking. It is unclear how much of an appetite a predominantly business-oriented readership would have for a weekend paper, or what editorial changes should be made to expand the audience. 
(The Financial Times, the leading business newspaper in Europe, publishes a Saturday issue that blends market news with extensive lifestyle and cultural coverage.)
Dow Jones and The Journal also face significant logistical hurdles. While Dow Jones owns printing plants around the country that could be put to work producing a Saturday Journal, getting those copies to readers would be more difficult. A substantial part of the newspaper's daily circulation of 1.8 million is delivered to offices, concentrated in the business districts of major cities; a Saturday paper would have to go to the homes of a more far-flung and suburban audience. 
The news of a possible Saturday paper was reported yesterday by Dow Jones Newswires, which is also owned by Dow Jones & Company.
Leland Westerfield, a publishing analyst with UBS Warburg, said yesterday that the move would be a logical next step for Dow Jones to expand the reach of its flagship paper. The Journal currently has five-day editions in North America, Asia and Europe and provides a preprinted Sunday business insert, The Wall Street Journal Sunday, to 74 newspapers, with a combined circulation of 10.8 million. 
Over the last five years, The Journal has expanded significantly. Weekend Journal has been published on Fridays since 1998, and last spring The Journal was redesigned, adding pastels to the newspaper's front page and a new section, Personal Journal, on Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Thursdays.
"It's about scale, as are most matters in media," Mr. Westerfield wrote in an e-mail message. "Media channels have proliferated, but you can argue that the ranks of differentiated journalism brands have been thinned in recent years. So publishers with quality journalism and established brand names, like the W.S.J., can do more to slake the thirst of loyal readers."
He added, "Why allow another financial journal or video programmer a seat at the table with your audience?"
To lead the editorial exploration of a Saturday paper, Dow Jones tapped Lawrence Ingrassia, the editor of The Journal's Money & Investing section, over the Christmas holidays, the executives briefed on the undertaking said. Asked about his assignment yesterday, Mr. Ingrassia said, "No comment."
Brigitte Trafford, the company's spokeswoman, also declined to comment. 
At a December meeting with analysts, the chief executive of Dow Jones, Peter R. Kann, avoided a direct response to a question about a Saturday publication. 
Dave Kansas, a senior editor at The Wall Street Journal Online, will temporarily take over Mr. Ingrassia's responsibilities on the Money & Investing section.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Karen Elliott House, publisher of The Journal, seeks to expand the paper's journalistic reach. (Norman Y. Lono)(pg. C6)
