HEADLINE: GOLF; 
Opportunity Awaits With Woods Hurt for Opener

BYLINE:  By CLIFTON BROWN 

DATELINE: KAPALUA, Hawaii, Jan. 8 

 BODY:
Even before the first tee shot, it is clear that 2003 will not be a typical year for the PGA Tour.
 The season-opening Mercedes Championships will begin Thursday at the Plantation Course without Tiger Woods and Phil Mickelson, the top two players in the world ranking. Woods is recovering from knee surgery in December, and he is not expected back until mid-February. Mickelson is skipping the Mercedes for the second consecutive year, electing to stay home after a heavy schedule in November and December. 
 The most talked-about issue in golf these days is not the competition, but the controversy surrounding the Masters, to be held April 10-13 at Augusta National Golf Club. The Augusta National chairman, William Johnson, who is known as Hootie, has stated that the club will not add a woman to its membership before the tournament. Martha Burk, the chairwoman of the National Council of Women's Organizations, who has led the campaign for admittance of a woman, has promised not to ease the pressure.
As Augusta braces for protests and demonstrations during tournament week, players cannot escape the topic, which will be debated, discussed and dissected from now until mid-April.
As a native of Augusta, Ga., Charles Howell III, one of the Tour's rising stars, could sense a different atmosphere in his hometown when he visited during Christmas. 
"A lot of business and people around Augusta are becoming hurt by it," Howell said, referring to the membership controversy. "I know one of the housing bureaus has had 40-some houses canceled already. My youngest brother's girlfriend works for the largest caterer in Augusta, and they've had a whole lot of orders canceled and a lot of parties canceled. The impact goes far beyond golf. It's hurting the city, the economy. A lot of people depend on the income from the Masters.
"What's right or wrong? I have an opinion, but everyone does. I keep my opinion to myself. Augusta National is a private club, but then again, it's 2003 and you'd like to see a woman member out there."
Opinions vary depending on whom you ask.
"With all that's going on in the world, we're worried about membership at a golf club?" said Rocco Mediate, a five-time winner on Tour. "It's their club and their right to invite who they want."
Nick Price, a three-time major champion, sees the issue differently. "They're 10 years behind the times," he said. "They should have had a lady member in there 10 years ago." 
While the Augusta issue will linger, the players who were fortunate to make this week's field have soaked up the sunshine, the surf and the 80-degree temperature as they start a new campaign with new goals and fresh attitudes.
The winner of the Mercedes will take home $1 million, plus a new Mercedes-Benz SL500. Not a bad way to start the year. And with Woods sidelined, players sense an opportunity to get a quick start, hoping to end Woods's four-year reign as the Tour's top money-winner and player of the year.
This week's favorites include the reigning British Open champion, Ernie Els; the defending Mercedes champion, Sergio Garcia; the winner of last year's P.G.A. Championship, Rich Beem; Vijay Singh; Justin Leonard; Retief Goosen; Jeff Sluman; and Price.
Mediate sees both opportunity and disappointment in not having Woods on Tour early.
"The money race is more wide open, but we need to have Tiger healthy," Mediate said. "He makes our Tour better. He brings more people, he brings more coverage. I'm one of those guys who would rather have Tiger in the field. A, it raises the level of play. And B, if you happen to win, it's a much better feeling when he's around."
Only last year's Tour winners qualify for the Mercedes, and this year's field features 18 first-time winners. Call yourself a serious golf fan if you recognize Jonathan Byrd, John Rollins, Gene Sauers, Craig Perks and Ian Leggett without a program. Those players all won tournaments last year, while world-class players like David Toms, Davis Love III, David Duval, Mike Weir, Scott Verplank and Hal Sutton did not.
Has there been a changing of the guard, or was last year a fluke? It will be interesting to see how many first-time winners can capture another tournament and how many veterans will bounce back.
"I think you'll see a lot of young players play well, but I don't think you'll see 18 first-time winners," Howell said. "That was a bit of a shock."
Dan Forsman, who had not won since 1992, proved something to himself by winning last year's SEI Pennsylvania Classic at age 44. For Forsman, an invitation to the Mercedes is never taken for granted.
"I'm just glad they remembered my address," he said.
Then Forsman looked out toward a gorgeous view of the Pacific Ocean and considered the benefits of beginning a Tour season at the Mercedes. Somebody will end the weekend $1 million richer and the last-place finisher will earn at least $53,000. "You know, it's really hard to have a bad week out here," Forsman said. "I guess you could. But you'd have to try hard."

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: ASIAN ARENA; 
Defectors Want to Pry Open North Korea

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 8 

 BODY:
The Bush administration is now willing to talk to North Korea about its nuclear bomb program. Next week, South Korea will send the North 11,800 tons of rice.
 But in interviews, three recent defectors from North Korea drew on their experiences to give their own proposals for how to deal with the unpredictable government of their impoverished homeland. 
 The proposals included closing China's five border bridges and imposing an economic quarantine; undermining the leadership cult by smuggling in radios tuned to South Korean stations; and, in the words of one woman, by "bombing the North with ladies' handbags." 
"My eyes were opened when, through a trader friend, I got hold of some South Korean clothing," recounted the woman, Lee Ji Young, 31. "I was surprised that they were very good clothes. I had to scissor off the labels, of course."
"Before, I had believed what they told us about the food donations from South Korea and the United States: 'Because we are so strong militarily and strong ideologically, they send us all this tribute,' " Ms. Lee said, smiling at the memory. 
Six months after escaping from North Korea, she sat in the office of a human rights group here, happily wearing a gray wool jacket, with a stylized American flag patch on the left arm and, on the back in large black script: New York Yankees.
The Kim family's Communist dynasty -- founded by Kim Il Sung and continued by his son, Kim Jong Il -- has ruled North Korea for the last half century by maintaining what may be the world's tightest monopoly on information about the outside world. That grip will loosen, defectors say, when North Koreans learn such basic facts as their rank as Northeast Asia's poorest nation. Per capita income in South Korea is 13 times the level in North Korea.
Military pressure, the defectors warned, will have little effect on one of the most militarized societies in the world. In the mid-1990's, during a famine, Ms. Lee recalled, "they had this slogan: 'Without the candy bowls, you can still live; but without the bullets, you cannot survive.' "
But behind the fire-breathing rhetoric, "the North Korean Army is in shambles," she added. 
"The North Korean military elites are skimming from their budgets, cutting down the average ration for soldiers," said Ms. Lee, whose husband served in the military. "The soldiers have become very undisciplined. They steal piglets." 
Economic sanctions, if applied by China, North Korea's largest trading partner, might force Kim Jong Il to mothball his nuclear bomb projects, said the defectors, who all escaped through China. But according to a report released last week by South Korea's National Statistical Office, only 14 percent of North Korea's limping economy depended on foreign trade in 2000, compared with 69 percent in South Korea. 
"When China and Russia stop giving aid, North Korea is bound to halt its nuclear weapons program," said Ma Young Ae, 39, a former counterintelligence agent who now runs a restaurant here with her new South Korean husband.
"Most of the food in Pyongyang is from China," she said, referring to North Korea's capital. "The best way to stop the nuclear program is to stop the aid."
But Ms. Ma, who said she did undercover work in China before she defected in 1999, said that merely persuading China to close the five river bridges would not seal off North Korea. "A lot of private boats cross the river," she said. "Unless they put up an electrified barbed wire fence, they will keep doing it."
An economic quarantine was also recommended by Park Soon Duck, a former Korean Workers' Party secretary at an iron mine.
"North Korea has to be sanctioned economically -- that is the right way to bring down the regime," argued the energetic Ms. Park, who works as a janitor and writes for a defectors' journal in her spare time. "They can't survive on their own. The fundamentals of self-reliance are in shambles."
The end of the Communist government would be the only guarantee that the nuclear weapons production would stop, she said.
Ms. Park said she had no patience with young South Koreans who muse that a North Korean nuclear bomb is really a "Korean bomb."
"That's a 3-year-old kid talking, someone who doesn't know about politics," retorted Ms. Park, whose two sons -- a seminarian and a street vendor -- are in Seoul.
All three women agreed that the slower, but more effective way to undermine North Korea's system would be to break the information monopoly that the government holds over the nation's 22 million people.
"Churches in South Korea say it has to be the Bible, others say the culture has to go in," Ms. Ma said . "In my case, as a Christian, I believe the Bible will enlighten the people very quickly."
But she conceded, "If you are caught with a Bible, you can be executed or sent to political prison camp."
In South Korea, when winds are blowing north, Christian groups sometimes tie Korean-language Bibles to balloons and send them over the border. The South Korean government has largely ended such activities, believing that it undermines its policy of peaceful coexistence with North Korea.
Ms. Ma urged the Bush administration to flood North Korea with radios equipped with long-lasting batteries that would allow North Koreans to listen to South Korean stations and to Radio Free Asia, which is supported by the United States. 
"Radios, tape cassettes, magazines -- that's what I mean by cultural penetration," she said. 
In North Korea, "all the tape recorders and radio have to be registered," said Ms. Lee, who was a housewife until she left 18 months ago. "At registration, they cut off and solder the tuning dial to make sure you don't have a 'free' radio. If you have a cassette player, sometimes the police come to your apartment to check your cassette library."
To fight ideological contamination, North Korea's government for years taught citizens that goods from South Korea were laced with cyanide.
"North Koreans are brainwashed to believe that everything from the South has poison on it," Ms. Lee continued, admitting that this legend might prevent people from picking up radios or handbags left scattered over the countryside. But that taboo is wearing down with the influx of foreign aid and goods from China.
As North Korea became an international charity case in the late 1990's, she said, foreign goods became increasingly common: medicines at her local hospital, children's clothes handed out at kindergartens, winter boots and blankets distributed at an old people's home.
"We were able to see at the public distribution center bags of rice with the U.S.A. logo on it, that said in Korean, 'Gift from the United States,' " she continued.
But Ms. Lee, who is now studying at a cooking school in Seoul, said: "They warned us: 'Just because you are getting their food, don't have any fantasies about the U.S.A. This aid will not last. They may turn into a wolf at anytime and bite us.' "
"I believed all that until I got to South Korea," she said.

Ms. Ma, a former counterintelligence agent, now runs a restaurant in Seoul. (Photographs by Jae Hyun Seok for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: POLITICS AND THE ECONOMY: THE 2004 CAMPAIGN; 
Senator Miller, Democratic Maverick, Will Retire

BYLINE:  By DAVID FIRESTONE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 

 BODY:
Senator Zell Miller, the wild-card Georgia Democrat who has contributed to some of the Bush administration's biggest legislative victories, announced today that he would not seek re-election in 2004.
 Mr. Miller, who is 70, did not give a reason for his decision, but he has not been raising money in Georgia and has frequently muttered that he is weary of Washington's partisanship and slow-moving legislative machinery. 
 Given the recent Republican victories in the state, his decision increases the possibility that the seat will go to the Republicans.
"I wanted to make my plans known early so that those who want to run can begin their preparation," he said in a statement. "I realize some will call me a lame duck. But those who know me know I will be the same duck, continuing to serve no single party but all the people of Georgia."
Mr. Miller was an early supporter of President Bush's 2001 tax cut and is considered a likely ally of the administration's economic plans this year. For months last year, he was the only Senate Democrat to support Mr. Bush's plan to reduce Civil Service and union protections for workers in the new Department of Homeland Security, often bitterly denouncing his party for supporting the interests of unions rather than security and efficiency.
His conservatism often led to speculation that he might consider changing parties, but he scoffed at the notion and last year campaigned hard for the re-election of Senator Max Cleland, a fellow Georgia Democrat. Mr. Cleland was defeated. 
Mr. Miller's two terms as governor left him popular in Georgia, in large part for creating the HOPE scholarship, which gives lottery proceeds to college students. He left retirement in 2000 when he was appointed by Gov. Roy E. Barnes to the seat left vacant by the death of Senator Paul Coverdell, a Republican, and hed won election to the remainder of Mr. Coverdell's term later that year.
In his statement, he said he would not endorse any candidate to succeed him. The field is likely to be large. Mr. Barnes, who was defeated in November, took himself out of the running today, but Democrats said Mr. Cleland might seek the nomination. Several Republican members of Congress are considering a run, trying to take advantage of what may be a new Republican surge in the state, and a spokesman for former Representative Bob Barr said Mr. Barr was strongly considering a race.
Senator George F. Allen of Virginia, chairman of the Republican Senatorial Campaign Committee, said the open seat would be an "excellent opportunity" for Republicans in 2004, noting that Mr. Bush carried the state overwhelmingly in 2000.
Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader, said that he was disappointed by Mr. Miller's decision, but that the party hoped to recruit a strong candidate in the next few weeks.

HEADLINE: POLITICS AND THE ECONOMY: THE ENVIRONMENT; 
McCain and Lieberman Offer Bill to Require Cuts in Gases

BYLINE:  By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 

 BODY:
At a packed committee hearing, Senators John McCain, Republican of Arizona, and Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut, joined forces today to challenge the Bush administration on global warming.
 The two former -- and possibly future -- political rivals to President Bush and each other offered their bill to reduce the emissions of heat-trapping gases, saying the administration was stuck in neutral on that crucial environmental matter. 
 "The United States is responsible for 25 percent of the worldwide greenhouse gas emissions," Mr. McCain, chairman of the Science, Commerce and Transportation Committee, said as he opened the hearing. "It is time for the United States government to do its part to address this global problem, and a discussion of mandatory reductions is the form of leadership that is required." 
That assertion was a direct challenge to Mr. Bush, whose approach relies on voluntary reductions, and it guaranteed that the McCain-Lieberman bill would face stiff opposition, particularly after next week, when Mr. Lieberman is to announce that he is seeking the Democratic nomination for president next year.
The bill, forged with advice from industry and environmental groups, would require that by 2010 industries cut emissions of carbon dioxide to 2000 levels and by 2016 to 1990 levels.
It would create a "cap and trade" system under which companies that failed to meet the goals could buy "credits" from companies that exceeded them, an approach used to reduce acid rain. The program would apply to electric utilities, industrial plants, transportation and large commercial enterprises, which were responsible for 85 percent of emissions in 2000 in the United States.
The administration declined to join the Kyoto treaty on climate change, even though last year Mr. Bush accepted findings by a panel of American experts that human activity had caused most of the global warming in recent decades.
Mr. Bush set a policy that until 2012 would rely on voluntary measures by industries to slow growth in emissions of carbon dioxide and other heat-trapping gases. He said more research was needed to clarify the potential environmental risks of warming before taking stronger measures, although White House officials said recently that they might speed their timetable in seeking compliance.
Today, the White House was unenthusiastic about the McCain-Lieberman approach.
A spokesman, Scott McClellan, said: "We're already making great progress on the president's common-sense plan to significantly reduce the growth in greenhouse-gas emissions and working with Congress to pass the most significant reduction in power-plant emissions ever."
Senator James M. Inhofe, the Oklahoma Republican who is chairman of the Environment and Public Works Committee, said the causes of global warming were still open to question. He indicated that he had a fundamental difference with the McCain-Lieberman approach by noting that the Congressional Budget Office had found that cap-and-trade programs amounted to "an energy tax on consumers."
Many people at the hearing rejected the idea that the White House was doing something serious about global warming and criticized the administration for saying it needed to do more research.
Mr. Lieberman, the first witness, said the administration's approach would "allow greenhouse-gas emissions to keep increasing indefinitely, presenting this country and the world with a bigger and bigger environmental crisis to tackle down the road," hurting the economy and America's stature in the world.
Of his bill, he said, "we do less than is explicitly called for under the Kyoto agreement, but we sure do a lot more than nothing."
Speaking for the administration at the hearing was James R. Mahoney, assistant commerce secretary and deputy administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. 
Dr. Mahoney said, "We do have evidence of global change," but he added, "There are substantial uncertainties about causes, and because of that uncertainty about causes, there's also substantial uncertainty about mitigation methods that might be effective."
He said the administration was spending $1.7 billion on research. Dr. Mahoney also announced that the White House would be the host of an international Earth Observation Summit this summer to discuss climate change.
And he warned that the McCain-Lieberman approach of mandatory reductions in gases would lead to "years of litigation."
Mr. McCain said a voluntary approach did not "meet the urgency" of the threat from global warming.
Senator Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, was more dismissive.
"I don't think these workshops are going to cut it," Mr. Wyden told Dr. Mahoney, asking him what event, "short of flooding the National Mall," would persuade the administration that global warming was a serious problem.
Dr. Mahoney said that was above his pay grade, but offered that the administration had to worry about the "economic dislocation" caused by any mandatory program.
The hearing was the first by this committee in the new Congress, a sign that Mr. McCain wanted to make a statement. That statement, his opponents said, was that he and Mr. Lieberman were posturing.
"This was a political statement," said Frank Maisano, representing the Business Coalition on Global Warming, who predicted widespread opposition to the bill. "It's so broad, and it covers so many people and it would be so complex and complicated. It's too burdensome for anyone to fathom."
Representatives of environmental groups were thrilled with the McCain-Lieberman approach. 
"It's a very big event that McCain and Lieberman would open up with this," David Doniger of the Natural Resources Defense Council said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senators Joseph I. Lieberman, left, and John McCain yesterday offering a plan to reduce heat-trapping gases. (Doug Mills/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: POLITICS AND THE ECONOMY: THE NATIONAL MOOD; 
Deep Divisions on Who Will Benefit From Bush Tax Plan

BYLINE:  By DEAN E. MURPHY 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 8 

 BODY:
On a mother-daughter day out, Barbara Bowers and Laura Folsom strolled Maiden Lane today, a gated pedestrian district of boutiques and beauty salons that cater to the well-to-do.
 Ms. Bowers carried a shopping bag from Neiman Marcus. Her daughter, Ms. Folsom, was dressed elegantly in a black sweater and scarf over slacks. Politically, they have much in common: They are Republicans and stand to benefit from the tax cuts and economic plan proposed on Tuesday by President Bush. 
 But like many other Americans, Ms. Bowers and Ms. Folsom are deeply divided on the president's prescriptions for the stalled economy. The women agreed that something major needed to happen. They praised Mr. Bush for turning the nation's attention to something other than attacking Saddam Hussein. 
But the consensus ended there.
"I think it's a farce," Ms. Bowers, 65, of Palo Alto, Calif., said of the president's plan. "I don't think it will help the average working person one bit."
Ms. Folsom bit her lip as her mother spoke, then countered in rapid fire. "The people who have money and invest it are creating jobs," said Ms. Folsom, 39, of Alamo, Calif., whose husband, a pilot for United Airlines, recently took a 40 percent cut in pay and benefits. "It is all connected. By helping the people who can invest, you are also helping the overall population."
The debate continued as the women walked toward Union Square, with Ms. Bowers saying she would never vote for Mr. Bush because of the perceived tilt toward the rich and Ms. Folsom promising to back the president all the way.
In varying forms, the scene here was played out across the country today, as families dissected the economic proposals over kitchen tables, co-workers argued the merits during breaks at the office and financial analysts tried to figure out the bottom line for their clients, many of whom expressed confusion about where they stood.
"The focus on the economy is great, but as far as I can tell, the separation between the rich and poor continues to increase," said Amir Nashat, 29, a venture capitalist from Cambridge, Mass., who described himself as a political independent. "Democrat or Republican, when they focus on the economy, they do things that are meant to please their voters, not make long-term changes for the better."
In Louisiana, a mother of three young children said she was heartened by the bigger child tax credit proposed by the president but wondered why the plan seemed to give even more to the wealthy. In Seattle, the owner of a sausage restaurant welcomed the proposed end to taxation on corporate dividends and said everyone, including his elderly parents living on investment income, stood to benefit. In Atlanta, a museum consultant questioned the wisdom of tax cuts of any sort, suggesting the government could better use the money elsewhere.
A telecommunications company manager in Denver, echoing sentiments from many others, wondered if any of it would become law anyway because Iraq remained at the top of the president's priorities.
"We'll see if it happens," said the manager, Chris Lombardi, 42. "President Bush is trying to ensure he has unified support if we engage in war with Iraq. It's a timing thing."
Indeed, questions about a possible war served as a heavy backdrop to the president's announcement, raising doubts among some supporters and detractors about any economic plan put forth in a political environment that could turn the economy topsy-turvy in weeks or months.
"I promise you that whether or not we go to war with Iraq will have a much bigger effect on the economy than any of this," said Bryan Roberts, 35, a venture capitalist with Venrock Associates of New York, who was attending a health-care conference here with Mr. Nashat.
As the president's tax cuts and economic proposals were pulled apart across the nation today, the main point of contention followed the same political debate framed on Capitol Hill: rich vs. poor.
Many of the better-off people likely to benefit from the changes argued that it was unfair to cast the proposals in simple terms of winners and losers. John Siddall, 58, the chief executive at an advertising agency in Richmond, Va., said he fell within the top federal tax bracket and stood to save about 2 percent in taxes. But he said the emphasis on his wallet missed the point.
"As a small-business owner," Mr. Siddall said, "it's more important for me for the economy to do well. This business supports the lives of 50 other families. For us to do well, the economy has to do well."
Alan King, a sales manager for a plastics manufacturer in Atlanta with a household income of nearly $200,000, said the Bush strategy was a straightforward matter of "pump priming" the economy.
"Rich people create jobs; poor people take jobs," Mr. King, 43, said. "Rich people make money. Poor people spend money. It will stimulate the economy, unless rich people just stick the money in their pocket."
The sausage restaurant owner in Seattle, Don Schultze, 49, said his business sustained the families of 15 employees. Dominated by a wooden bar, short stools and the aroma of grilling onions and sausages, Mr. Schultze's restaurant, Shultzy's Sausage, has turned a profit in just two of its 14 years. But Mr. Schultze, who described the president's plan as "brilliant in its simplicity," said he saw things getting better, particularly because of changes in the tax policy on dividends.
"Our economy is based on growth," he said. "To start growth, the plan is going to benefit everybody and benefit everybody immediately." 
Another person in Seattle's University District, John Watkins, was far more pessimistic. Mr. Watkins, 52, was waiting for his morning caffe latte at Sureshot coffee shop, as loud music filled the dark space and a jackhammer tore up the payment outside. Mr. Watkins owns the used-book store adjacent to the coffee shop. He has two employees and has been in business for 11 years. 
Mr. Watkins does not play the stock market and so cares little about the taxation of dividends. He wondered why Mr. Bush had not focused more on assisting small businesses directly by trimming payroll taxes, which would help keep down his labor costs and perhaps allow him to hire more people.
"I don't see a big help for me," Mr. Watkins said.
In East Setauket, N.Y., Elaine Dawson, 46, said the plan needed to be reworked to provide more benefits for "working people." Ms. Dawson, the mother of four whose husband owns a surveying business, estimated her family would save about $1,000 under the plan. But she said that would not be nearly enough to kick-start the economy.
"I think his intention is to give large tax breaks to corporate investors while throwing a small bone to the average Joe in hopes that we're all going to believe that it will benefit us all in the long run," Ms. Dawson, a Republican, said.
In Addis, La., the mother of three, Jennifer Lejeune, 34, pored over the books of the small dance studio she runs. Her husband is a teacher. In a quick look at the Bush plan, Ms. Lejeune discovered that her family would save $1,200 in the child tax credits, about the same amount of money they recently spent on medical bills for their 4-year-old son, Josh, who has a detached retina.
Though grateful, Ms. Lejeune wondered if Mr. Bush or any of the other people who determine economic policy understood families for whom every penny counts.
"I feel like lawmakers are trying to find a solution to this problem," Ms. Lejeune said, "but they're not even in the same tax bracket as me. We're in two different worlds, and mine is based in reality."

HEADLINE: POLITICS AND THE ECONOMY: THE PRESIDENT'S PLAN; 
Near-Term Benefits of Fiscal Plan Are Debated

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 

 BODY:
A White House estimate shows that administration officials are expecting President Bush's tax plan to generate only 190,000 jobs in 2003, a small number when compared to the 1.5 million jobs that have disappeared over the past two years.
 The document, prepared by the White House Council of Economic Advisers, makes it clear that the main purpose of the president's 10-year, $670 billion tax-cut proposal is not to fix the economy's current weakness but rather to advance a longer-term agenda of reducing taxes and increasing future growth. 
 When President Bush announced his program on Tuesday, administration officials predicted it would create 2.1 million jobs and said the tax cuts had been "front-loaded" to have as much effect in the first year as possible. 
But the White House's estimate says the real economic stimulus would not begin until 2004, by which time many economists predict that growth will already have increased. 
The document, released today, gave ammunition to Democratic critics of the president's plan who argue that the tax plan is too expensive and would do little to relieve the pain of the current slowdown.
Senator Jon Corzine, Democrat of New Jersey, said the estimates validate Democratic criticisms that Mr. Bush is not primarily interested in economic stimulus.
"This isn't a jobs program, it isn't stimulus," he said today. "It is what it is, a restructuring of the tax system with a high proportion of the advantage going to people who are already doing well."
Senator Tom Daschle, the Senate minority leader, was pressing the same point, even without seeing the White House calculations.
"The president really ought to be embarrassed in putting a plan like this forward in the name of economic stimulus," Mr. Daschle, a South Dakota Democrat, told reporters today. "Regardless of what you think about fairness, regardless of what you think about size, 85 percent of this plan doesn't even take effect this year."
But the estimate is consistent with what Mr. Bush and his economic advisers have quietly been saying: that they have little interest in quick fixes and are primarily interested in long-term economic growth.
The estimate also includes an extremely optimistic projection of the plan's total cost. Using a supply-side analysis, which assumes that tax cuts will partly pay for themselves by promoting faster growth, White House officials predicted the actual revenue loss to the federal Treasury would be less than half the size of the tax cut between now and 2007.
In public, the White House has said the economic plan would cost the Treasury about $674 billion over 10 years. But under a supply-side scenario, the cost through 2007 would drop from $359 billion to $166 billion. The discussion of costs is significant because some lawmakers are concerned about how much the tax cuts will add to the federal deficit. 
No matter what the costs, the White House estimates confirm the opinion of most outside economists that Mr. Bush's tax plan would do little to help the economy this year.
The unemployment rate reached 6 percent in November, and about 95,000 people a week are exhausting their state-financed unemployment benefits.
The White House document predicts that the tax plan will increase economic growth by about four-tenths of one percent and foster an additional 190,000 jobs in 2003. The Council of Economic Advisers estimated that the tax plan's impact in 2004 would be much higher, fostering 900,000 additional jobs on top of those that would have been created without any additional stimulus.
Though Mr. Bush did use the word "stimulus" when talking about his goals last week, he and his top advisers have played down their interest in short-term jolts.
R. Glenn Hubbard, chairman of the White House Council of Economic Advisers, has tried to expunge the very word "stimulus" from policy discussions because he says it sounds too much like Democratic-style pump-priming.
After the president's speech on Tuesday, administration officials said the tax cut plan would generate 2.1 million new jobs over three years. But they were reluctant to spell out their assumptions about growth.
"The president's plan to create jobs and spur growth in the economy is crafted to make a difference in both the short term and the long term," said Claire Buchan, a White House spokeswoman. 
Though acknowledging that many of the effects of the tax cut plan would not begin until 2004, Ms. Buchan said the plan would nevertheless pump $58 billion into the economy in 2003 through income tax rate reductions, rebates for child tax credits and additional unemployment benefits.

HEADLINE: U.S. Lobbies Oil Exporters to Produce More 

BYLINE:  By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 

 BODY:
The Bush administration, alarmed by a 38-day strike that has crippled Venezuela's petroleum industry and caused sharp increases in prices, has begun pressing countries that export oil to increase production, administration officials said today.
 Those efforts, which are being led by senior officials in the State and Energy Departments, also seem intended to prepare for the potential disruption in the international oil market that would come from an invasion of Iraq, industry analysts said. 
 The globe-spanning lobbying campaign could bear fruit this weekend, when the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries is expected to meet in Vienna to discuss increasing production as much as two million barrels a day, or 8.7 percent. 
"We've seen a number of statements from members of OPEC about possibly increasing production, and that would be a positive development," said Richard Boucher, the State Department spokesman. "Obviously, they're going to have to get together and decide, but we're also in touch with various countries involved." 
Venezuela has been the fourth-largest source of oil for the United States, behind Saudi Arabia, Mexico and Canada, providing 14 percent of the nation's crude oil imports.
By some estimates, Venezuelan production has fallen 75 percent or more since a general strike, organized by opponents of President Hugo Chavez, began last month. 
"We were consuming 1.5 million barrels of Venezuelan oil each day that we're not getting now, which means we have to get it from someplace else," a senior State Department official said. "We've had a historic strategic energy relationship with Venezuela that is obviously being affected in a dramatic way at this point."
The expectation of an increase in production from OPEC was followed by an Energy Department report showing an unexpected increase in United States stockpiles, which caused oil prices to drop today for the third consecutive session. In New York, crude oil for February delivery fell 52 cents, or 1.7 percent, to $30.56 a barrel. Prices have dropped about 8 percent from a two-year high on Friday, the biggest three-day drop since mid-April.
Oil stocks held by refiners and storage companies rose 400,000 barrels, to 278.7 million barrels, in the week ended Friday, according to the Energy Department report.
In a separate report, the American Petroleum Institute, which can evaluate data differently, said supplies fell two million barrels, to 276 million barrels. (The institute has changed the release of its weekly report from late Tuesday to coincide with the government report.) Analysts had forecast a decline of up to five million barrels.
Some analysts asserted that the administration had underestimated the effect of the civil unrest in Venezuela and should have begun pressing for an OPEC production increase weeks ago.
Given that it will take 30 to 45 days for Middle Eastern countries like Saudi Arabia to increase production and deliver additional crude oil to the United States, the Bush administration's lobbying campaign to increase production appears intended to prevent huge market disruptions if the United States attacks Iraq, analysts said.
The United States military will have positioned enough troops and equipment in the Persian Gulf to begin an invasion of Iraq by early to mid-February, Pentagon officials have said.
"This is really about Iraq," said Roger Diwan, a managing director for PFC Energy, a consulting firm. 
But administration officials denied that, saying their main goal has been to offset sharply reduced production in Venezuela, where no letup in the strike is in sight. They said that OPEC members, particularly Saudi Arabia, typically grow uncomfortable when oil prices rise above $28 a barrel, raising concerns of worldwide recession, which could drastically reduce oil consumption.
OPEC's president, Abdullah bin Hamad al-Attiyah of Qatar, told Bloomberg News today that he wanted the price of crude to fall to $25 a barrel.
Some analysts and lawmakers have also urged the Bush administration to release oil from the strategic petroleum reserve, a stockpile of nearly 600 million barrels that the United States holds in case of severe supply disruptions.
But a spokeswoman for the Energy Department said today that the Venezuelan crisis had not yet met that standard. 
"We've been monitoring the situation very closely," said Jeanne Lopatto, the spokeswoman. "At this point, we do not feel that release of oil from the reserve is necessary."

HEADLINE: U.S. Begins Talks for Trade Pact With Central Americans 

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH BECKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 

 BODY:
The Bush administration officially opened negotiations today to create a free trade agreement with five Central American countries within a year, a big leap in its ambitious plans for a Nafta-like zone throughout the Western Hemisphere.
 The announcement cemented the role of trade as the administration's primary policy focus with Latin America. It gives the United States trade representative, Robert B. Zoellick, chief responsibility for promoting improved American relations in the region at a time much of the administration is focused on Iraq and terrorism. 
 Indeed, Richard E. Feinberg, former special assistant for inter-American affairs to President Bill Clinton and an early advocate of the regional free trade concept, said, "I believe these free trade agreements will be seen as the 21st-century version of strategic alliances." 
Some critics in Latin America are annoyed at what they say is the administration's strategy of dealing first with small countries that have fewer trade disagreements with the United States rather than including bigger trading rivals like Brazil.
And the initiative intensifies competition between Washington and the European Union for access to the Latin American market, where Europe is the second-largest trading partner after the United States. European officials in Brussels have taken note of Mr. Zoellick's Latin American push since Congress granted trade promotion authority -- once called fast track -- to President Bush in August. And now the Europeans are working to complete negotiations for a similar free trade agreement with Mercosur, the world's third-largest trade group, comprising Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay as well as Bolivia and Chile as associate members.
"It is obvious we are in stiff competition right now," a European representative in Washington said. "Our agreement with Mexico came after Nafta, and we don't want to lose out again, especially not with Mercosur.
Flanked by representatives of several countries that just decades ago knew the United States mostly as a purveyor of weapons in their civil wars, Mr. Zoellick said American interests in the region were now centered on liberalized trade, economic development and democracy.
"This is more than a trade negotiation," he said. It is "a plan to strengthen democracy and promote development in a region that has known too little of both."
However, these five countries -- Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras and Nicaragua -- offer relatively few of the problems that will appear in the hemispherewide talks for a Free Trade Area of the Americas, or F.T.A.A., since their trade largely meshes with the United States.
Critics, particularly in Brazil, say they fear that this regional agreement is an attempt by the United States to divide and rule, forcing the bigger Latin nations to accept Washington's dictates in the wider negotiations.
"I think this is tactical," said Mario Mugnaini, vice president for international affairs at the Federation of Industries in Sao Paulo. "If there are too many bilateral accords made around the region, then Brazil would ultimately favor closing the F.T.A.A. negotiations, but I don't think that's what the United States wants."
Still, United States trade with these five Central American countries is significant. They import a total of $9 billion worth of products from the United States every year, the rough equivalent of American exports to Russia, India and Indonesia combined. And the United States imports $11 billion worth of goods from the five countries, with nearly three-fourths of the products entering duty free under special-preference programs.
The European Commission's chief trade negotiator, Pascal Lamy, seeking to regain a European foothold in the region and to capitalize on its Old World ties to Spain and Portugal, will travel to Brazil in three weeks -- seeking to fortify relations on a continent that in just a few months has moved swiftly toward a greater opening toward the United States.
The United States and nearly every country in the Western Hemisphere agreed on a blueprint for a Free Trade Area of the Americas in November with the goal of essentially expanding the North American Free Trade Agreement all the way to Argentina by January 2005. Brazil, the largest Latin American economy and the nation most skeptical of a free trade area, is now co-chairman of those talks with the United States.
Last month, Washington concluded a free trade pact with Chile -- a model, Mr. Zoellick hopes, for the talks with the Central American nations, particularly in the areas of protection for laborers and the environment. 
Bernard W. Aronson, assistant secretary of state for inter-American affairs under President Bush's father, who first proposed a hemispherewide free trade zone, said that while Mr. Zoellick might be making rapid strides now, they were perhaps 10 years too late.
"I think that the U.S. and Latin America have paid an enormous price for failing to spread free trade throughout the hemisphere after Nafta," Mr. Aronson said. "If we had, the hemisphere would look very different, and much of the economic and political disintegration wouldn't have occurred."
But some of the praise for Mr. Zoellick's efforts today was laced with criticism of the administration for relying on trade to solve a myriad of crises in Latin America. "Zoellick is doing a wonderful job, but it's extremely unfortunate that he is carrying the water for the whole administration," said Julia Sweig, a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations. The region, she said, "deserves more senior attention."
At the beginning of the month, Brazilian officials were insulted when Mr. Zoellick led the American delegation to the inauguration of President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, leader of the leftist Workers Party. Not only was he considered too junior, but he has been held in some disdain for warning Brazil that it would be reduced to exporting to Antarctica if it failed to join in the Americas trade pact.
Brazil, indeed, has lobbied for the hemispherewide negotiations to be concluded as a single undertaking, meaning all loose ends of an accord must be tied up before all countries involved can sign.
Now, a senior trade official said, Mr. Zoellick is trying to push Brazil "into not just joining the pact, but leading the way."
The major sticking points in all the negotiations will be farm products, especially sugar and citrus fruit.
But the trade and economic ministers of the five Central American countries said today that they were willing to compromise to win permanent access to the United States economy and lure greater investment to their region.
"We're also talking about something more fundamental than trade," said Alberto Trejos, Costa Rica's foreign trade minister. "We'll derive many, many more permanent benefits and a vision of development that will mean more jobs and increased prosperity."
While concern over the strike-induced oil crisis in Venezuela and the civil strife in Colombia may occupy higher-ranking members of the administration, trade officials say they are well suited to be the most prominent representatives of President Bush in the region.
"Economics is the most compelling aspect of U.S.-Latin relations," said Peter Allgeier, a deputy United States trade representative. "Getting access to us gives the message to investors that their countries are a safe place to put their money."

HEADLINE: POLITICS AND THE ECONOMY: PROSPECTS IN CONGRESS; 
Democrats Ease Their Support For a Tax Cut

BYLINE:  By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 

 BODY:
A number of moderate Senate Democrats who were instrumental in helping President Bush pass a tax cut in 2001 said today that they opposed eliminating the federal tax on dividend payments, clouding the Congressional prospects for the central feature of the new Bush economic plan.
 In 2001, President Bush was able to garner enough bipartisan support in the thinly divided Senate to pass his $1.35 trillion tax cut package. This time, however, even the president's Republican supporters predict a tougher road. 
 "There are a number of Democrats who voted with him on the last tax cut, and also a number of Republicans, who are not willing to just accept this one as a fait accompli and take it as it is," Senator John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana, said in an interview, adding that the dividend tax cut would have to be "replaced and/or dramatically scaled down." 
The support of Mr. Breaux is considered crucial to passage of any economic stimulus legislation by the Senate, where Republicans have the barest majority. In 2001 he helped the White House win 12 Democratic votes for tax cuts. 
The centerpiece of the $674 billion plan is its proposal to eliminate taxes on corporate dividends, which many Democrats regard as an unjustified boon for the wealthy. Though the plan contains provisions that Democrats might support, including a $400-a-child rebate to many families and elimination of the so-called marriage tax penalty, the dividend tax cut is quickly becoming a lightning rod in the Senate.
Senator Dianne Feinstein, a California Democrat who voted for the 2001 tax cut, described the president's plan as "a nonstarter."
"Right now," Mrs. Feinstein said, "I don't know of any Democrat who's going to vote for it."
Senator Charles E. Grassley, the Iowa Republican who is chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, said Mr. Bush's plan was not likely to pass intact. Mr. Grassley, who helped push through the 2001 tax cuts, said he believed he would be able to negotiate a bipartisan bill that would win the support of a majority of senators.
"We will pass a large -- albeit not as large as the president requests, but a very large -- effective stimulus package, and we will do it by early spring," Mr. Grassley said.
Of the plan's dividend provision, he said: "It might be modified, I would agree. But it would not be eliminated."
At this stage, lawmakers are staking out negotiating positions and could change their stances as the proposal gets closer scrutiny. And while the dividend tax cut may face tough going in the Senate, it has been getting a generally warm reception in the House, where Republicans have a firmer hold on the legislative process. 
Speaker J. Dennis Hastert, Republican of Illinois, said he expected a quick vote on the bill "and I would suspect it will look very much like what the president asked for."
A potential problem the White House may face in the House is the desire of some Republican leaders to enact more expansive tax cuts than the White House proposed. Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the House Republican leader, said today that he would like to pass an even bigger proposal.
"I look at the Bush plan as a floor," Mr. DeLay said, "not a ceiling." 
With the Senate nearly evenly divided -- 51 Republicans, 48 Democrats and one independent -- the White House must count every vote. To avoid a Democratic filibuster, Senate Republicans are leaning toward attaching the stimulus plan to a budget bill, a parliamentary procedure that would allow legislation to pass with a simple majority of 51 votes. 
But Senator Bill Frist of Tennessee, the majority leader, said Republicans had not yet determined how to move a tax package through the Senate, or how big it should be. Asked whether he agreed with Mr. DeLay that the president's call for a $670 billion tax cut over the next decade should be a floor rather than a ceiling, Dr. Frist said it was "premature for me to say whether that's a floor."
The political and economic climate in Washington has changed enormously since the 2001 tax cut. Despite the Republicans' control of Congress, those changes do not work entirely in Mr. Bush's favor.
The war on terrorism has helped run up the federal deficit, which is driving Democratic criticism of the economic stimulus plan. A handful of Senate Republicans, like Senators Lincoln Chafee of Rhode Island, who voted against the first Bush tax cuts, and Olympia J. Snowe of Maine, apparently share that concern. 
On Thursday, Mr. Chafee plans to join with Mrs. Feinstein to introduce legislation that would freeze the current top income tax rate until budget surpluses return, thus blocking a provision of the 2001 tax cuts from taking effect. 
Ms. Snowe said in a statement that she would like to "carefully review" the dividend proposal, as well as the overall cost of the Bush plan.
"At a time of growing federal deficits," she said, "it is especially important that this plan be right-sized, without putting our future at risk."
At the same time, Mr. Bush has lost some good will among Democrats in the Senate by campaigning for their opponents last November. Among them is Mary L. Landrieu of Louisiana, who voted for the 2001 tax cuts but said today that she would not support the plan Mr. Bush announced on Tuesday in Chicago.
"There is not enough stimulus in the stimulus package," Ms. Landrieu said.
Democrats in general favor a much narrower initiative. In the House, for example, Democrats have proposed a $136 billion stimulus package that would cost taxpayers $100 billion when spread out over 10 years. In the Senate, Max Baucus of Montana has proposed a $160 billion stimulus plan similar to the one proposed by Democrats in the House.
The administration says eliminating dividend taxes, which would put $364 billion in the hands of investors, would increase economic growth by increasing the stock value of companies, encouraging investment. But today, leading Democrats stepped up their criticism of the plan.
"If anything, it's a stimulus plan for the rich," said Senator Tom Daschle, the Democratic leader. 
Later, Mr. Daschle went to the White House, along with Congressional leaders of both parties, to meet with Mr. Bush to discuss the agenda for the coming year. Though the economic package was high on the list, there was no effort to bridge the partisan divide on tax cuts.
Representative Steny H. Hoyer of Maryland, the Democratic whip, described it as a "feel-good meeting" that emphasized the willingness of both parties to work together, without yielding any particular evidence that they would do so.

HEADLINE: Happy Talk in Albany 

 BODY:
Gov. George Pataki offered a feel-good assessment of the state of the state yesterday when there was little to feel good about. Mr. Pataki painted New York's budget crisis as something that had no relation to his own policies, and suggested that it could be resolved without undue pain to the taxpayers. The governor, a Republican, even had the chutzpah to lecture the Legislature about the need for being "frank, honest and clear about the scope of the crisis." It was a challenge he certainly did not meet with yesterday's speech. 
 Sounding more conservative than he did during his re-election campaign, Mr. Pataki made his main pitch for no new taxes. That felt less like a promise than an attempt to make the Legislature find the revenue to bridge a $2 billion deficit in this year's budget and a gap of maybe $10 billion in next year's. The governor's plan is to cut his way out of budget troubles, and to use irresponsible gimmicks like borrowing against anticipated proceeds from the tobacco company settlements. Until this week he was also undoubtedly expecting help from Washington. But President Bush failed to come to the rescue on Tuesday in his speech about the economy. 
 Mr. Pataki notably failed to mention any help for localities that are drowning in costs imposed by the state. Unless they get aid, any taxes he avoids in Albany will show up in the overstressed cities and counties.
When it came to new initiatives, the governor revived many of his moss-covered favorites, good ideas that are always tucked into the end of this speech and never seem to go anywhere, like campaign finance reform and revamping the Rockefeller drug laws. With the state government broken, his only proposed fix was to promise voters the right to put their own ideas on the ballot through petitioning. This is an attractive-sounding concept that works out to be terrible in reality, as most states saddled with the initiatives have found out. 
To be fair, it would be hard for the governor to come up with many new programs at a time of such financial peril. A promise to push for more renewable energy over the next 10 years was one suggestion that sounded promising. But over all, Mr. Pataki's big thought for the new year seems to be that if he says everything will be fine, that will make it so.

HEADLINE: Back to the Right 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 8 

 BODY:
After winning re-election by running as a liberal Republican, Gov. George E. Pataki moved back to the right today, firmly positioning himself in the dominant wing of his party with a promise to cut spending and oppose higher taxes.
 The governor's annual address to the Legislature was a mix of standard conservative themes that dovetailed nicely with the tax-cutting and tough-on-terrorism philosophies emanating from President Bush's White House. 
 The speech appeared to put Mr. Pataki in a better position to bid for national office if the opportunity arises. Political advisers to the governor say he would like to keep himself in the national mix, as a possible replacement for Vice President Dick Cheney should he decide not to run for re-election in 2004, or as a candidate for a cabinet post in the Bush administration that might open up. 
Mr. Pataki spent much of his 55-minute speech talking about the need to be vigilant against terrorism and to pass new laws to make it easier to ferret out terrorists. He applauded American soldiers abroad and allowed himself a moment of patriotic gloating over a piece of marble, reputed to be from a palace where Osama bin Laden once lived, that New York reservists brought back from Afghanistan.
He also praised his administration's success in attracting high-tech industries to upstate New York with tax breaks and subsidies. And he made it clear he felt cutting taxes to spur the economy was more important than preserving spending.
The governor promised to shrink the government's size and to hold no program sacred except public security. He urged lawmakers not to pass "job-killing taxes" but to maintain "New York State as the tax-cutting capital of America."
"We simply must spend less money," he said.
The governor's stance against more spending was a sharp departure from his strategy during the election, when he said little about shrinking government. Instead he stressed his support for expensive social programs, like insurance for the poor and drug subsidies for the elderly, as part of an effort to woo Latinos, union members and moderate Democrats.
Mr. Pataki even quoted President Ronald Reagan, who holds a special place in the hearts of conservative Republicans. The governor challenged lawmakers to act now to make the difficult decisions necessary to balance the budget and keep taxes down, rather than take what he called "the path of political expediency." It was the only quote he used.
Conservatives and Republicans were delighted with the speech; labor leaders and Democrats, some of whom supported his re-election bid, were dismayed.
"He's coming home to his roots," said Michael Long, chairman of the Conservative Party. "He made it clear no part of the budget is left untouched except security. One thing is sure. We are not going to raise taxes."
Assemblyman Alexander B. Grannis, a veteran Manhattan liberal, echoed the views of many Democrats when he said Mr. Pataki's prescription for the state's budget troubles would prove too painful for most voters to accept.
"I'm not sure slashing services to the degree necessary to meet this deficit he is just beginning to acknowledge is palatable to most New Yorkers," he said. "I don't see how it's realistic."
Not only did the governor vow to go ahead with $200 million in tax cuts already enacted and slated to take effect this year, but he said he would also call for new tax incentives to attract investment to the state.
He presented the options before lawmakers, as the state struggles to close a $2 billion gap in this year's budget and at least an $8 billion gap in the next, as a stark choice between creating jobs or raising taxes to save themselves from unpopular choices. "We must choose jobs," he said.
Mr. Pataki also distinguished himself from former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, the liberal icon whom he defeated in 1994. He asserted Mr. Cuomo had prolonged the recession in New York by raising taxes during the economic downturn in 1989.
Then Mr. Pataki argued that his administration had taken the wise path when he took over in 1995, by cutting taxes and spending simultaneously in the face of a $5 billion deficit. He claimed a turnaround resulted, even though many economists say the national economy was already entering the biggest boom in history when he cut taxes.
The subtext of Mr. Pataki's speech was clear: any fuzziness about the governor's leanings that emerged during the campaign was erased.
What the governor left out also signaled a shift to the right. He made no pledge to protect state aid to local schools, and promised to "lower the cost of Medicaid." He said nothing about bailing out New York City.
The governor also distanced himself from the state's fiscal crisis, portraying it as unavoidable and unforeseeable fallout from the terrorist attack in September 2001, rather than a result of the deal last year between himself and legislative leaders to spend the state's reserves and other one-time revenues in order to avert budget cuts before the election.
"He took the usual liberties in explaining how all this came about," said Edmund J. McMahon, an analyst with the conservative Manhattan Institute. "He portrayed the state as a completely innocent bystander, which it is not."

HEADLINE: Bush and the Economy: The Debate Heats Up 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "The Charles Schwab Tax Cut" (editorial, Jan. 7): 
 You call President Bush's move to end the dividend tax "cynical." 
 But the right tax cuts, paired with a reduction in spending, will result in a jump in corporate profits by encouraging investment, which causes the creation of more jobs and increases the government's financial intake through taxes.
The broker Charles Schwab, the president and millions of Americans realize that supply-side economics and this tax cut work.

HEADLINE: Bush and the Economy: The Debate Heats Up 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 While President Bush's economic plan offers the promise of billions in tax giveaways to America's wealthiest (front page, Jan. 8), it offers no help at all to cash-strapped local governments, like our own. 
 The president's plan is more a shell game than a policy. He promises tax cuts for the few while forcing local governments to raise taxes on the many.
What New York City and the country need is a responsible plan that includes a federal revenue-sharing program to help cities and counties balance their budgets and hold the line on property taxes. The program could be financed by deferring part of the tax cut directed at the top 5 percent. 
A recent City Council study estimates that an $80 billion federal revenue-sharing plan would mean that the average city homeowner could see his or her property taxes fall by $207, while the average co-op owner could see a reduction of $307. 
It would also mean that the City Council and the mayor could spare vital services like police, fire, sanitation and education. 

GIFFORD MILLER
Speaker, New York City Council
New York, Jan. 8, 2003

HEADLINE: POLITICS AND THE ECONOMY: JOBLESS COMPENSATION; 
Bush Signs Bill to Extend Unemployment Benefits

BYLINE:  By CARL HULSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 

 BODY:
President Bush signed into law today an extension of unemployment benefits for about 2.5 million Americans just hours after the bill cleared the House, making the politically popular legislation the first enacted by the new Republican-controlled Congress.
 Moving to dispose quickly of a measure that languished in the last Congress, Mr. Bush and Republican Congressional leaders said the measure guaranteed that benefits would continue to about 800,000 people in danger of being cut off. The Labor Department estimated that 1.6 million more would qualify for federal aid under the new program, which would run through May. 
 With Congressional leaders at the White House, Mr. Bush said the legislation "should bring some comfort to those of our fellow citizens who need extra help during the time in which they try to find a job." 
Democrats said the $7.2 billion Republican-endorsed approach fell short of what was needed in an uncertain economy and accused the majority Republicans of preventing them from offering alternatives on the jobless and spending.
"A few people in Republican leadership circles are deciding ahead of time what the outcome of legislation should be, and then they are rigging the process so that there's no chance whatsoever of ever modifying it," said Representative David R. Obey of Wisconsin, senior Democrat on the Appropriations Committee.
The House was beginning to "much more closely resemble a Soviet-style Congress," Mr. Obey said.
The majority leader, Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, dismissed the complaints.
"What the Democrats' problem is, nothing is good enough for them," Mr. DeLay said. "In fact, I would venture to guess that they would have unlimited unemployment compensation so somebody could stay out of work for the rest of their lives and get unemployment compensation if they had their way."
In the end, House Democrats supported the jobless bill, which was passed unanimously by the Senate on Tuesday, but they objected to the refusal of the House leadership to consider enlarging the package. They wanted to offer new benefits to one million or more Americans who have already gone through their state and federal jobless aid. They said it would be a more direct benefit to the economy than Mr. Bush's proposed $674 billion economic plan, which has as its centerpiece eliminating the tax on stock dividends.
"We have a million people out there," said Representative Charles B. Rangel of New York, the senior Democrat on the Ways and Means Committee. "They don't have dividends." 
Under the measure, adopted on a vote of 416 to 4, about 800,000 people who had not received all 13 weeks of their added federal benefits under a program that expired Dec. 28 will get the remainder. In addition, people who exhaust their state benefits in the coming weeks will also be able to claim up to 13 additional weeks of federal assistance. The Labor Department estimates the average weekly benefit at $250.
The most recent national jobless rate was an eight-year high of 6 percent for November, with figures for December expected on Friday.
Republicans argued that Democrats had supported a similar, though less expansive version of the measure that died as Congress adjourned last November and that the one million people who have lost coverage had received substantial help.
"Let's not get mixed up in the rhetoric of partisanship here," said Representative Jennifer Dunn, Republican of Washington.
House Democrats contrasted the need for extended benefits with Mr. Bush's new economic plan, saying the unemployed should come first.
"If we want to stimulate the economy, what we do is put some money in the pockets of those individuals so they can go to the grocery store and buy a loaf of bread," said Representative Danny K. Davis, Democrat of Illinois, who said his Chicago area district had lost thousands of jobs.
The unemployment fight was a remnant of the last Congress, when the House and Senate failed to reach agreement on an extension of benefits. At the time, House Republican officials were willing to accept only a narrow extension, saying they wanted to consider the problem more fully this year.
In the Senate, a bipartisan group of lawmakers including Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, Democrat of New York, and Don Nickles, Republican of Oklahoma, worked out a three-month expansion.
Despite Democratic prodding, Mr. Bush did not intervene in the fight, but on the Congressional break he endorsed the idea of extending the benefits. House and Senate Republicans agreed to go along, though they were opposed to covering those whose money had run out. 
Speaker J. Dennis Hastert called the new coverage generous but indicated he preferred to help the jobless with a new economic program. "When I talk to my constituents who are having trouble finding a job, they are not satisfied drawing on unemployment insurance," Mr. Hastert said. "They want to go to work."
Mrs. Clinton welcomed the adoption of the law. "Uncertainty and concern have been replaced with five additional months of benefits for millions of Americans, and this victory is theirs," she said, adding that she would continue to press to cover people whose benefits had run out.
Labor Department officials said that because of the way unemployment claims were processed, no one would miss a check even though the program expired on Dec. 28.
After finishing the unemployment issue, the House moved to keep the federal government open while it tried to complete work on 11 spending bills that were also left from 2002. A temporary funding resolution approved last year expires Saturday, and the House adopted on voice vote tonight a measure that would keep agencies running through the end of the month. The Senate is expected to take it up on Thursday.
House and Senate leaders hope to pass by the end of January a huge package wrapping up most of remaining spending measures. Senate Republican leaders said today that they had pared $9.2 billion from bills drafted last year to reach a $750 billion level acceptable to the House and the White House, raising the prospect of a fight over cuts.
Mr. Hastert also said tonight that Representative Christopher Cox, a senior member from California, would chair a new select committee on domestic security.
House members also ratified a leadership decisions to make Richard W. Pombo of California the chairman of the Resources Committee. Tom Davis of Virginia, who directed the Republican Party's House campaign organization, will be the new chairman of the Government Reform Committee. Robert W. Goodlatte of Virginia will take over the Agriculture Committee, and Duncan Hunter of California the Armed Services Committee.

UP CLOSE
What the Unemployment Law Does

These are the highlights of $7.2 billion unemployment package signed into law yesterday by President Bush:

Maintains benefits for about 800,000 people entitled to up to 13 weeks of federal aid in a program that expired on Dec. 28.

Provides up to 13 weeks of emergency federal benefits to an estimated 1.6 million people who could exhaust their 26 weeks of state aid before the end of May.

Continues aid beyond June 1 for those who qualify under a phase-out provision that was not part of the program that expired on Dec. 28.

Provides no coverage for an estimated 1 million workers who remain unemployed and have exhausted their state benefits and emergency federal aid.

Does not affect a new proposal by President Bush to set up accounts of up to $3,000 to help the unemployed find work and pay expenses in their job search. Congress will consider that idea as part of the presidents economic plan.

HEADLINE: Technology Briefing E-Commerce: Congress To Consider Extending Internet Tax Moratorium 

BYLINE:  NYT 

 BODY:
 Legislation was introduced in both chambers of Congress to extend indefinitely a moratorium on Internet taxes. The current ban on federal and state taxes on online services is set to expire in November. 
Senator Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, and Representative Christopher Cox, Republican of California, submitted identical bills on Tuesday. "Putting new, unfair Internet taxes on the backs of consumers is not the way to fix state and local budget troubles," Mr. Wyden said. "It could seriously weaken the growing Internet economy and take jobs away from folks working for small Web companies." Congress passed the original ban on Internet taxes in 1998 to prevent states and local governments from imposing taxes that some thought could stunt the growth of the Web. Governors and state officials have argued that millions of dollars are lost in taxes every year when people shop on the Internet. But online retailers and technology companies, among others, say taxing online transactions could impair commerce, particularly during a recession.

HEADLINE: Gambling's Success 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "A Bad Bet" (editorial, Jan. 3): Communities that turned to casino gambling in the 1990's to address fiscal problems have been enormously successful. 
 A 1999 report by the National Academy of Sciences also concluded that "gambling appears to have net economic benefits for economically depressed communities."
As to the negative effects you allege, research conducted in 1999 for the National Gambling Impact Study Commission found that the presence of casinos does not correspond to increases in crime or bankruptcy; a separate Treasury Department study also found no bankruptcy link. 
Additionally, commission research estimated that the pathological gambling prevalence rate was 0.6 percent in 1999, whereas in 1976 it was 0.7 percent. Despite a significant increase in gambling opportunities, the rate has remained relatively static.

FRANK J. FAHRENKOPF JR.
President and Chief Executive
American Gaming Association
Washington, Jan. 3, 2003
