HEADLINE: Homeless Out-of-Towners Welcome; 
Families Rely on City's Vast Shelter System for a Place to Live

BYLINE:  By LESLIE KAUFMAN

 BODY:
Ramon Almestica came from Puerto Rico seeking a better standard of living. Rosland Jackson fled an abusive boyfriend in North Carolina who had tried to abduct her youngest child. Jacqueline Garcia and her family were evicted from their apartment in Miami while vacationing in New York and have been here ever since.
 All three are or have been residents of the city's homeless shelters. 
 New York has always been a Mecca to out-of-towners dreaming of bettering their lot. Some scrub dishes in restaurants, others audition at theaters or fill its schools. And as it turns out, there is a sizable number who seek to improve their lives through the city's vast and fast-expanding shelter system. 
In October, the most recent month for which data were available, 10 percent of those seeking assistance at the Emergency Assistance Unit, the city's primary intake office for homeless families, reported that they spent the previous night outside the five boroughs; historically, the monthly average, which fluctuates, has been closer to 5 to 6 percent, city data show.
Of the 16,628 families that applied for shelter in the first 10 months of 2002, 2,681, or 16.1 percent, resided outside the city a month earlier, according to an average of city figures. (The city does not ask homeless individuals to report where they were last housed.)
Behind the statistics lies a debate that has long caused rifts in other cities, like San Francisco and Santa Monica, Calif., that have generous policies toward the homeless: are the families truly in need, or are they using an already overburdened system as a taxpayer-financed relocation service?
The Department of Homeless Services investigates each family to evaluate whether it is truly homeless or whether there might be relatives who can offer shelter. Some homeless families readily admit that they sought help from the city, through the Emergency Assistance Unit office in the Bronx, after friends and relatives said they had found decent apartments with the help of the unit's caseworkers.
But advocates for the homeless say that for the most part, families are not exploiting the city's homeless policy, but they come to live with relatives or for economic opportunities and end up in the shelters when things do not turn out as expected.
"They come for the same reason immigrants have always come: they think the streets are paved with gold," says Beverly Cheuvront, a spokeswoman for the Partnership for the Homeless, a nonprofit advocacy group. "And they are completely unprepared to deal with the realities of our housing market and our current economic situation."
New York is the only city under court order to provide shelter immediately to any people who can prove they need it, regardless of their origin or immigration status. As a result, it has perhaps the most tolerant admissions policies and greatest array of services and housing to offer its homeless clients. While that has raised some concern that the city could become a magnet for the poor, city officials remain sanguine.
"We are a city of immigrants, and the fact that the homeless system reflects that diversity is not surprising," said Linda I. Gibbs, the commissioner of the Department of Homeless Services. "Our focus is to ensure that people who have lost their homes here have access to housing but to make it clear that the E.A.U. is not to provide relocation services."
Certainly, New York is not the only city to shoulder the burden of the destitute from outside its borders. More than half of the people in the shelter systems in Spokane, Wash., and Minneapolis come from out of town, most frequently from surrounding rural counties where there are no equivalent services for the homeless, according to Dennis Culhane, a professor at the University of Pennsylvania, who does research on shelter systems nationwide.
Other cities, like Philadelphia, demand that shelter seekers prove they have been city residents for at least six months. Mr. Culhane and other academic researchers who have studied New York's shelter system say their own research from previous years shows that an average of about 4 percent of the families seeking shelter say they have spent the previous night out of the city, a figure considerably lower than the 10 percent reported by the city this month. Mr. Culhane said he was not surprised by the rise but could not explain it without further study.
Others were more skeptical. Marybeth Shinn, a professor of psychology at New York University who studies homeless families, said focusing on where the city's homeless came from was a red herring that distracted from real problems, most important a lack of affordable housing.
"Politicians have frequently put out a Greyhound theory that problems have been dumped on us," Professor Shinn said. "All around the country, homeless populations are for the most part homegrown." 
Ramon Almestica, his dark eyes peering out of his black down hood, says simply that he came here "to make a better life." Mr. Almestica grew up in New York, but left at age 12 to live in Puerto Rico with relatives. He said he returned because he was not making much of a living as a carpenter. 
Mr. Almestica, his wife and their 6-year-old daughter had been living with his mother-in-law, but he said he decided to seek help through the shelter system because his mother lives in a "nice place" in Brooklyn that she got through the Emergency Assistance Unit. He went to the unit, he said at its Bronx office, because she encouraged him to do the same.
Rosland Jackson came to the shelter system after moving out of the North Carolina home she and her three children shared with the father of her third child. He had become verbally and physically abusive, she said, and it got so bad one night when he was drunk that he threatened to kidnap the children. She responded by threatening him with a gun, she said.
Ms. Jackson, 36, said she tried to seek refuge at a shelter in North Carolina, but her batterer soon tracked her down and she decided to flee to New York. Ms. Jackson was raised here, but she had not lived in the city for 10 years. A friend who knew of her situation encouraged her to come here, and she went directly to the Emergency Assistance Unit after she arrived at the Port Authority Bus Terminal in February 2001.
Now she is housed in a two-bedroom apartment in the Bronx, and she says she is feeling much more secure. "The city is large," she said, "and it is easy to get lost."
While many homeless families come to New York knowing of the Emergency Assistance Unit, a larger percentage seem to hear about it after they get here. Jacqueline Garcia said she, her husband and their three children were visiting relatives in New York in February 2001 when her mother called from Miami to say that an eviction notice had been placed on the door of their two-bedroom apartment.
Her husband had recently been laid off from his job as a shipping and receiving clerk and they were having trouble making their $575-a-month rent, but even when he was working and earning $200 a week they were stretched, she said. "We had nothing to return to, so we decided to stay here," Ms. Garcia said. The family of five was living with relatives when she heard about the E.A.U. from her welfare caseworker.
Now settled in a federally subsidized three-bedroom apartment in the Bronx and with her husband working as an assistant manager at a Foot Locker shoe store, Ms. Garcia is glad she made the move. "I could never qualify for public housing in Miami," she said, saying her husband's salary disqualified her. "I love New York." 

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jacqueline Garcia, her husband, Peter Vasquez, and their children, from left, Eladio Vasquez, Yusmary Garcia and Anessa Vasquez, in their Bronx apartment. (George M. Gutierrez for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: YACHT RACING; 
New Zealand Cries Betrayal As Skipper Races for Swiss

BYLINE:  By MIKE WISE with WARREN ST. JOHN 

DATELINE: AUCKLAND, New Zealand 

 BODY:
In the choppy green waters of Auckland Harbor, the Kodak moment from the 2000 America's Cup is of Russell Coutts holding aloft the Auld Mug trophy, smiling through sea-chapped lips. Thousands of his countrymen lined the docks of the Viaduct Basin that day, roaring for their skipper and his triumphant crew.
 But within weeks, the pixie-dust tale of the home-grown sailor who kept the Cup in New Zealand had turned sour. Coutts left his syndicate to accept a $5 million offer to become skipper of the Swiss boat Alinghi. In the process, he took half of Team New Zealand's crew with him -- and turned a nation against him. 
 Just ask Charles Stone, the Web site editor for BlackHeart, an alliance of zealous New Zealanders formed solely because of Coutts's defection. 
"I wouldn't even talk to the bloody traitor, unless he were asking for a ride to the airport," Stone said.
"We always had Dennis Conner to dislike for a long time, but Russell Coutts has taken that position over," said Simon Jolly, who helms a commercial yacht in Auckland harbor. "To be in New Zealand when that happened, many people feel he committed treason."
As Coutts readies his sleek and well-equipped yacht for the Louis Vuitton Cup challenger final on Jan. 11, he may be the most disliked Kiwi alive.
He needs five victories against the last remaining American boat, Oracle, to advance to the Cup finals in February against New Zealand -- a matchup that would be the equivalent of Walter O'Malley's bringing a team filled with former Brooklyn Dodgers back to New York to compete for a championship.
And if Alinghi wins the Cup, New Zealanders lose. They lose the world's oldest sporting trophy, an estimated $650 million in Cup-generated revenue, and, above all, a good measure of their sailing pride. 
Law-enforcement officials are now worried that if Coutts tries to raise the trophy in Auckland Harbor, the reaction could be vehement and the indelible image embarrassing to New Zealand.
Coutts defends his switch to Alinghi by saying he had achieved all his goals as a sailor for New Zealand, and was ready for a new challenge. He also contends he achieved a great accomplishment for his home country by defending the Cup three years ago, and had earned the right to move on.
Some Kiwis agree. But many, especially in the yachting community, retain a deep enmity represented by a billboard near the harbor sponsored by BlackHeart that regularly changes its anti-Alinghi message. A sampling: "Coutts and Co. -- Swiss bankers since 2000," and "High on a hill lived a lonely boatman -- yodelei, yodelei, yodelei-e-hoo."
 The anti-Coutts crusade took an ugly turn in early January when the Alinghi syndicate said it had received anonymous letters threatening the children and family of team members. The Auckland police are investigating the letters.
 "I am horrified by the tone in these letters, as I am sure most New Zealanders will be," said Michel Bonnefous, Alinghi's executive director. "As a team we are committed to winning on the water, and we look forward to the next round of sailing, but we will be cooperating fully with police to track down and bring the perpetrators to justice. We came here, in New Zealand, to sail, not to have our children threatened."
 Coutts wrote a letter to The Daily Telegraph, saying, "We will go racing mindful of the menacing letters that some Alinghi team members received threatening violence to our families' property and base." 
The venom belies a country known for its live-and-let-live demeanor. Kiwis offer their homes to backpacking strangers for the night, and hitchhiking along sheep-strewn roads is still one of the safest modes of transportation.
But to understand the venom, one needs to understand the passion for sailing in New Zealand and the unique geography of a two-island nation where the coastline is longer than the Atlantic and the Pacific coasts of the United States combined. One in 10 Kiwis owns a sailboat.

The National Pastime
After Sir Edmund Hillary, the first man to scale Mount Everest, New Zealand's greatest hero was Sir Peter Blake, the yachtsman who led the successful challenge in 1995 against Conner in San Diego and organized the defense in 2000.
Children begin sailing at age 6 and younger. At its core in New Zealand, sailing has none of the elitist qualities that come with the American perception of the sport. Regardless of a family's income, a rusted boat for a few hundred dollars can be salvaged and repainted for competition. Coutts was a product of that system, and Kiwis take great pride in the fact that they pay for their Cup challenges through merchandising and donations, not tycoons.
When billionaire backers of other syndicates -- Ernesto Bertarelli of Alinghi, Larry Ellison of San Francisco-based Oracle and Craig McCaw and Paul Allen of Seattle's OneWorld -- began to recruit New Zealanders for their crews, many Kiwis felt the lifeblood of the nation's sport was siphoned away.
"New Zealand had big plans for what the America's Cup could become if it got rid of all of its negative connotations and became a great celebration of sailing," Stone said. "And we did that. But all it took was one major defection to start the ball rolling."
BlackHeart was founded by an Auckland advertising executive named Dave Walden. It is essentially an alliance of 3,000 sailing fanatics. It began as a way for New Zealanders to gather to express their anger. They have described themselves as like-minded, as staunch and as true New Zealand patriots. But they also add, "The time for action is upon us." 
"We've got to take a lesson from the Aussies and get a bit of the mongrel in us," Walden said in a recent interview with an Australian newspaper. "New Zealanders have a lovely nature, but at times we are a bit too bloody soft."
The scorn over being dumped for another team or another city is a universal fan reaction. Yet the anger directed toward Coutts is not the same as for the former Knicks coach Pat Riley when he returns to Madison Square Garden after having left for the Miami Heat's millions. Irate fans eventually got over the hurt and were happy simply to root against him.
In New Zealand, the anger and feeling of betrayal have lingered and intensified, and people meet to organize protests, raising anti-Alinghi billboards and excoriating Coutts and his crew on the Internet. 
Coutts's rival skipper in the challenger finals, Chris Dickson of Oracle, is also a native Kiwi. But he was not part of Team New Zealand for the past two America's Cups, and did not lure away the best of New Zealand's sailors, as Coutts did. As such, he and other Kiwis who are competing for other countries have managed to stay clear of the vitriol reserved for Coutts and Brad Butterworth, the Alinghi tactician who was the first person Coutts lured away. 
In December, as Coutts stepped off a small dinghy onto the docks of Takapuna Wharf after a race, he was heckled for 15 minutes. In the earlier rounds, dozens of black-shirted Kiwis emblazoned with only the national emblem, a silver fern, and the word Loyal cheered wildly for the boats belonging to Coutts's rivals. In contrast, when Alinghi left the Viaduct Basin, they looked on in stone silence.
Bertarelli is so concerned for Coutts's safety if Alinghi captures the Cup that he has intimated to at least two team officials, who requested anonymity, that he wants to quickly shepherd Coutts and Butterworth from the yacht straight to the airport, possibly via helicopter.
"I find the whole thing quite surprising," he said. "People tend to forget what Russell has done for the country."
After Coutts and Butterworth helped win the Cup for New Zealand in 1995 and successfully defended it in 2000, they pledged their loyalty toward making another defense.
But Bertarelli's $5 million offer, along with a promise of more control, persuaded Coutts to leave. When he took Butterworth and others with him, it prompted a Kiwi sailing exodus. Twenty-one of the 64 sailors on the water in the Louis Vuitton semifinals were New Zealanders.
Beyond BlackHeart, radio hosts and news media commentators have fed the enmity within the general populace. When Coutts tossed a few nonchalant barbs his former team's way, the front page of The New Zealand Herald blared, "Coutts Savages Team New Zealand."
But some Aucklanders have a more balanced view of Coutts's decision. "I'd like to see one of the BlackHearts stand on the dock and say no to a $1 million check," Brad McCracken, a local bartender, said. "I don't think they would."

Reasons for Leaving
Coutts, who many yachting observers believe has become the most gifted and cunning skipper in sailing, said he is unaffected. His crewneck cotton shirts, bushy eyebrows, high cheekbones and thick brown hair make him look like an Eco-challenge competitor, fresh from his last adventure. 
At a local business association breakfast he was invited to in December, against the wishes of several members -- Coutts explained his reasoning. He said he had run his course in New Zealand sailing after having been a youth champion, an Olympic gold medalist and a skipper who had successfully challenged for and defended the Cup. He also did not avoid the money issue.
"Clearly, that was a consideration," he said. "But there was also an opportunity to have a great deal of control and vision of the team, including putting it together."
Coutts contends he has not noticed the snubs and the jeers. "I've never once had anyone say anything to me directly," he said in an interview in November. "Well, once, when I was flying back right after signing with Alinghi, a New Zealand guy came up to me on the plane and said, 'You've got cheek coming back.'
"I said: 'What's the matter? Haven't I done enough?' And that's pretty much how I feel now." 
Conner, the American sailing legend, is fond of saying the Cup is not worth money. But tell that to Kiwi tourism officials and they will point to the $650 million Team New Zealand's first defense brought to a stagnant economy looking for a boost. They expect an even bigger haul this time. If Coutts wins the final and the Cup goes to Europe for the first time in its 151-year history, so does the money the event generates.
Some New Zealanders extrapolate and conclude that Coutts's defection is putting people out of work. Others contend that Coutts and others -- including the OneWorld designer Laurie Davidson, Team New Zealand's former designer -- took intellectual property with them, Kiwi sailing secrets that will cause the demise of a cash cow.
"We're not going so far as to say the city dies if we lost the Cup," Stone said. "But it means more to this city than any other city in the world. My God, they'll auction off a part of the harbor, a huge piece of Auckland."
Bertarelli countered: "We are here for a sporting event and no one should forget that. We're not here to grow the Kiwi economy. If we were here to do that, then I'd be doing biotechnology here, not sailing. If you compete in a sporting event, you have to accept the possibility of losing."
 In early January, Stone dismissed the notion that BlackHeart helped create an environment that led to the threats. "We have been at pains to point out all along that our organization was formed to focus the anger in a lighthearted and humorous way, in order to prevent exactly an ill-disciplined or criminal scenario such as this," Stone wrote in an e-mail message. 
In the City of Sails, meanwhile, people line the docks daily, pounding their fists against their chests and cheering against the crew led by the man who wants to take the Auld Mug out of his homeland and bring it to Switzerland.
"Come on, Russell, we know the story," a recent BlackHeart newsletter said. "And it reads like Macbeth."

CORRECTION-DATE: May 2, 2004

 CORRECTION:
A report in the F.Y.I. column of this section on Dec. 15, 2002, about the America's Cup, credited it erroneously with a precedent. It is the world's oldest sailing trophy, first awarded in 1851, but not ''the oldest trophy in sport.'' The Scorton Silver Arrow is considered the oldest, awarded annually in an English archery tournament since 1673. (The error also occurred in sports articles on Jan. 10, 2003; Dec. 22, 2002; May 10, 1992; Dec. 25, 1983; Sept. 27, 1983; Sept. 25, 1983; June 12, 1983; and Jan. 16, 1983; as well as editorials on May 19, 1992, and Jan. 21, 1987; also a Travel article on Sept. 4, 1983, and the Saturday News Quiz on June 18, 1983.) A reader's letter dated this past April 12 reported the error.

HEADLINE: Analysts Predict Harsh Cuts Despite Pataki's Optimism 

BYLINE:  By AL BAKER

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 9 

 BODY:
A day after Gov. George E. Pataki gave a speech to the State Legislature expressing optimism in the face of a bleak fiscal landscape, many here and elsewhere today asked not whether his budget would hurt ordinary taxpayers, but how much.
 By any interpretation, the governor's speech on Wednesday laid the groundwork for spending reductions that will affect people in all corners of the state. 
 Fiscal conservatives welcomed some of them, saying they are necessary to rein in excessive and even luxurious spending built up in the economic boom of the past six years. But Democrats and Republicans agree the cuts will not come without pain. 
Mr. Pataki only spoke in broad strokes about his plan for grappling with a multibillion-dollar budget gap. The precise line-by-line details will not come to light until he presents his executive spending plan on Jan. 29, so most of the prognosticating today was an analysis of his 55-minute address.
The parameters the governor laid out suggest two main themes: cuts in core state services and a reluctance to raise taxes. That translates into austere times the likes of which state residents have not seen in at least eight years, budget analysts and others said.
Health and hospital professionals could see cuts, and their patients will likely feel some. Educators and students could, too. Those who run social programs, and those who benefit from them, are probably not exempt. Unions may be asked to help. City residents, rural residents and suburbanites, too, may feel a sting.
"Everything will be hit," said E. J. McMahon, an analyst with the conservative Manhattan Institute. "I don't think there is any question of that."
The pain will linger even if the economy recovers, especially if Mr. Pataki gets legislative approval to borrow $4 billion against payments from tobacco companies to help fill the current hole, incurring more long-term debt, some said.
"It's a one-shot; it is the mother of all one-shots," former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, a Democrat who Mr. Pataki defeated in 1994, said today of the borrowing idea.
But many noted that Mr. Pataki, the three-term Republican governor who made so many promises to spend on expensive social programs during his re-election campaign last fall, cannot possibly satisfy them all. State revenues are running $2 billion behind expectation this fiscal year, and next year a gap of at least $8 billion is projected.
"This is going to be slash and burn," a senior Republican legislative aide predicted.
Mr. Pataki made repeated references in his speech to opposing new taxes and, in fact, he vowed to go ahead with $200 million in tax cuts scheduled to take effect this year. He also said he would call for new tax incentives to attract high-tech industry to the state.
Mr. Pataki's Republican allies cheered the notion. Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader, said Mr. Pataki deserved time to draw up his budget documents and defended him if anyone perceived a dearth of details.
His Democratic opponents, led by Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, said they were puzzled by the governor's lack of specifics. Meanwhile, they said, they are advocating their own plan, a mix of spending reductions, some borrowing and new revenues to spread the pain.
The state's Public Employees Federation, which represents 55,000 white-collar state employees, wants the state to avoid deep cuts in services and jobs by increasing revenues through a two-year surcharge of under 1 percent on the portion of a resident's income that exceeds $100,000. It also wants the governor to rethink any opposition to tax increases.
"Deep job cuts in the state work force will hurt both the public employees who are already understaffed and will hurt the citizens who are dependent on those services," said Denyce Duncan Lacy, a spokeswoman for the union.
Robert A. Kurtter, a senior vice president for state ratings at Moody's Investors Service, a Wall Street bond rating agency, said the cuts would likely fall in areas that account for the bulk of state spending: education, health care and corrections.
Beyond that, he said: "There are one-shots and gimmicks and the deficit bond that the governor has already proposed. And we haven't seen the budget proposal, so we don't know what combination it will be and how it will all work out. It will be painful and require legislators to make some very difficult decisions."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. George E. Pataki spoke in hopeful but only broad terms about New York's budget in his speech to the Legislature on Wednesday. (James Estrin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Bush Offers a Break if Companies Pay Taxes 

BYLINE:  By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
ONCE upon a time, the corporate income tax produced nearly a quarter of the federal government's revenue. Over the years it was whittled away. Rates came down and companies found a host of ways, some authorized by Congress and some involving clever ways around the law, to avoid the tax.
 By the boom of the late 1990's, corporate income tax receipts, whether measured as a percentage of government revenue or as a portion of the national economy, had declined by roughly half from their level in the 1960's boom. 
 But now, President Bush has proposed a plan that might lead to a revival of the corporate income tax. That may not have been his intent, but it could be one result of a move to help shareholders.
The Bush plan gives tax breaks to owners of companies that pay taxes. The easiest way to measure that break is to calculate that shareholders will be allowed to receive $1.86 in tax-exempt income -- either dividends or capital gains -- for every dollar of corporate income taxes actually paid. (In fact, the benefits would be less, for many shares are owned by tax-exempt charities or tax-deferred pension plans that would not be able to use the benefits.)
The Bush plan was advertised as ending the double taxation of corporate dividends. The plan accomplishes that by exempting from taxation only dividends that come from profits on which corporate taxes were actually paid. Other dividends would still be taxed, so owners of companies that pay no taxes get no break. Owners of companies that pay taxes but not dividends would be able to report lower capital gains, and save taxes that way.
If the Bush plan were enacted, it would suddenly be easy to see just how much companies are paying in federal income taxes, since shareholders would receive benefits based on the payments. (Figuring that out from corporate annual reports is now all but impossible, and few make the effort.) Companies that did manage to avoid paying taxes would not be able to hand out the new benefits to their shareholders, who would presumably resent that and perhaps wonder what good the tax savings had done them.
Conceivably, that might make companies less eager to pay Wall Street for clever strategies to duck taxes, since cutting corporate taxes would have a cost for shareholders. And in some future Congress, when lawmakers sought ways to raise revenue, it would be easier to see which companies were not paying their fair share of taxes.
For this to work, it needs to be loophole-free. The 1992 Treasury Department study on which Mr. Bush's plan is modeled allowed no exceptions: A company's shareholders could benefit only to the extent that the company paid federal income taxes. The new proposal also allows credit for foreign income taxes, which may be reasonable but should not become a precedent for more exceptions when Congress gets down to details.
One can easily envision the line of corporate supplicants. They will say that surely the low-income housing credit, or the credit for qualified electric vehicles, or something else, is so important that shareholders of companies that use that credit should not suffer. Companies that reduce their federal tax burden through generous granting of stock options will not want to have that fact reflected, and will lobby for changes. It will be interesting to see whether corporate America lines up behind this plan, which offers a lot more benefits for shareholders than it does for corporate managers.
One can argue whether or not the government can afford the cost, or how much economic stimulus will come from this plan. But enactment of the Bush proposal to end double taxation of corporate profits could have the surprising benefit of making it more likely that such profits would be taxed the first time.

HEADLINE: Bush Names Veteran Anti-Communist to Latin America Post 

BYLINE:  By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 

 BODY:
The White House announced today that President Bush will nominate Roger F. Noriega, the United States representative to the Organization of American States, to be assistant secretary of state for Western Hemisphere affairs, the most senior diplomat for Latin America.
 Mr. Noriega will replace Otto J. Reich, whose own nomination to be assistant secretary was blocked by Senate Democrats in 2001 and who served in the position under a temporary "recess appointment" that expired in November. 
 Though Mr. Reich's supporters had thought Mr. Bush would renominate him after the Republicans captured the Senate in November, their hopes were dashed when senior Republicans, including Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, the new chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, joined Democrats in opposing him.
His opponents argued that Mr. Reich, a staunchly anti-Communist Cuban exile, botched relations with Venezuela and had taken too hard a line on Cuba. Mr. Reich, these critics said, also did not have the support of Secretary of State Colin L. Powell. 
Ari Fleischer, the White House spokesman, acknowledged the bipartisan opposition to Mr. Reich today in explaining why Mr. Bush had decided to pull him into the National Security Council, a position that does not require Senate approval. 
"The principal reason was because the president wanted his expertise here," Mr. Fleischer told reporters. "I never ruled out that there could have been other factors as well, and it's always important to gauge the inclinations of the Senate."
Mr. Noriega's nomination comes at a time when South America is in turmoil and the Bush administration is under fire for paying too little attention to the region.
Venezuela is in the 39th day of a general strike against President Hugo Chavez that has halted oil production, driving up gas prices in the United States; Argentina's economy has been shrinking, weakening much of its middle class; and Colombia is racked by a bloody civil war that shows few signs of abating.
Against that backdrop, some analysts said they hoped that if Mr. Noriega could gain quick Senate approval, the Bush administration could mount a more aggressive initiative to stabilize the region.
But it was unclear whether Mr. Noriega could win quick approval. Aides to Senator Christopher Dodd, a Connecticut Democrat who led the opposition to Mr. Reich, called his nomination "disappointing."
Like Mr. Reich, Mr. Noriega served in the State Department during the Reagan administration, helping forge fiercely anti-Communist policies toward Latin America.
"There are a number of individuals with a great deal more stature and strong bipartisan support who could do this very important job," Mr. Dodd's spokesman said.

HEADLINE: The Right Tax Plan for Today and Tomorrow 

BYLINE:  By Lawrence B. Lindsey; Lawrence B. Lindsey was chief economic adviser to President Bush from 2001 to 2002.

DATELINE: CLIFTON, Va. 

 BODY:
President Bush has proposed a set of tax reforms that will give a quick lift to the economy and make for long-term improvements in our tax system. Critics argue that the plan is merely an effort by the president to exhibit concern about the economy (and to avoid the fate of his father). Such charges are baseless. The president's bold plan reflects the ideas that have long been central to his tax policy.
 In December 1999, Mr. Bush, then a candidate, called both for sharp reductions in tax rates and for taking 6 million working families off the tax rolls by doubling the per-child tax credit and cutting the bottom rate of income taxation by one-third. He made clear his reasoning, saying that the economy might well need an insurance policy in the near future. At the time, conventional wisdom held that we were entering an era of unparalleled growth and perpetually rising stock prices. Six weeks later the Dow Jones industrial average began its decline; the Nasdaq followed suit in March and fell by nearly 60 percent in a year. Manufacturing employment began a steep plunge. 
 After the election, Mr. Bush held a meeting in Austin, Tex., with business leaders, which reinforced his conviction that steps had to be taken immediately to help revive the economy. The critics said he was talking the economy down and that his proposals were overly stimulative. Yet he passed the plan in record time, and it has been crucial in pulling us out of a recession. 
Now the critics are repeating many of the arguments they made before: the new package is too large, it makes the wrong changes and it disproportionately benefits the wealthy. All are off the mark.
Consider the size of the proposal. It would inject about 1 percent of the gross domestic product -- around $100 billion -- into the economy this year and next. After that, it would be roughly one-third of 1 percent of the domestic product over the rest of the next decade. 
This is prudent. The latest forecasts from leading economists show an unusually large spread in growth projections -- they range from between 1.5 percent to 3.5 percent for 2003. Thus the president's insurance policy analogy again seems apt. If the pessimists turn out to be right, the plan's injection of 1 percent of gross domestic product will help ensure that overall economic growth will not slow much below the current 3 percent rate and that unemployment will not rise further. If the optimists turn out to be right, the additional 1 percent growth will not prove to be too much -- there is enough unemployment and spare production capacity that even 4.5 percent growth wouldn't overheat things.
The form, as well as the size, of the package reflects the needs of an economy working to repair the financial wreckage of the 90's, when an irrationally exuberant stock market resulted in lower private savings and higher corporate debt. Repairing that damage will require sufficient growth in household incomes to allow families to continue their current spending habits and yet restore their bank balances. It will also require reforms to lay a more solid financial footing for long-term economic growth. The Bush proposal does all these things.
The tax cuts in lower brackets, the reduction of the marriage penalty, the changes in the alternative minimum tax and the $400 increase in the per-child tax credit comprise two-thirds of the package over the next two years. When combined with the aid to be given to small businesses and the unemployed, and the benefits to middle- and upper-middle-class Americans from changes in the way stock dividends are taxed, an additional $80 billion is likely to go to consumers in each of the next two years.
Second, ending the double taxation of dividends is crucial to long-term economic expansion. When one combines the current 35 percent corporate rate with the top personal rate of 38.6 percent on stock dividends, the government can take 60 cents out of each dollar that a company earns and pays in dividends.
When taxes are excessive, people avoid them. Companies rely more on taking out loans and issuing bonds than on selling stock. This creates a more volatile base for our economy because companies' debt in relation to equity gets skewed. Firms also choose to reward shareholders by driving up share prices rather than by paying dividends. This puts increased emphasis on reported earnings and less on cash payouts -- and we know what sort of accounting tricks this can lead to. Some of us may remember the old saying, "Cash is a fact, earnings are an opinion." Sadly, the bursting of the bubble of the 90's taught that lesson to a new generation of shareholders.
The final criticism of the president's plan is that it disproportionately favors the wealthiest Americans. Wrong. The tax cut is almost exactly proportional to taxes paid. Under current law, families making more than $200,000, who pay 45 percent of the income tax under current law, will get 40 percent of the tax cut. Families making less than $100,000 will pay 28 percent of the income tax this year and will get 34 percent of the tax cut. Not only that, Mr. Bush's plan would provide bigger tax cuts for middle-income families than the Democrats' alternative would.
President Bush is proposing the right amount of support for economic growth in the near term and the right kind of reform to promote long-term expansion. He is doing it in a way that cuts taxes proportionately for all income groups. Once again, the president is proposing a plan that is right on target.

HEADLINE: New Police Crackdown Takes Aim at 61 City Neighborhoods 

BYLINE:  By LYDIA POLGREEN

 BODY:
The Police Department will flood crime-ridden neighborhoods, subway stops and housing projects with 1,400 police officers fresh from the Police Academy later this month, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday. 
 The new program, called Operation Impact, aims to keep violent crime at the lowest rate in a generation and fight persistent problems in some neighborhoods, Mr. Bloomberg said. 
 "Operation Impact will strategically monitor and combat crime in areas that have not equally shared in New York City's decline in crime," Mr. Bloomberg said, speaking at the 77th Precinct in Crown Heights, one of the neighborhoods that will receive additional patrols.
The program is the second major crime initiative Mr. Bloomberg has proposed; last year he put in place Operation Clean Sweep to crack down on crimes like panhandling and prostitution. 
Though he noted that crime rates in New York City remained low -- bucking a trend of growing violent crime in large cities -- Mr. Bloomberg's comments were an acknowledgment of the difficulties the city may face with a struggling economy and as the police force shrinks because of budget constraints. 
While crime in the city is down over all -- there were fewer than 600 murders last year, the fewest since 1963 -- problems persist.
In the 77th Precinct, one example that Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly cited, homicides were down 22 percent over the last two years, but shootings were up 41 percent. "The goal is to drive down crime by saturating the target areas with officers and suppressing violent crime," he said. 
The first phase of the program began last Friday, when 800 officers on overtime shifts were sent to 61 places across the city. Later this month, when the current Police Academy class of about 2,100 graduates, 1,400 of them will be sent to patrol such areas. 
The new officers will be highly visible: most will be on old-fashioned foot patrols, the police said, and will work with more experienced officers and detectives in the narcotics, vice, warrants and other specialized units. 
The 61 areas were chosen based on police crime statistics and consultations with community leaders. And those areas paint a more nuanced picture of crime in the city than the one usually drawn by city officials. Between West 30th Street and West 52nd Street and Seventh and Eighth Avenues in Midtown, for example, street robberies and burglaries are a problem, even though crime over all is down, Mr. Kelly said. 
In several housing projects in Brooklyn and the Bronx, shootings and robberies are on the rise, Mr. Kelly said, even as homicide rates have decreased. 
Tracy L. Boyland, a City Council member who represents Brownsville, Brooklyn, said she would be glad to see more officers in her neighborhood. 
"I think the presence of police officers is always a deterrent to crime," she said. "I am glad Commissioner Kelly is addressing this early on."

HEADLINE: The Iraq Dossier 

 BODY:
International arms inspectors told the Security Council yesterday that they had not yet found any "smoking gun" proving Saddam Hussein's continued manufacture of unconventional weapons. That increases pressure on the Bush administration to share more of what it knows about the state of Iraq's biological, chemical, nuclear and missile programs. Less than three weeks remain until Jan. 27, when the inspectors are to provide a more comprehensive report. If Washington hopes to persuade the world and the American people that Baghdad has forfeited its chance for a peaceful solution, it will need compelling evidence to support its case. 
 It is probably unrealistic to expect revealing photographs of weapons production lines. In an era of satellite surveillance, countries with something to hide long ago learned how to conceal their secrets from aerial cameras. Using other forms of intelligence, however, the United States claims to have assembled a persuasive case. Also in recent days, America has been providing more intelligence help to the weapons inspectors, a process that should accelerate now that the U.N. has the resources on the ground to put those tips to immediate use before Baghdad can spirit away incriminating evidence. 
 Successive U.N. resolutions place the burden of proof on Iraq, not Washington or the arms inspectors, to demonstrate that all unconventional weapons programs have been terminated and that known or unaccounted-for stocks of biological and chemical warfare ingredients have been verifiably destroyed. The 12,000-page declaration Iraq submitted last month conspicuously failed this test. It offered no adequate explanation of what happened to more than 500 artillery shells containing nerve gas and 400 bombs suitable for delivering germs and toxins. It didn't credibly account for more than two tons of material used to produce biological weapons. It failed to mention new efforts to acquire uranium and raised more questions than it answered about preparatory work on unmanned drones and longer-range missiles. Since handing over that report, Iraq has not provided satisfactory answers for these omissions, implausibly contending that relevant records and materials are simply missing.
These evasions have not satisfied Hans Blix, the U.N.'s chief weapons inspector, who has complained that while Iraq has not directly interfered with his inspectors, it has failed to provide the active cooperation required to complete their mission. In a country as large and tightly controlled as Iraq, the inspectors will never be able to assure themselves without active help from the government that deadly illegal weapons ingredients aren't hidden somewhere.
Yet for all the Iraqi maneuvering, America cannot simply declare Baghdad to be in violation of U.N. requirements and then go immediately to war. The political, economic and military implications of combat -- not to mention the potential loss of American and Iraqi lives -- demand every effort by the United States to resolve this confrontation short of war. That may involve extending the period for inspections, and certainly requires Washington to return to the Security Council for further deliberation before turning to the use of force. The presence of tens of thousands of American troops in the region and the return of uncomfortably hot weather in the spring are not reasons to start fighting before every diplomatic option has been exhausted. 
There can be no wavering from the goal of disarming Iraq, but all chances of doing so peacefully should be explored before the world is asked to decide on war. Before that point is reached, Washington should share its evidence with the public.

HEADLINE: U.S. Threatens to Act Against Europeans Over Modified Foods 

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH BECKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 

 BODY:
The Bush administration's top trade official announced today that he was weighing whether to approach the World Trade Organization with a case against the European Union for its ban on genetically modified food, asserting that the "Luddite" and "immoral" European position was leading to starvation in the developing world.
 The official, Robert B. Zoellick, the United States trade representative, said that when famine-threatened African nations refused American genetically modified food last year, they were acting under the influence of the European position. 
 "The European antiscientific policies are spreading to other corners of the world," Mr. Zoellick told reporters, adding that African leaders seeking to avoid "the food that you and I eat" were letting their people starve. 
"I think that is a rather serious development," Mr. Zoellick said, in the strongest statement yet made on the subject by an administration official. "I find it immoral that people are not being able to be supplied food to live in Africa because people have invented dangers about biotechnology. That puts it rather high on my scale to deal with."
European officials rejected Mr. Zoellick's assertions, saying they had never encouraged African nations to reject aid.
Moreover, Pascal Lamy, the European Commission's chief trade negotiator, said today that if Mr. Zoellick did approach the trade organization with such a case, it would only complicate Europe's plan for lifting its ban against the foods, which is expected to occur in the spring.
When that happens, products tested and deemed safe will be allowed into European markets -- with labels identifying them as genetically modified. The United States does not require such labeling.
Tony Van der haegen, the expert for food safety at the European Union delegation in Washington, noted that "in a democracy you have to take into account fears of the people, and the people in many European countries are concerned about genetically modified food."
European consumers have for years questioned the safety of genetically modified foods. Many object to what they consider aggressive American promotion of those foods, which is seen as influenced by American agribusiness.
British newspapers have coined the term "Frankenfoods," reflecting the deep suspicion of crops like corn and soybeans, when genetically modified to increase productivity and improve resistance to disease. Such modifications, many fear, may have unintended consequences for human health.
American consumers, though already exposed to modified foods, have expressed uncertainties about them; several state legislatures have discussed bans of their own.
If all goes as planned with the lifting of the European ban, the effect on world trade will be measured in the billions of dollars as American biotechnology is exported to new markets.
Last August, the argument over biotechnology caused an aid crisis in Zambia, which rejected genetically modified corn from the United States despite widespread hunger. What had been a trade and consumer issue became a matter of life or death.
Mr. Van der haegen asserted that Mr. Zoellick's statement today was made for the benefit of African leaders whom he will meet next week at a trade conference.
"Ambassador Zoellick was a bit unfair to whip Europeans when we did not block the food aid," he said.
The administration is expected to decide whether to bring a case before the World Trade Organization by the end of the month.
"We're reviewing our options to determine how to best resolve this issue," said Claire Buchan, a White House spokeswoman.

HEADLINE: Senate Passes Temporary Financing Measure for Agencies 

BYLINE:  By CARL HULSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 

 BODY:
The Senate approved a measure today to keep federal agencies operating through the end of the month, allowing the new Congress time to work through a spending impasse that could present an early test for the narrow Republican majority in the Senate.
 After the House passed the stop-gap bill on Wednesday and left town until later this month, senators by a voice vote adopted an identical temporary financing resolution. It will be a substitute for 11 spending measures Congress failed to approve last session. Republicans intend to combine those measures into one bill for a vote in the coming days. 
 Senate Democrats said they were willing to let the interim bill pass without debate but promised a fight over more than $9 billion in spending reductions that Senate Republican leaders have accepted in talks with the House and White House.
"We will voice as strongly as we can our opposition to these cuts and our determination to find a way to address them," said Senator Tom Daschle, the Democratic leader.
Other lawmakers and top Senate Democratic aides promised to contest elements of what will be a huge bill to finance federal agencies that include the Agriculture Department, the F.B.I. and the National Institutes of Health.
"Once people start looking at this bill and see what policies will flow from it, there will be strong objections," predicted Scott Lilly, Democratic staff director of the House Appropriations Committee. 
He cited as examples provisions that would reverse budget increases for education programs and cut into $1.2 billion that Amtrak officials have said they need to maintain operations. 
Republicans would like to get the final spending measure -- totaling $385 billion -- approved in time for President Bush's State of the Union address on Jan. 28. But their push is being slowed by the failure of the Senate leadership to reach an agreement on committee membership and financing. 
Without that deal, Senate Democrats still run the panels. For instance, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut, said today that he would lead a confirmation hearing next week on the nomination of Tom Ridge as the secretary of homeland security.
The fact that Democrats still control the panels is preventing the Republicans from taking up the spending measure at the committee level. A meeting of the Appropriations Committee planned for Friday was postponed today when it became clear the organizing negotiations would not be concluded.
Senate Republicans say they want to move quickly on the spending because it includes billions of dollars that could aid the economy and help the unemployed. "As one that has just come back from my home in Alaska, we have the highest unemployment I've seen," said Senator Ted Stevens, who is in line to become chairman of the Appropriations Committee. He called the spending bills "vital to really start this engine again, our economic engine."
Mr. Stevens said he was open to working with Democrats to try to resolve problems with the spending bill. But Republican aides said they anticipated Democratic "mischief" with the spending measure. In addition, some Republicans will want to add money for farmers hurt by drought after a relief plan died last year, as well as wildfire protection.
The spending stalemate arose last fall because of differences among the Senate, the House and the White House about total spending levels. President Bush insisted on a ceiling of about $750 billion while the Senate, then controlled by the Democrats, sought roughly $10 billion more. The House Republican leadership sided with the president, but stopped bringing bills to the floor, partly due to a fight between conservative and moderate Republicans concerning how much to devote to health and education programs. Just two spending measures covering military appropriations were enacted.
Since the election, Republicans have agreed to Mr. Bush's numbers. Mr. Stevens said this week that more than $9 billion had been pared from the Senate version of the bills. Aides said the areas facing the largest reductions were labor and health, which would be cut by almost $3 billion, and the bill financing the Commerce, State and Justice Departments, which would drop by about $2 billion.
Democrats say they have not seen the details of the new spending plans, but are already arguing that domestic security efforts are being shortchanged. "We expect there are going to be cuts in homeland security across the board," said a spokesman for Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, the senior Democrat on the Appropriations Committee. He cited a reduction of $670 million for the Immigration and Naturalization Service and said the proposed bill provided no money for an election overhaul measure passed last year.
In the House, rules give the Republican leadership much more leverage to push through the spending plan. Democrats complained this week that they were being denied the chance to propose changes, but Republicans dismissed the objections.
"I understand the minority is upset," said Representative C. W. Bill Young of Florida, chairman of the House Appropriations Committee. "They are upset because they are the minority, and I know about that. I served under in this House for 24 years under their rule."

HEADLINE: New Chief for Budget Office 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 

 BODY:
House Republican leaders decided today to recommend Douglas J. Holtz-Eakin, a senior economic adviser to President Bush, as the next director of the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office.
 The decision drew praise from supply-side economists but criticism from Democratic lawmakers, because both groups believe that Mr. Holtz-Eakin would support a disputed method of evaluating the cost of tax proposals. 
 In the method, known as "dynamic scoring," analysts try to estimate the cost of a tax change by predicting its impact on economic growth, rather than just calculating how much revenue would be lost or gained. Republicans have long lobbied Congressional analysts to use the method, contending it more accurately measures the budgetary impact of tax cuts. The method also offers the political benefit of reducing the size of projected deficits. 
The budget office plays an important role in estimating the government's long-range fiscal health, and, in that capacity, its top officials have adamantly opposed the use of dynamic scoring. 
Mr. Holtz-Eakin, a professor of public finance on leave from Syracuse University, is chief economist to the White House's Council of Economic Advisers, which used the method to help make the case for President Bush's $674 billion tax-cut proposal.
The council estimated that the plan would cost the treasury $359 billion in the first five years using conventional analysis. Under dynamic scoring, the council forecast that added growth would cut the real cost to $166 billion.
William Beach, a champion of dynamic scoring at the Heritage Foundation, a research group here, said Mr. Holtz-Eakin had not spoken publicly about the method but predicted he would support its use. He called the nomination "a profound choice" and said Mr. Holtz-Eakin had done a lot of work on the macro-economic effects of tax changes."
Senator Kent Conrad of North Dakota, the senior Democrat on the Senate Budget Committee, expressed dismay. "Dynamic scoring could lead Congress down a fiscally irresponsible path where the true cost of tax cuts and spending legislation are significantly underestimated," he said.
The job became open last week, when Dan L. Crippen's term expired and Republican leaders expressed no interest in reappointing him. Mr. Crippen, a Republican, resisted dynamic scoring.

HEADLINE: Bush Says His Tax Proposal Will Be Fair for All Incomes 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON and SHERYL GAY STOLBERG 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 

 BODY:
President Bush promoted his tax cut proposal today as fair to all Americans and accused opponents of the package of engaging in class warfare. 
 Seeking to counter criticism from Democrats that the $674 billion, 10- year economic plan is unfairly skewed to the wealthy, Mr. Bush traveled to a small flag company in Virginia to argue that his plan would slash the federal income tax bill for many middle-class families, and to suggest that his political opponents were trying to split the country along economic lines. 
 "You hear a lot of talk in Washington, of course, that this benefits so-and-so or this benefits this, the kind of the class warfare of politics," Mr. Bush said. "Let me just give you the facts, that under this plan a family of four with an income of $40,000 will receive a 96 percent reduction in federal income taxes." 
But Democrats said Mr. Bush was only attacking them because he could not get around the reality that the overwhelming majority of the tax benefits would go to the richest people in the country. They said that if anyone was waging class warfare, it was Mr. Bush, against low- and middle-income people.
"It's an old and tired complaint, and it completely disregards the fact that the Democratic Party has always wanted all Americans to move forward together," said Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, who has said he will be a candidate for the Democratic presidential nomination. "I also believe the president's economic policies are class warfare against all classes."
With even some Republicans saying that Mr. Bush would have to compromise to get a plan through Congress, Democrats broadened their critique today, saying that the president's proposal does not offer any substantial financial assistance to cash-strapped states and could force states to raise taxes, cut services or both.
Because state income taxes are typically tied to federal income taxes, states will almost certainly lose revenue under the White House plan, lawmakers said. The plan could also make it more expensive for states and municipalities to issue their own bonds. The White House considered including assistance to states, reportedly as much as $10 billion, but the provision was cut.
"If you look at this economic stimulus plan, it's actually a tax hike," said Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York. He added, "It's robbing Peter to pay Paul."
Not long after Mr. Schumer spoke, at a news conference with other Democrats, another string of Democrats took to the Senate floor to criticize Mr. Bush's plan. 
Saying her state could lose up to $1.1 billion under the Bush plan, Senator Barbara Boxer, a California Democrat, said, "It's taking a nightmare problem that we already have with our states and making it even worse, more chilling."
Republicans rallied around the President even as they acknowledged the plan is likely to be altered.
"Will it pass the Senate intact?" asked Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison, Republican of Texas. "Probably not. Nothing ever does." But, she added, "I certainly think what the president is proposing is exactly right."
Although the White House expressed confidence that Mr. Bush's plan would win Congressional approval, there were indications that the Senate Republican leadership would have difficulty finding the votes it needed from within party ranks. Senator Lincoln Chafee of Rhode Island, one of only two Republicans who voted against Mr. Bush's 2001 tax cut, came out in opposition to the new plan today.
Mr. Chafee joined with Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California, to call for a freeze on the planned tax cuts for Americans in the top income bracket, which under Mr. Bush's plan would drop this year to 35 percent from 38.6 percent. The proposal would save $88 billion, the senators said. 
But White House officials said the president would work hard to sell the proposal to voters and lawmakers. "All people who pay taxes should get tax relief," Mr. Bush said. "This is a fair plan. It's an important plan. And it's a plan that will help people find work, because it will help keep this economy growing."
In labeling criticism of his plan as class warfare, Mr. Bush struck an aggressive posture that Democrats said was intended to intimidate them. 
"It is class warfare, and they've declared it," Representative Charles B. Rangel of New York, the senior Democrat on the House Ways and Means Committee, said in an interview. "Here the president kicks the hell out of the poor and tells us we're guilty of class warfare."
In a memorandum he circulated to House Democrats this week, Mr. Rangel noted that class warfare was a phrase that "seems vaguely un-American," and he compared its use in the tax debate to the way people in the civil rights movement had once been called communist sympathizers. He urged Democrats "not to be intimidated." 
An analysis by the Tax Policy Center, a moderate-to-liberal research organization run by the Brookings Institution and the Urban Institute, found that Mr. Bush's plan would direct 28.3 percent of its benefits this year to the top 1 percent of earners, with incomes starting at $317,000, and 22 percent of its benefits to the bottom 80 percent of earners, those making less than about $68,000.
But Ari Fleischer, the White House spokesman, said it was wrong for Democrats to suggest that wealthy people should not get a tax cut simply because they were successful. "It's class warfare to say that there are wrong people in America and these wrong people are not deserving of tax relief," Mr. Fleischer said.
He also said the administration's plan would remove more lower income people from the federal income tax rolls entirely.
In his stop at the National Capital Flag Company in Alexandria, Va., Mr. Bush emphasized that his plan would create jobs and focused on the benefits to middle-income workers. Using the example of a married couple with two children and income of $40,000, he said his plan would reduce their federal income tax bill to $45 from $1,178, a savings of $1,133.
"Now that may not seem like a lot of money to some of the big shots," Mr. Bush said. "That's real significant money for this family."
At a discussion with employees of the flag company and other workers, Mr. Bush heard mostly strong support for his tax plan. But the president also heard a polite but blunt denunciation of the biggest element of his plan, the proposal to end the taxation of stock dividends, from Donald Lucas, a retired accountant who the White House said receives $3,000 to $4,000 a year in taxable dividend income.
"It's a good idea, but I've got to be honest with you, I don't think it's fair," Mr. Lucas said. "I think corporations should pay taxes on their profits and I should pay taxes on the dividends that come to me as income."
Mr. Bush replied, "That's the debate."

HEADLINE: Alternative Tax Looms Large Despite Plans For Other Cuts 

BYLINE:  By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
In outlining President Bush's big new tax cut plan this week, the White House promised that it would not make anyone worse off because of another tax that reduces or denies tax cuts to millions of middle- and upper-middle-income Americans. 
 But tax experts digging into the details of the plan said yesterday that the administration's plan actually provided for only minor and temporary relief from the tax, known as the alternative minimum tax. And those benefits will mainly go to those least affected by this separate tax originally intended to make sure that the rich cannot live tax free. 
 A major publisher of tax books for lawyers and accountants advised clients yesterday that the White House "proposal does not address the underlying problems that will continue to subject an increasingly larger number of taxpayers to the A.M.T." CCH, the publisher, also noted that even that minor relief from the alternative tax would last only through next year. 
Under the minimum tax system -- which operates in parallel to the normal tax code and applies to those who owe more under its provisions -- many deductions are denied, including those for children, the taxpayers themselves and for state and local taxes. At that point, taxes are calculated at rates of 26 to 35 percent.
Philip Schwindt, a CCH analyst, calculated yesterday that the alternative tax could start to hit one-child families with incomes as low as $71,000 by 2006 and that couples with similar incomes and two or more children would soon see their tax credits for child care and college education expenses either reduced or wiped out.
The Treasury Department's senior tax policy official, Pam Olson, said that the administration planed to propose a solution to the problem, but probably not until after Mr. Bush's first term had ended. The target date is the end of 2005, she said. "We are working on it," Ms. Olson said. "It is a hard issue."
Ms. Olson also said any concerns that the government might not be able to afford to relieve the middle class and upper middle class of the alternative tax was misplaced. "It is not an issue of whether we can afford a solution," she said, "but it is tied up in some fundamental fixes to the tax system, including the A.M.T."
If Mr. Bush's plan becomes law this year, the number of people paying the alternative minimum tax will rise by 9 percent, to 3.3 million, and the amount of tax paid will swell by 28 percent, to $18.5 billion, according to the Tax Policy Center in Washington, a joint project of the Brookings Institution and the Urban Institute, two centrist-to-liberal research organizations. Other groups estimated different figures, depending on how various complexities are interpreted, but they all agreed the burden of the minimum tax would continue to rise unless the law is changed.
Indeed, in a study done last fall, the policy center found that the revenue from the alternative tax is scheduled to rise so fast that it could cost as much as $951 billion over the next decade to return to the original intent of the law.
By 2010 a quarter of taxpayers -- about 36 million -- will be subject to the alternative minimum tax, several studies have found. It will cost taxpayers -- through 2010 -- $566 billion, one study showed.
In states where incomes and tax deductions tend to be higher, like New York, California and Illinois, Treasury figures show, nearly four of five taxpayers making $75,000 to $300,000 annually will be subject to the alternative tax by 2010 under current law. By moving up the tax rate cuts and making other changes, the president's new proposal would throw more middle-class taxpayers into the alternative tax sooner.
The House Joint Economic Committee warned in a May 2001 report that "if nothing is done to reform the A.M.T. it eventually will become the dominant type of income tax."
Rather than overhauling the alternative tax, President Bush this week focused on providing tax relief to investors and accelerating the schedule of tax cuts approved in 2001.
As for the alternative tax, the White House proposed only to increase the thresholds on deductions and exemptions that make the tax applicable. The plan calls for allowing married couples to take up to $57,000 in tax breaks before the alternative tax applies, up from $49,000 under current law. For single people, the threshold would rise by $4,000, to $39,750. The exemptions would fall back in 2005 to $45,000 for couples and $33,750 for singles.
The administration has consistently acknowledged that the alternative tax was never meant to apply to the middle class or upper middle class and that a solution is needed. 
Mark Weinberger, who was the administration's first chief tax policy official, said two years ago that "President Bush was elected on a promise to cut taxes, not to reform the alternative minimum tax." But he vowed that once the 2001 tax cuts were enacted, the administration would turn its attention to the middle- and upper-middle-class taxpayers affected by the alternative tax.
Paradoxically, the alternative minimum tax rarely applies today to those making more than $627,000. But because it has not been adjusted to reflect inflation or other economic changes it now applies to some single parents making as little as $32,000. It is the fastest-growing tax affecting those making $50,000 to $500,000 and the revenues it raised were critical to the financing of the 2001 tax cuts, which primarily benefited the top 1 percent of taxpayers, who on average make more than $1 million each.

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: NUCLEAR STANDOFF; 
NORTH KOREA SAYS IT IS WITHDRAWING FROM ARMS TREATY

BYLINE:  By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Friday, Jan. 10 

 BODY:
Stepping up pressure following an American offer to open talks, North Korea said today it was withdrawing from the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty. The announcement means that, in 90 days, North Korea will no longer be bound by the treaty.
 The statement, carried by its official news agency and monitored here, said North Korea had no intention of producing nuclear weapons and was acting in self-defense because it was "most seriously threatened" by the United States. 
 "Though we pull out of the N.P.T., we have no intention to produce nuclear weapons and our nuclear activities at this stage will be confined only to peaceful purposes such as the production of electricity," it said. 
There was no immediate response from the United States.
Even as the reports began to percolate of North Korea's declaration, two representatives of the country's permanent mission to the United Nations were meeting with an American official to discuss the confrontation with Washington over the North's nuclear program.
Han Song Ryol and Mun Jong Chol met in Santa Fe, N.M., on Thursday night local time with the New Mexico governor, Bill Richardson, a former American ambassador to the United Nations who has experience working with the North Koreans on sticky issues. Page A11. 
The Bush administration made clear that the meetings were unofficial. Mr. Richardson was only empowered to deliver the same message that the administration had said in public: that there would be no negotiations until North Korea halted its two nuclear projects.
North Korea has not responded to an offer made on Tuesday by Washington to hold discussions with the participation of South Korea and Japan. 
Instead of responding, North Korea's official radio station repeated the country's demand that Washington sign a nonaggression treaty as the price of an easing of tensions.
North Korea has repeatedly accused the United States of threatening to invade it and has said it reserves the right to develop nuclear arms in self-defense. It continues to insist it has no nuclear weapons at this stage.
It made a similar announcement of withdrawal from the treaty in 1993 when challenged about its suspected nuclear weapons program. That crisis was defused in 1994 when it agreed to halt its nuclear program in exchange for help in building a nuclear reactor for peaceful purposes, an agreement it has now repudiated.
Tensions have risen here since October, when the United States said North Korea admitted to pursuing a nuclear arms program in violation of the 1994 agreement. It then threatened to reactivate the nuclear facilities at Yongbyon that had been closed and monitored under the agreement.
Today's statement denounced the International Atomic Energy Agency, whose monitors North Korea expelled last week, as a tool of the United States. The agency has threatened to report North Korea's noncooperation to the United Nations Security Council.
"The I.A.E.A. is used as a tool for executing the United States hostile policy," it said, and therefore North Korea can no longer remain bound to the nonproliferation treaty, which it signed in 1985 and which it said caused "the dignity of our nation to be infringed upon."
The announcement of North Korea's break with the international treaty came the morning after North Korea agreed to hold cabinet-level talks with South Korea, the highest-level dialogue between the two since North Korea admitted last October that it was maintaining a secret nuclear weapons program.
North Korea proposed holding the talks on Jan. 21-24, the week after a high-ranking American envoy visits here. In the past, North Korea often balked at invitations for high-level talks, but the nation's new policy, as spelled out in a New Year's Day editorial, is to make joint action with South Korea a priority in an effort to drive a wedge between the South and the United States.
In Seoul, several moves were under way to repair ties with the United States. The relationship has been strained by widespread demonstrations calling for a more equal relationship with the United States.
The withdrawal of the 37,000 American troops here "could send foreign investors flooding out of the country in fear of instability, throw the economy into turmoil and give North Korea a chance for provocation," South Korea's Defense Ministry warned in a monthly newsletter, Defense News, which circulated here on Thursday. "North Korea tries to weaken the South Korea-U.S. alliance's capability of deterring war."
Public opinion polls here indicate that about 55 percent of South Koreans, a group that consists largely of older people, want the troops to stay. In an indication that South Korea's silent majority may be starting to stir, about 400 South Korean military veterans and housewives staged a pro-American rally on Wednesday, burning an image of the North Korean leader, Kim Jong Il, clinging to a missile.
Separately, the office of President Kim Dae Jung issued a statement on Thursday implicitly asking South Koreans to tone down the weekly vigils outside the American Embassy here. The statement said, "We need to calm excessive worries of the international community about the anti-U.S. atmosphere."
Conservatives criticize the government for addressing symptoms of anti-Americanism without addressing an underlying cause: a deep erosion among young people in the belief that American troops are needed in South Korea.
"Now is the time to sincerely consider whether or not to continue the weekend candlelit protests and risk our national security and healthy relations with the U.S. at this crucial time," The Korea Times newspaper, said on Thursday.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY 

 BODY:
 INTERNATIONAL A3-8

North Korea to Withdraw From Nuclear Treaty
Stepping up pressure after an American offer to open talks, North Korea said it was withdrawing from the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, an announcement that sets the clock for a formal withdrawal within 90 days. A1

HEADLINE: 2 Airline Executives Say Industry Needs More U.S. Aid 

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 

 BODY:
Two of the nation's biggest airlines told Congress today that they were searching their operations for cost cuts but still needed government help to pay for new security measures and to tackle their single largest expense: labor.
 The largest airlines lost about $9 billion last year, according to the Department of Transportation, as they struggled to adjust to fewer passengers and greater security challenges. Congress gave the industry $5 billion immediately after the terrorist attacks. 
 But executives from two large airlines testified today before the Senate Commerce, Science and Transportation Committee that the industry might need an additional $4 billion to help it through its financial crisis.
"We have the responsibility to right our own ship," said Richard H. Anderson, chief executive of Northwest Airlines, but "the reality is that there are significant security burdens," including the costs of installing stronger cockpit doors, as well as other costs that the airlines have incurred since the terrorist attacks. Stringent cuts and layoffs allowed Northwest to return to profitability in the third quarter, he said. 
Today's hearing was the first of several examining the problems of the industry and whether the federal government should extend additional financial assistance.
Some lawmakers, including Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican who is the new committee chairman, were reluctant to pledge any new money, even though they stressed that they wanted services to smaller cities to be maintained. 
Mr. McCain agreed with airline executives at the hearing that the industry's troubles were deeper than those of previous downturns and that structural changes were needed in an industry that is effectively two-tiered, including the bigger carriers and the smaller discount carriers. 
Mr. McCain is considering whether to reintroduce legislation that would set up an arbitration panel to quickly and definitively resolve airline labor disputes. His proposal would speed up the current process, which allows for lengthy mediation and the possibility of strikes.
Mr. McCain's proposal would allow arbitrators to consider a carrier's financial condition, including a "reasonable profit," before making a decision after 30 days.
The largest airlines want to see the legislation revived because they say the current process has led to an unsustainable level of wages and benefits. They have formed an organization to help shape a grass-roots campaign to win support for rewriting the airlines' labor rules. 
Mr. McCain's bill was not passed last year, but, if it was reintroduced, it could receive a more favorable response now that the Republicans control Congress. 
Donald J. Carty, chief executive of American Airlines, a unit of the AMR Corporation, said that revising the airline labor law "would not help us through the current crisis." But he called it a long-term tool to assist the airlines "once we get healthy, to keep healthy."
Duane Woerth, president of the Air Line Pilots Association, which represents 66,000 pilots, told the committee that binding arbitration was unnecessary because there had been few strikes in the airline industry.
Compulsory arbitration "would remove all collective bargaining rights," he maintained. 
"The current system produces contracts about 99 percent of the time, so we only have a strike every 10 years," Mr. Woerth said. Airlines favoring such arbitration maintain that the true figure is much higher: about 160 strikes in the last 50 years.
Mr. Carty also said his airline would begin to re-examine its labor contracts, a process he hoped to start within 60 days.
"It won't be easy because it involves changes, and changes our employees won't necessarily embrace," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Richard H. Anderson, left, the chief executive of Northwest Airlines, spoke with Duane Woerth, president of the Air Line Pilots Association, before testifying yesterday at a Senate hearing on the airline industry.(Doug Mills/The New York Times)
