HEADLINE: State Pushes Suffolk to Build More Cells 

BYLINE:  By JULIA C. MEAD

 BODY:
SUFFOLK jails have been overcrowded for decades, and now the state is pushing the county to add 1,200 more beds by 2007. But the county's budget woes could render such an expensive project politically unpopular unless, perhaps, the alternative was worse.
 Sheriff Alfred C. Tisch said that if Suffolk did not commit to building the more jail space by next month, hundreds of inmates could be transferred to less crowded jails upstate. And in the long run, he said, that could cost more than a new jail. 
 Oneida and Onondaga Counties have agreed to take Suffolk's overflow, but Sheriff Tisch estimated that housing 400 inmates upstate could cost as much as $20 million a year. "I don't think the Legislature wants to answer to the taxpayers for wasting that kind of money," he said. "I don't think it wants to answer for delays in court cases or for inmates' families having no visitation." 
To help stem the overcrowding, the sheriff is proposing building an 850-cell, $106 million jail, which would bring the total number of jail beds to 1,976. That figure does not include 120 beds that are being planned in Yaphank. 
County Executive Robert Gaffney said: "Clearly something needs to be done. The sheriff and I both understand a long-term solution would be more cost-effective." 
Though the county's current fiscal climate "is not the best time to be doing it," Mr. Gaffney said his 2004 capital budget would be sent to the County Legislature with "most, if not all of the sheriff's requests." He and the sheriff are Republicans.
But David Bishop, a Democratic legislator from Lindenhurst, scoffed at a $106 million jail. "That's more than the county's entire capital budget," he said. "You can undertake a capital plan in bad economic times, but the one thing Suffolk can crow about is that we have our debt level under control. A big borrowing could blow that."
"I don't dispute we're overcrowded, but the solution may not rest in building more jails," said Mr. Bishop, a member of the Legislature's public-safety committee. "We won't know what we need until we study the issue."
Last month, in response to a warning from the New York State Commission of Corrections, the County Legislature approved $1.1 million in planning and design costs that will lead to 120 additional beds at the existing county jail in Yaphank. That project is expected to total $38 million. The Legislature also appropriated $150,000 to complete a survey of jail needs. 
On Dec. 11, the state commission's staff members told the public-safety committee that the time for studies had passed. Variances permitting the jails to house more inmates than they were designed to hold expire next month. James Lawrence, the commission's operations director, said the variances would not be extended unless the county commits to expanding its jails. 
Mr. Gaffney is taking the commission at its word. "I don't think they were fooling around," he said. 
According to a transcript of the Dec. 11 meeting, Mr. Lawrence said that the county must "literally address the problem" rather than making "a gesture" at reducing overcrowding. He said the 120 additional beds at Yaphank would be "a good first step," but "the bottom line is that you need 1,200" more beds by 2007.
The Yaphank jail, completed in 1961, was designed for 504 inmates but now houses about 588. Space for 280 new beds is to be built there, but in the expansion, 160 beds will be eliminated, so the net increase will be only 120 beds. 
The other county jail, which is in Riverhead, was built in 1969 and expanded in 1988. It is designed for 760 inmates but more than 1,100 are housed there.
Suffolk's jail population has exceeded its capacity of 1,112 inmates every day since at least 1980, the Sheriff's Department said. Variances raise the legal maximum to 1,712, but that means that two inmates must bunk in an 8-by-6-foot cell designed for one. Other inmates sleep in day rooms or in the gym in Riverhead. Variances are intended to address temporary space shortages, but Suffolk has had a succession of them since 1995.
Angie Carpenter, a Republican legislator from West Islip and the chairwoman of the public-safety committee, disagreed with the state. She contends that taking the preliminary steps to build 280 new cells and appropriating money for the study of jail needs ought to qualify the county for an extension.
"I think it demonstrated a good-faith effort, but we'll find out," she said. The state commission plans to discuss the matter on Feb. 4.
Ms. Carpenter and Mr. Bishop said the study would identify ways to reduce the jail population, including alternative sentencing programs. But Suffolk already has one of the best alternative sentencing programs in the state and has "probably maxed out the capability," Mr. Lawrence said last month.
He said the commission had pushed for the construction of many of the 16 new jails now being erected in the state. Overcrowding forces 15 jails to board inmates elsewhere.
Mr. Bishop said that any suggestion that Suffolk might have to do the same was "rhetoric designed to obfuscate the fundamental issue: the need to first look at the system in its entirely."
Jeffrey Tavel, the president of the Suffolk County Criminal Bar Association, said that having inmates housed upstate would be unworkable. "That would be a horrible situation," he said. "Defense attorneys can't go all the way upstate to meet with their clients. It would wreak havoc on the court schedule. And no family visits would be devastating."
If approved, the new jail would likely be built in Yaphank, which is fast becoming a hub for law enforcement. The county owns land near the police headquarters there, and a training center for fire and other emergency services volunteers was recently completed.
A renovated kitchen at the Yaphank jail will be able to turn out 1,000 meals and could easily serve a larger jail, Sheriff Tisch said.
Mr. Gaffney said that as many as 40 percent of Suffolk's inmates "would probably be better off in psychiatric facilities," but since the state shut down three Long Island psychiatric hospitals in recent years, that left the jails with what he called "a hidden mandate."
"We're just going to have to bite the bullet," he said.

HEADLINE: Lifeboat Long Island 

BYLINE:  By JOHN RATHER

 BODY:
LONG ISLAND governments have plenty of emergency plans and protocols for dealing with disasters like hurricanes, toxic spills, explosions and fire. Emergency officials say these same plans would make for a swift response to a terrorist incident.
 Now, with New York City and more particularly Manhattan widely perceived as a terrorist target, Nassau and Suffolk are stepping over county lines to join in preparing for an unnatural disaster of longer duration: an attack on the city that cuts off geographic Long Island from the mainland, and not just for days, but for weeks. 
 The two county executives, Thomas R. Suozzi in Nassau and Robert J. Gaffney in Suffolk, said as long ago as last winter that they wanted a single, unified master plan for responding to a long-term emergency situation even as it more closely coordinates immediate emergency actions. Now work has begun. 
Quietly and without waiting longer for a requested but never-received $3 million in state financing, emergency officials in the two counties have set up five bicounty subcommittees to look into and eventually preside over all aspects of keeping Lifeboat Long Island afloat and provisioned in a protracted and regionally immobilizing emergency. Some of those emergencies could include bioterrorism or a nuclear attack in some form. 
The emergency plan will not delve into the massive cultural and social upheaval on a hunkered down Long Island, under siege and split off from the mainland. But it will try to assure continuity of vital services, including alternative forms of commuting and travel, to minimize economic disruption. 
"What we are developing is a survival plan for how we can function for two months cut off from the city, with no bridges and no tunnels," said Richard A. Rotanz, director of the newly created Nassau County Emergency Management Office.
Mr. Rotanz, a former deputy director in the New York City Office of Emergency Management who was involved in emergency response to the 2001 attack on the World Trade Center, and emergency officials in Suffolk agreed this would be no easy job.
If the bridges and tunnels are closed, the planners will need to inventory alternate ways for bringing in supplies, including airlift, ferry, barge and freighter, to the island, which is unable to feed or fuel itself. Warehouses for storage and distribution of emergency food and water, evacuation centers for displaced people, police-enforced curbs on all but essential motor vehicle travel, restricted gasoline sales and detailed measures for continuing vital services would all be within the plan's scope.
"Everything is under development now," said David H. Fischler, the commissioner of fire, rescue and emergency services for Suffolk County. "But this is a massive undertaking. It's not something that can be done in a day or a year."
Subcommittees for transportation, communications, utilities, medical facilities and stockpiling of food and other essentials will include representatives of private businesses and the local, state and federal governments. Final authority locally will rest with the two county executives.
As crucial as it will be to emergency management, as a security measure the finished plan will never be shown to the public. Emergency officials said that residents should prepare now by having battery-powered radios, flashlights and supplies of batteries, food and water, the same advice they give for preparing for a hurricane.
With the counties and the state financially strapped and the timing and amount of federal emergency preparedness aid in question, resources are limited.
"We are going to provide the best system we can with what we have," said Joseph C. Michaels, the assistant deputy Suffolk County executive for public safety.
Last month Suffolk activated a new $300,000 computer system using emergency management software that would keep all officials on the same page during a prolonged emergency. Forty computer stations are now set up in the county's emergency operations center in Yaphank. 
But the Nassau emergency management office has yet to install a similar system for lack of funds. Although the office recently moved from a decrepit emergency center in the basement of police headquarters in Garden City to a new and undisclosed location in Hicksville, the new office has been getting by on state and federal grants and currently has only eight staff members. "As the budget gets going we'll be a little more robust," Mr. Rotanz said.
The two counties will have to overcome a long history of apartness, and other impediments including weak links between police and volunteer firefighters and emergency workers. Mr. Fischler said they would also have to reach out to Queens and Brooklyn, which might have seats on the hypothetical lifeboat but which for a century have been on the other side of a political and social wall.
If all goes well, what would emerge late next year is a computer-based plan using emergency management software seamlessly linking Nassau and Suffolk, at least. Everything from inventories of food and medical supplies to emergency announcements advising the public would be part of the program.
While officials and agencies monitored events in real time on a computer system designed to stay up and running amid widespread power failures, residents would be asked to take shelter at home or wherever they could, turn on the television or listen to a battery-powered radio if power were out, and await official instructions. "We will direct them accordingly when the time comes," Mr. Fischler said.
Discussions with a number of emergency officials threw little light on how they would deal with public panic, spontaneous evacuations and large numbers of people fleeing the city for Long Island.
All of them said they were ready for whatever came. "I won't say we are totally prepared, but we have a working group that can make decisions," Mr. Michaels said.
But questions about the level of coordination and public education have arisen. "Long Island does not have a single plan to respond to an emergency," said Matthew T. Crosson, president of the Long Island Association, which supports the longer-term planning. "It is not clear that there will not be conflicts among the plans of various jurisdictions, and it is not clear that the population knows what to do in the event of an attack."
Mr. Rotanz agreed that public education was needed, but said it would come after organizational and emergency preparedness was complete. "Once we get our plans up and running we will have an outreach program," he said.
Mr. Fischler said it would be unwise to tell people where to go or what to do in advance of an attack. "To say do this or do that may be putting people in harm's way," he said. "That's why we won't identify shelters ahead of time: because every incident is fact-specific, and certain shelters may be too close to the incident."
The absence of information for the public extends to the state Office of Emergency Management, which would assist in an emergency. The office's Web site lists public awareness campaigns for hurricanes and other weather hazards, but not for nuclear releases or any terrorist-related hazard.
Asked why, Dennis Michalski, a spokesman for the emergency management office, replied: "That's a good question. I don't have an answer for that right now. We do have things in development." 
County health departments in Nassau and Suffolk have received federal financing through the state for bioterrorism preparedness and now face local costs and administrative responsibility for mass smallpox vaccinations ordered by President Bush.
The first phase, vaccinations for health care and some emergency workers, was to begin by later this month. A second phase for other emergency workers, police and firefighters would follow. The Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta will supply the vaccine.
David Ackman, the Nassau health commissioner, said his department received $1.25 million for bioterrorism preparedness and spent it for communications, equipment, software, training and staff. "It does not account for the expense of vaccinating thousands of people," Dr. Ackman said. He said he expected additional funds this year and in 2004. 
Dr. Ackman is also a co-chairman of the bicounty medical facilities subcommittee. "We are certainly better prepared than we were at this time last year," he said. "There is a sense of urgency and a great deal of effort going into making sure Nassau County can respond to any event."
Jeanne Alicandro, the director of emergency medical services for the Suffolk Health Department, said the county was completing plans for giving mass vaccinations if they became necessary. She said the county had a limited stockpile of antibiotics for anthrax, plague and other biological agents.
Dr. Alicandro said that the department, which is also represented on the medical facilities subcommittee, was investigating how to cope with major disruptions in the delivery of medicine and supplies. But she said the problem seemed solvable. "It would be hard to imagine no air and boat," she said.
Mr. Michalski said the state recently received a consultant's audit on the adequacy of state emergency response plans for nuclear plants in New York.
He said the audit, which was ordered by Governor Pataki last year, reviewed plans for communities around the Indian Point nuclear complex in Westchester County and also for Fishers Island, which is partly within the federally required 10-mile evacuation zone for the Millstone nuclear complex in Waterford, Conn. Fishers Island, part of the Town of Southold, is the only area within the federal zone that is part of New York, though the Star Foundation, an antinuclear group in East Hampton, has warned that a worst-case disaster at Millstone could make parts of Long Island uninhabitable.
Utilities and private companies advised by authorities that they are potential targets have increased security and made preparedness plans. Stephen M. Jones, chief executive officer of the Suffolk County Water Authority, Long Island's largest public water supplier, said the authority had spent about $2 million since September 2001 on new security.
He said the authority changed the locks on all pump station gates, put welded steel cages over the openings of ground-level storage tanks, upgraded computer security and issued new security identification badges to employees.
The authority also used a $65,000 federal grant to hire an engineering company to perform a vulnerability risk assessment. Mr. Jones said he expected its report within weeks.
Bert J. Cunningham, the spokesman for the Long Island Power Authority, said the authority had been "fairly close-mouthed about contingency plans" because of security considerations. "We have certainly been looking at and shaping plans for the possibility of terrorist incidents," he said.
He said LIPA also received alerts from federal, state and local authorities on possible threats. Last week, the power authority, Keyspan, emergency management officials from New York City, Nassau and Suffolk and representatives from the F.B.I. and the New York Air National Guard met to discuss terrorist threats and preparedness, Mr. Cunningham said.
Mr. Cunningham said the authority had increased ability to supply power during an emergency that cut off power imports because of small units installed at various locations on Long Island over the last two years to meet summer peak demand. The units added 450 megawatts of locally generated power.
He said the transmission system had also been outfitted with connections for small portable generators that could be trucked to Long Island in an emergency. If bridges and tunnels to Long Island were closed, he said, alternate delivery would be no problem.
"We would fly them into Gabreski Airport on military aircraft," he said, referring to the Suffolk County airport in Westhampton. "There are ways of dealing with this."
An increased role for passenger and vehicle ferries during a lengthy closing of bridges and tunnels off Long Island has become part of a waterborne transportation study by New York and Connecticut.
Alan Meyers, the lead consultant for the plan, said emergency ferry terminals could be quickly set up using barges supported by piles. "We need to ask how much we are capable of doing if you looked at every place you could have ferry service," Mr. Meyers said. "It's an important question now."

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Country Club, the Bronx; 
A Waterfront Enclave Within the City

BYLINE:  By CLAIRE WILSON 

 BODY:
DURING the five years that Joan Varela lived the green life in Putnam County, all she could think about was getting back to the Bronx. But the move back had one condition. 
 "I would only move back if we could go to Country Club," she said. "It is upscale, prestigious and immaculately maintained." 
 On Eastchester Bay opposite City Island, the neighborhood is rare within the city limits for its waterfront properties with private deep-water docks, beaches and nearby beach clubs that hum with life year-round. By night, the lights of the Throgs Neck Bridge twinkle in the distance like so many diamonds. 
It was a view of the bay from the kitchen and the back deck that immediately sold the Varelas on the 3,500-square-foot house, for which they paid $470,000 early in 2001 and which Mrs. Varela said would now sell in the $600,000 range. It has three bedrooms, two and a half baths and many amenities, but it is the setting on the water that she and her husband, Mike, a letter carrier for the Postal Service who also has a landscaping business, enjoy the most. 
"You smell the salt water at night and feel like you're on vacation," said Mrs. Varela who is the operations manager at the The Bronx Times, a weekly newspaper, as well as a part-time sales representative for a designer fragrance company. "When it storms, we sit out on the deck and watch." 
The Varelas' house is one of 11 modern Nantucket-gray homes that were built in a cluster called Country Club Estates at the water's edge some 15 years ago. The Varelas pay $140 a month for landscaping and outdoor maintenance services. While they have a view of the bay, they have no access to the water and they are ready to buy property with access as soon as something comes up. Being a Country Club resident should work to their advantage. Houses in the area are in such demand that they sometimes change hands within days among people who know each other, often without brokers. 
George Febles, a teacher of American history and economics and a track coach at Fordham Prep, bought his house -- a $350,000, three-bedroom, 1,800-square-foot colonial with Tudor accents -- through word of mouth, thanks to someone in Staten Island that he knew from high school track circles. The house has three bedrooms and one and a half baths. 
"Her father wanted to sell it to a young professional family, and he didn't want to go through a broker," said Mr. Febles, who has two children. "We thought it was crazy to buy the first thing we looked at, but it's great -- very quiet and near all the main highways." 
Country Club is a small enclave defined by Interstate 95 to the west, Spencer Drive to the north, Layton Avenue to the south and the waters of Eastchester Bay, according to Marcia Pavlica, president of the Country Club Civic Association. Some residents believe the neighborhood derives its name from the Westchester Country Club, currently in Rye, but in fact it is named for another club, the Country Club of Westchester, which stood on Eastchester Bay from 1881 until 1922.
Residents' livelihoods cover a wide range, including public officials, teachers, lawyers, engineers and small business owners. Those who commute to Manhattan can do so by local bus and subway or by express bus, run by a company that is involved in a dispute with the city but which has agreed to provide service until April. 
Waterfront properties like those along Country Club Road are the jewels in the crown in Country Club, whose overall cozy atmosphere is created by a whimsical mix of housing styles, from wooden saltboxes to brick or fieldstone colonials and Tudors to 50's-era Capes and ranches. Away from the water, most plots are small, usually 100 feet deep but sometimes only 30 feet wide. Adding to its charm, not every block has sidewalks and lawns along the tree-lined streets roll softly down to property lines defined by neat rows of Belgian blocks. Garages abound and on-street parking is plentiful. 
"It is not a cookie-cutter kind of community," Mrs. Pavlica said. "You'll find houses of all descriptions and sizes, giving it a very comfortable look."
NEW houses are being built on plots where older homes have been knocked down, and prices are going up across the board.
"We've seen the greatest increases in the past 24 months," according to Joseph Lemongelli, owner of Better Homes Realty and president of the Bronx Manhattan-North Association of Realtors. "Houses that sold for $250,000 have gone up by 30 percent or more." 
Prices on one-family detached homes start about $255,000 for a house that needs work and can go up to $475,000. Two-family houses start at $450,000, according to Phyllis Basilone, sales associate with Prudential Kafcos Realty. 
Houses on the waterfront are harder to price because there are few of them. Dorothy DeMarco, principal in Town and Country Homes & Properties, herself the owner of a spacious waterfront two-family with private dock and koi pond at the back, said that in five years she has sold two waterfront houses -- one for $515,000 and one for $545,000 -- that were knocked down and replaced with new structures. Mrs. DeMarco guesses a waterfront house might now sell for more than $700,000. "Where else do you have a two-family house on the water with a deep-water dock and city taxes?" she asked. 
Taxes in the area are deemed reasonable, especially compared with areas in Westchester or Long Island. "They're around $2,000 now, and that's as good as you can ask for," Mr. Febles said. 
As for rental properties, John Velez, a sales agent with New Directions Realty, said studios in a two-family house go for about $850 a month and one bedrooms for about $1,000, but $1,300 with a water view, while two-bedrooms without water views rent for $1,250 to $1,400. 
Young people who were raised in Country Club often want to stay there to raise their own families, largely because of the quality and variety of schools that serve the area. There are two public schools for children in kindergarten through fifth grade: Public School 71 on Roberts Avenue and Public School 14 on Bruckner Boulevard.
Of students at P.S. 71, 52.4 percent are reading at or above grade level and 49.8 percent are scoring at or above grade level in math. Fourth and fifth grade students there can participate in a special architecture workshop, where they make sketches and scale models two afternoons a week. Of P.S. 14 students, 63 percent are at or above grade level in reading and 61.9 percent in math. Last year the school started a popular after-school Video Club where students made an entire film, from writing the script through editing the finished product.
Intermediate School 192 Hollywood Avenue, for Grades 6, 7 and 8 has a magnet program, Mathematics Integrated Theme Academy, for students who are good in math and who enjoy a math-related approach to other subjects like social studies and literature. Of all students in the school, 30.7 percent are reading at or above grade level while 29.8 percent score at or above grade level in math.
Middle School 101 on Lafayette Avenue is a small five-year-old school with only 540 students in Grades 5 through 8, who are chosen by lottery from 20 elementary schools. The school is designed for advanced students, with 89.2 percent reading at or above grade level and 83.9 percent scoring at or above grade level in math. 
Herbert H. Lehman High School on East Tremont Avenue is so popular that it gets more than 6,000 applicants for the 100 places open annually for children outside its home area, according to Robert Leder, the principal, who has been at the school for 24 years.
On the SAT reasoning tests, Lehman students who graduated in June 2001, the most recent figures available, scored 437 on the verbal test and 447 on the math, compared with a statewide average that year of 495 in verbal and 505 in math. Of seniors graduating in 2001, 61 percent went on to four-year colleges and 36 percent to two-year colleges. 
Many children from Country Club, which has a high proportion of residents of Italian heritage, attend three parochial high schools. Preston High School in nearby Throgs Neck is a Roman Catholic girls-only school for Grades 9 through 12. Tuition there is $4,850 per student per year, and 100 percent of graduates go on to college. Admitting both boys and girls in Grades 9 to 12, Cardinal Spellman on Eastchester Road is another popular choice for college-bound students. Tuition and fees are $5,000 a year. 
SITTING on a bluff overlooking Eastchester Bay in Country Club, the co-ed Villa Maria Academy, another Catholic school, has been in the same location for more than 100 years. Tuition is $3,600 per student for Grades 1 through 8 and $3,000 for prekindergarten. St. Benedict's School, which is on Edison Avenue in Throgs Neck, charges $2,700 for students in the parish and $4,000 for students from outside the parish. It offers kindergarten through eighth grade and will resume its pre-K program in September after a one-year hiatus. Closer by is Our Lady of the Assumption on Parkview Avenue, where tuition varies from $2,350 per year per individual child in the parish to $4,500 for parish families with three or more children enrolled. 
There is no commercial area in Country Club, a feature that adds to the welcome quiet of the neighborhood. A number of family-owned Italian specialty stores and delicatessens like the popular Lizzie's Supermarket on Layton Avenue are sprinkled throughout the neighborhood, but for large chain supermarkets residents must make the 15-minute drive to the Bay Plaza shopping center or go farther afield to Westchester. Good restaurants, especially Italian ones, abound. For seafood lovers, City Island is just a few minutes away by car or boat, which can tie up at restaurant docks.
Waterfront beach clubs like the Manheim and the American Turner's Club in adjacent Eastchester Bay have been a staple of Country Club social life for decades, providing beach access, function rooms and in some cases pool and gym facilities.
The Bronx Zoo and the New York Botanical Garden are about three miles away, and lovers of the great outdoors can drive five minutes to nearby Pelham Bay Park, which at 2,764 acres is three times the size of Central Park. It offers tennis, horseback riding, the historic Bartow-Pell Mansion and Museum and the Thomas Pell Wildlife Sanctuary as well as nine miles of shoreline, including Orchard Beach. Greens fees at the two golf courses run $24 for 18 holes.
On summer evenings, the sprawling park is a magnet for Country Club residents who converge there for after-dinner strolls or to watch teams from different countries play soccer. "It's like our village green," Mrs. DeMarco said.

One of the oldest and most exclusive clubs in the country, it offered golf, tennis, shooting, yachting, swimming, sailing and skating and was one of the first places that polo was played on American shores. Members included New York society families like the Vanderbilts and the Knickerbockers, some of whom may have been present on Jan. 2, 1922, when the elegant clubhouse burned to the ground. According to an account in The New York Times, not even the best efforts of the ladies' bucket brigade could save the structure, built in 1888. The parcel was auctioned for development in the 1930's, about the time of the sale of the adjacent Spencer Estates, once owned by a magazine publisher, Lorillard Spencer, who died in 1912. HEADLINE: When the Rich Are Not So Different 

BYLINE:  By MARGE PERRY 

 BODY:
PORSCHES in the parking lot of the local food pantry? It may come to that.
 Last year, as unemployment in New Jersey reached a six-year high, hunger relief groups recorded a 17 percent increase statewide in the number of people seeking food assistance. Poor areas were hard hit, of course, but the big surprise is that the increase in some of the wealthiest areas was double that. 
 "In the last 14 months, we've seen a 30 to 40 percent increase in people seeking food assistance," said Bea O'Rourke, manager of the Center for Food Action, which is based in Mahwah and serves parts of Bergen and Passaic Counties.
Food pantries say upper-middle and middle-class families throughout New Jersey are facing a choice: pay either to keep a roof over their heads or to put food on the table. They cannot afford both. And the future looks even worse for some; although economists cite signs of economic recovery in New Jersey, they also warn that industries like the high-technology sector, which has already laid off so many workers, may continue to lag. 
In affluent Morris County, one man who spoke on condition of anonymity said that in 2001 he grossed $185,000 as a senior executive of a Fortune 500 company. His salary easily covered the mortgage and upkeep on his $500,000 home as well as the maintenance of two cars and his 13-year-old daughter's piano lessons, sports activities and tutoring. He donated regularly to the United Way, and several times a year his daughter took groceries to the local food bank.
The man, who lost his job in March, now visits the food bank himself. Twice a month he picks up groceries for his family.
"I've never taken assistance from anyone in 19 years of working," he said softly in a recent phone interview.
"People need to know this can happen," he continued. "I couldn't appreciate this until I went through it. When you make a six-digit salary, you can't imagine people like you in this situation. I would have thought people who use pantries are losers -- drug addicts, people who don't want to work."
His family is living on his wife's $20,000 annual salary and what is left of their savings after stock market losses. It is not enough money to keep their house, pay medical bills and buy groceries.
As others are discovering, although expenses like dance lessons, restaurant meals and vacations may be relatively easy to pare back, rent and mortgage payments are not. Housing expense remains a colossal monster to feed each month, but the alternative is homelessness.
In a strong economy, New Jersey's high housing costs force residents to spend much of their income on rent or mortgage payments, which leaves less money to sock away for a rainy day. When the economy takes a downturn, that rainy day comes as companies downsize or reduce medical benefits. As families put their limited funds into having a place to live, not enough money is left for food.
Record numbers of residents in wealthy areas now turn to pantries for help. In Morris County, for example, the Interfaith Food Pantry distributed 31,394 bags of food in 2002, far surpassing the 25,861 distributed in 2001 and the 18,101 in 2000. 
"We serve towns that are not usually considered towns in trouble," said Ms. O'Rourke of the Center for Food Action in Mahwah. "Our hunger is a silent hunger. Most of our clients are the working poor. Some lost a job and can't find another of equal pay. So maybe they take two lower-paying jobs and try to scale down. Meanwhile, they lose health benefits. But they have to keep a roof over their heads, and you can't really work in suburbia without a car."
It doesn't always take something as financially drastic as losing a job to send a family over the precipice and into the food pantry. One middle-class family was living fairly comfortably, even after the husband's health benefits had been decreased, until doctors told them that their son had leukemia. 
"The mother has to stop working to care for the child, and on top of that, she's now paying for gasoline to drive into the city, parking and meals when he spends the day at the hospital," Ms. O'Rourke said. "The family ended up at the pantry because after paying their mortgage and costs associated with their son's illness, they didn't have enough money left to feed their other three children."
The need for food assistance is not restricted by class, education, work ethic or income level.
Ms. O'Rourke described another new client, a family where the father was laid off two weeks ago: "Two kids and a mortgage of $1,100. They were living right on the edge before he lost his job, because the mother had been ill and couldn't work. He applied for unemployment, but that takes six weeks. The mother is now able to go back to work part time, as an adjunct professor, if she can even find a job."
The father and the mother, nearly desperate to work, cannot withstand the financial setback of even temporary unemployment.
Families who rent are no better off than those paying a mortgage. According to a study by Legal Services of New Jersey, to afford the statewide average rent of $980 for a two-bedroom apartment requires annual income of about $40,000. Though census data for 2000 showed that New Jersey had the highest median household income in the nation, $54,276, the flip side is that about 35 percent of households in the state earn less than $40,000.
"We're the first line of defense in a bad economy," said Meara Nigro, director of communications for Community FoodBank of New Jersey, the largest food bank in the state. She and others say the pantries are no longer used for only short-term crises; families in financial straits rely on them to free up enough money to pay for housing.
Rosemary Gilmartin, executive director of the Interfaith Food Pantry in Morris County, said, "We've become a supplemental feeding program."
The problem deepens because as the need for their programs increase, donations to pantries decrease.
Food pantries operate mostly on donations from food companies, private groups and individuals and surplus commodities from government organizations.
In a leaner economy, food companies tend to manage their inventories more closely to avoid overproduction. As a result, they give away fewer items that are nearing expiration dates. Such donations represented the single largest source of the 24 million pounds of food distributed by Community FoodBank of New Jersey in 2002. But the amount given by food companies, 8.3 million pounds, was down significantly from the 9.3 million pounds that they donated in 2000.
Donations from individuals also decreased.
"All of us are having trouble getting food and volunteers because of the economy," Ms. O'Rourke said. "People who used to give us $25 now give $10. And we have volunteers who have become clients."
Some programs to feed the hungry, however, are actually growing, despite the economy.
One such organization is Table-to-Table, which picks up cooked and highly perishable foods that would have been thrown out from restaurants, food manufacturers and wholesalers, country clubs and grocery stores and delivers it in refrigerated trucks to food assistance programs that have the capacity to store and serve it at safe temperatures.
"There's a tremendous amount of food out there," said Claire Insalata Poulos, president of Table-to-Table, a group that is based in Englewood Cliffs and is financed by corporate grants and private donations. "We haven't even scratched the surface."
The organization's three refrigerated trucks are constantly on the move five days a week, delivering food for less than 15 cents a meal. Ms. Insalata Poulos says recipient agencies supplement their usual items with what Table-to-Table brings them.
When a Table-to-Table truck pulled up recently at the loading dock of the A.&P. in Midland Park, the store manager, Joe Sidor, talked about the food he was about to hand over.
Looking at four shopping carts filled with frozen chickens (stamped with a sell-by date of that day), deli-counter sandwiches and salads, and an assortment of frozen foods, produce and store-baked pies, he said: "I love this program. All these years, it killed me to throw this stuff away. This is stuff I would eat at home if it were in my refrigerator, and we had to just throw it. It's great to know it's going to people who really need it."
An hour and a couple of pickups later, the truck delivered its haul to the Father English Food Pantry in Paterson. Barbara Gaschler, who as president of the Emergency Food Coalition of Passaic County has her office there, was especially happy to see fresh oranges among the delivered goods. "This is great," she said. "Kids will actually get fresh fruit."
Ms. Gaschler says she sees 100 to 110 families a day and refers them to 24 pantries in Passaic County. Many of them wait two hours for a screening interview and then an hour for one or two bags of food.
"It's hard enough for them to come here, take time off from work, maybe," she said, shaking her head. "They don't want to be here." 
Like those people, the man from Morris County who lost his executive position does not want to be using his local pantry. In a race against his dwindling resources, he has sent out more than 1,000 resumes. Until his savings and unemployment benefits run out, he says, he will keep looking and hoping for any kind of job, even an entry-level position. Meanwhile, with so much time to spare, he helps sort and stack groceries at the pantry that helps him.

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME; 
When Rents Exceed Legal Limits

BYLINE:  By JAY ROMANO 

 BODY:
IN the various interactions between tenants and landlords, few are as vexing as disputes over overcharges in rent-regulated apartments.
 The stakes, lawyers for both groups say, can be high. Landlords who overcharge tenants can be required to refund up to four years worth of overcharges -- often with a refund for the last two years of triple the amount of the actual overcharge. But tenants who do not file a complaint within two years of the first overcharge for apartments under rent control and four years for those under rent stabilization could lose the right to obtain any refund at all. 
 "This is a complaint-driven process," said Marcia Hirsch, general counsel for the state Division of Housing and Community Renewal, which handles rent overcharge complaints. "A tenant can file a complaint that basically says, 'I think I'm being overcharged,' and we will open a file." In fact, since July 1997, the division has accepted more than 8,500 overcharge complaints, Ms. Hirsch said. Because many cases are appealed, the agency does not maintain statistics on the outcomes of the cases, she added. 
Actually completing the complaint, however, is a bit more complicated. The complaint form (available from housing division offices and on the agency's Web site at www.dhcr.state.ny.us under "rent administration: forms") is a four-page document with 25 questions. And while the form poses some fairly predictable questions about the tenant, the building and the lease, it also requires the tenant to articulate why he believes he is being overcharged and to submit evidence. In addition, the tenant must record his rental payments month by month from the date of occupancy or for the past four years if rent-stabilized or two years if rent-controlled, whichever is shorter. The form also elicits whatever information the tenant may have about rent increases charged by the landlord.
"There are four common ways that landlords may increase rents," Ms. Hirsch said. The most common is the result of increases approved by the New York City Rent Guidelines Board (for rent-stabilized tenants) or by the Division of Housing and Community Renewal (for rent-controlled tenants.) For example, Ms. Hirsch said, for rent-stabilized renewal leases signed from Oct. 1, 1997, to Sept. 30, 2000, the board allowed increases of 2 percent for one-year leases and 4 percent for two-year leases. For leases signed from Oct. 1, 2000, and Sept. 30, 2002, increases of 4 percent and 6 percent were allowed.
Besides those increases, Ms. Hirsch said, landlords have also been able -- since June 15, 1997 -- to raise the legal rent for a vacant apartment by adding a "vacancy allowance." For new leases since that date, she said, landlords have been entitled to an 18 percent increase for a one-year lease and a 20 percent increase for a two-year lease. Under some circumstances, Ms. Hirsch said, additional vacancy increases may be allowed. For example, if the prior legal rent for an apartment was less than $300 a month, the landlord is entitled to an additional vacancy allowance of $100 a month.
Landlords may also legally increase rents, Ms. Hirsch said, are by passing along the costs of major capital improvements made throughout the building or to individual apartments. With a buildingwide improvement, she said, the landlord is typically entitled to a permanent per-room increase of one eighty-fourth of the cost of the improvement, with each tenant's increase being allocated based on how many rooms he has. With an individual apartment improvement, the landlord is entitled to permanently increase a unit's rent by one-fortieth of the cost of an improvement without going through the housing division. (When an individual apartment improvement is made to an occupied apartment, Ms. Hirsch said, the tenant must consent to the improvement in writing for the landlord to be entitled to an increase.)
Knowing the amount of allowable increases over a period of years, of course, is of little use unless the tenant has a starting point upon which to base his or her calculations. And that, lawyers say, is where the going gets a little rough.
David Ng, a Manhattan lawyer who frequently represents tenants, said that one way for a tenant to identify a reference point of the last legal rent is to ask the housing division for a list of recent rent registrations for that apartment filed by the landlord. Some landlords routinely provide this information directly to tenants. Having that list, Mr. Ng said, will provide the tenant with a point of reference from which he or she can determine the legal rent. 
But there is no guarantee that the landlord has registered the rent. Mr. Ng explained that while the law requires landlords to file registered rents annually, there is basically no penalty for failing to do so. As a result, it is conceivable that a tenant who rented an apartment in, say, January of 2000 could find that the landlord has not registered any rent for the apartment since January 1998. That could be a problem, Mr. Ng said, because of a change in the law that took effect on June 15, 1997.
That change, he said, established a "statute of limitations" for rent overcharge actions. A statute of limitations, Mr. Ng said, is a time frame within which a lawsuit -- or administrative complaint -- must be brought in order for the plaintiff to recover damages. For rent-stabilized tenants, he said, a complaint for a rent overcharge must be filed within four years of the date of the first alleged overcharge. For rent-controlled tenants, the time frame is two years. 
Under the 1997 change in the law, Mr. Ng said, the Division of Housing and Community Renewal will go back only four years to establish a starting point for determining the current allowable rent for a rent-stabilized apartment. So, for example, if a tenant rented an apartment on Feb. 1, 2000, and then filed an overcharge complaint on Jan. 31, 2003, the division will go back to the beginning of the tenancy to calculate the overcharge up to the present time. On the other hand, if a tenant rented an apartment for more than the legal rent on Feb. 1, 1999, but the tenant did not discover the overcharge or file a complaint until Feb. 2, 2003, and all increases since then have been legal, the tenant probably will not be able to recover anything. 
A tenant who is being overcharged and who does file within the period prescribed by the law, however, may be entitled to recover even more than the actual overcharge.
Sherwin Belkin, a Manhattan lawyer who represents landlords, said that when housing division determines there has been a "willful" overcharge, the agency has the power to order the landlord to reimburse the tenant for the amount of the overcharge -- for up to four years of overcharges in the case of a rent stabilized tenant and two years for a rent-controlled tenant -- and can order that the amount of the reimbursement for the last two years be tripled. The tenant then has the right to deduct up to 20 percent per month from the rent until the overcharge and any penalty are fully recovered. When the amount exceeds $1,000 or the tenant has moved from the apartment, he or she may opt to obtain a judgment from the landlord for the full amount.
Mr. Belkin said that while the two- or four-year limitation on overcharge complaints may seem harsh to tenants, the use of a statute of limitations is basically fair. "Under D.H.C.R.'s interpretation of the law, "the onus is completely on the landlord to prove the legality of the rent," he said. "And if the agency that there has been an overcharge, there is an automatic presumption that the overcharge was willful, so the landlord then has the additional burden of proving that it was not. It's a double whammy."
John Fisher, director of TenantNet, an Internet-based information service at www.tenant.net, said tenants who believe they are being overcharged should file a complaint with the housing division as soon as those suspicions are confirmed. "You need to get as much information as you can, as quickly as you can."
In addition, Mr. Fisher said, tenants should talk to other rent-regulated residents in the building to get some idea of other tenants' rents. 
"Don't be embarrassed," he said. "Even a small overcharge can add up to a lot of money."

HEADLINE: IN BUSINESS; 
When Cameras Roll, So Do Dollars

BYLINE:  By MAREK FUCHS 

DATELINE: CROSS RIVER 

 BODY:
AT Ward Pound Ridge Reservation here, no coyotes or wild turkeys can be spotted, but beneath the trees, on the fields and atop rocks, grips, gaffers, thick-neck wrestlers and baby-faced production assistants are running wild. Battle cries suddenly go up as opposing Revolutionary War armies, the red coats and the blue, charge at each other across an open field. They meet in the middle where, instead of bayoneting one another, the soldiers enter a wrestling ring for headlocks and body slams. Just how did it come to pass that King George's army and Minutemen are charging at each other in the middle of this reservation's 4,700 acres of wilderness. 
 Well, World Wrestling Entertainment was filming a television commercial for its Royal Rumble, a wrestling match that will be held on Jan. 19 at the Fleet Center in Boston and seen on a pay-per-view telecast. The Royal Rumble is one of World Wrestling Entertainment's biggest wrestling matches, said Greg Castronuovo, the company's vice president for marketing. 
 The location of the shoot was arranged with the help of Iris Stevens, who, as the director of the Westchester County Film Office, helps turn everything from county parks to local homes into places that can pass as MGM's backlot. If the land or buildings being used are owned by the county, Mrs. Stevens collects a fee on behalf of the county; if the property is owned by a municipality or a private citizen, Mrs. Stevens may act as liaison. Getting permission to film can cost hundreds of dollars on a downtown street to thousands for use of a private home.
Mrs. Stevens, who works out of a first-floor office in the county office building in White Plains, is a cross between a location scout and a real estate agent, and the reservation, she said, is currently her "poster child location." It is white-hot popular for all of the kinds of shoot that she helps arrange: commercials, films and still photography.
"We wanted something that looked like a majestic, northeast field that we could cheat as being something from 1775," said the Royal Rumble commercials codirector, Kevin Sullivan. "This isn't a set, it's nature. It's perfect."
The spots producer, Rich Krekian, said that because World Wrestling Entertainment is headquartered in Stamford, Conn., the company usually prefers to shoot in Connecticut. But location scouts were hired and Mrs. Stevens was called in. "And we looked at photographs and this was hands down the best," Mr. Krekian said. "And we're paying probably half of what we would at a private location." World Wrestling Entertainment paid $4,000 for the use of Ward Pound Ridge Reservation. 
When production companies contact Mrs. Stevens in search of a field or farm, she can show them the reservation or Muscoot Farms in Somers or any number of other locations.
Part of the reason Westchester has historically been such a popular location for film shooting is its proximity to New York, but another advantage is that it offers such a wide variety of settings: there are urban landscapes in Yonkers, Mount Vernon and New Rochelle, plus plenty of suburban and rural locals, and an airport. There is also the Long Island Sound and the Hudson River, as well as private mansions, thousands of acres of county parkland, as well as odd and original settings, like Playland, which was used in the movie "Big."
O N a recent afternoon, Mrs. Stevens sat in her office answering an inquiry from a producer looking for a medical examiner's office circa 1930.
"We have a medical examiner's office," she said to a caller, "but it's not going to look like the 1930's. It's very spiffy." The producer said something on his end and Mrs. Stevens replied: "I think they're going to have to rewrite it." Then, after the producer presumably said that the rewrite was a no-go, she continued: 'I do have a 1930's building that has a police station in it."
Despite the fact that reservations are still being converted for rumbles and the phone continues to ring in her office, Mrs. Stevens said that the county film business has, despite a slight pick-up recently, fallen off sharply in the past two years.
"Two years ago, it was great, fabulous," Mrs. Stevens said, "but it's probably fallen off 40 percent since last year. It's been a terrible film economy." The reasons, she said, have been a bad national economy, which has limited the number of commercials and independent films produced. 
"It's been a very grim picture," Mrs. Stevens said. "We've been dramatically hit." 
"Everything about this industry is bottom-line driven and now it's more bottom-line driven. My phone still rings, but there's less business and more haggling and negotiating. Bigger jobs are being done for less money."
Less filming means less money for the county, on many levels. In addition to the fee the county or municipality charges for the shoot, there are the dollars thrown off when a film production crew rolls into town for a period of time and spends money locally. Actresses get their nails done and best boy electrics buy sandwiches at the town's delis.
"Unfaithful," for example, starring Richard Gere and Diane Lane, spent 66 days shooting in the county. A spokeswoman for the county executive said that the film industry pumped more than $6 million into the county's economy in 2001, including more than $1 million in fees alone.
"As nice as it is to see our parks and building and airport up on the silver screen, it's even nicer to see all those dollars going to economic development," County Executive Andrew J. Spano said. "Local companies and hospitality-related services are getting business they never would have otherwise."
Not every star who comes through town gets beauty treatments, however. Kurt Angle, the W.W.E. wrestler and a 1996 Olympic wrestling gold medalist, was the featured actor in the Royal Rumble shoot but was not about to get his nails done locally -- or probably anywhere else.
Mr. Angle had wrestled in the W.W.E.'s Smackdown! event the night before and had flown into La Guardia Airport the morning of the shoot, and driven here in a long black limousine.
After putting two red coats into headlocks and mocking them for losing the war, Mr. Angle signed autographs for a scrum of young fans, looked around and said: "It's beautiful. It's just like I imagined battlefields back then, on green earth. Beautiful."

HEADLINE: HEALTH; 
A Loss of Support

BYLINE:  By YILU ZHAO 

 BODY:
FOR more than 20 years, social workers employed by the White Plains division of the New York Presbyterian Hospital have visited mentally ill patients regularly at their homes, checking on their health, taking them shopping for groceries, filing benefit applications for them, putting them into psychiatric treatment at times of crises and most often just chatting with them.
 Many of its current patients, mostly single elderly men who suffer from bipolar disorder or schizophrenia, have been abandoned by their families or have lived alone their entire adult lives. 
 The program will stop running next month. New York Presbyterian Hospital cited its financial loss -- about $100,000 annually -- for running this program as the reason to close it when the hospital informed the county government and the social workers of its decision in mid-December. It had clinical reasons as well. 
"It is better for patients to receive social support services from the providers of their psychiatric care," said Philip Wilner, the hospital's medical director of behavioral health and a vice president.
New York Presbyterian receives about $850,000 in state aid and Medicaid reimbursement for the program. The patients themselves do not pay.
The hospital treats 35 patients from this group, but roughly a quarter of the 250 patients do not receive any psychiatric treatment, their social workers said.
The 19 social workers will most likely be laid off, although the hospital has said it will relocate them if similar positions come up in the New York Presbyterian system.
The patients in the program might be picked up by a different hospital or another nonprofit organization, said Jennifer Schaffer, Westchester's commissioner of mental health, who is seeking out organizations that might be willing to take over the contract for the program. Myrna Manners, a spokeswoman for the hospital, said the hospital was examining all its programs in Westchester but did not have plans to cut any others.
Vincent Suppa, 61, who suffers from bipolar disorder, is stunned by the prospect that his social worker, Patricia Duran, will stop visiting him. A former computer technician, he lost his job eight years ago because of his mental illness. Since then, his wife has left him, and he was institutionalized more than three years ago. He now lives at an adult home, Lincoln Rest, in Ardsley, and his two children, who are 30 and 28, rarely visit him.
"Terrible, terrible," he mumbled in a husky low voice about losing Ms. Duran, who has visited him once a week for the last two and a half years ago. She has brought him warmth, laughter, pizza and prescription drugs, he said. Around the holidays, she has taken him shopping for clothes and gadgets. Her visits have become one of the few things he looks forward to.
"I don't feel any good," he said, his voice trembling. "I hope Patricia gets her job back with another hospital and can keep coming."
A woman who lives in a group home and suffers from schizophrenia, a social worker said, experienced a severe relapse when she learned that the program is ending. She has been crying and more depressed than usual, refusing to get up in the mornings, to shower or to follow any of her other daily routines.
Although a number of the social workers agreed to be interviewed, they all asked to withhold their names, hoping New York Presbyterian would transfer them to other locations. They are also counting on severance packages from the hospital (a week's pay for every year worked). 
Government financing for New York Presbyterian to run the program comes through the county's Community Support Services. Other participants in the Community Support programs include St. Joseph's Medical Center in Yonkers and Phelps Memorial Hospital Center in Sleepy Hollow. 
New York Presbyterian has always lost money providing social services to mentally ill patients in Westchester. Phelps, which also loses some money providing similar services, said it has absorbed the losses and views its participation in the program as a community service, said Mary Sernatinger, a hospital spokeswoman.
Dr. Schaffer is seeking another group to take over New York Presbyterian's contract, but it is uncertain whether the new contractor will hire the program's social workers. She said she has received several inquiries from other hospitals and nonprofit groups and is hopeful that she will find a new provider soon.
Studies have shown that support for mentally ill patients once they leave hospitals reduces relapses, homelessness and suicide rates.
Although New York Presbyterianhad a $2.2 million profit in 2001, the most recent figures available, like many other major hospitals in the region, it has been squeezed economically because of lower payments from Medicare and other government programs and low reimbursement rates from health-maintenance organizations and other managed companies, which pay hospitals 50 to 70 percent of the retail rate. 
"It's very hard for hospitals right now, particularly in psychiatric care," Dr. Wilner said. "There is not enough behavioral money out there. The hospital is trying to expand programs whose revenues and costs match more closely.
"We are committed to these patients," he added. "We are not abandoning them." 

GRAPHIC: Photos: Residents of Lincoln Rest in Ardsley, above and right, will lose visits by social workers from New York Presbyterian Hospital. (Photographs by Suzy Allman for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Garment District; 
Amid Offices and Factories, Space for Arts Groups

BYLINE:  By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
UNTIL about three years ago, all 25 floors of the 750,000-square-foot building at 520 Eighth Avenue, between West 36th and 37th Streets in the garment district, were filled with manufacturers, almost all of them involved in the garment trade. Since then, 500,000 square feet have been converted to offices and rented to such tenants as the Mason Tenders Welfare Fund, with 50,000 square feet; several real estate agencies; and a number of nonprofit organizations, including Chess in the Schools, a program that uses chess to teach learning skills to pupils from kindergarten through high school.
 But the most unusual tenant at 520 Eighth Avenue may be the Alliance of Resident Theaters, better known as A.R.T./New York. As a service and advocacy organization for more than 400 not-for-profit theaters and related arts groups, A.R.T./New York was familiar with the need of its constituents for office and space at affordable rents. Last May, it took action to meet that need when, with the promise of $3 million in city and foundation financing, it signed a 20-year lease for the entire third floors of 520 Eighth Avenue and the adjoining building at 261 West 36th Street. 
 Last August tenants began moving into the 32,000-square-foot space, in which passageways were made through the walls to join the spaces in the two buildings. There are now 24 tenants, all are connected with the arts and related organizations. They pay $21 a square foot annually to A.R.T./New York for their space, a dollar more than the alliance pays its landlord, Jeffrey R. Gural, chairman of Newmark & Company, the owner of the two buildings. 
If Virginia P. Louloudes, the alliance's executive director, had her way, those companies would not have to pay even that extra dollar. "We're just trying to break even, not make a profit," she said, adding that the additional dollar helps offset operational costs. 
Most of the financing to renovate the third floor was provided by the Bloomberg administration, which gave $1.5 million (honoring a pledge by the Giuliani administration). The City Council provided $1 million and the Manhattan borough president, C. Virginia Fields, gave $250,000. City agencies also hope to give additional funds in future years so that A.R.T./New York can lease and renovate additional floors in the building, Ms. Louloudes said, but whether the hopes will reach fruition will depend on the economy.
OTHER donors included J. P. Morgan Chase, the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation, the Hyde and Watson Foundation and Bruce and Carol Mitchell. In addition, the LuEsther T. Mertz Charitable Trust gave a $1.2 million recoverable grant, essentially an interest-free loan, to provide bridge financing while A.R.T./New York awaited funds from the city.
A number of people directly involved in the projects also made donations. Mr. Gural, the landlord, donated $250,000, and before A.R.T/New York took possession of the floor, he demolished what was there and put in new windows. In addition, according to Paul G. Wolf, a partner in DenhamWolf Real Estate Services, the company that found the space, negotiated the lease and oversaw the work, when A.R.T./New York made known its interest in renting the space, Mr. Gural agreed to hold it off the market until the alliance received the promised money from the city. 
Mr. Gural realized that the vicissitudes of fund-raising faced by nonprofit groups, in the theater and other areas, made the eventual success of the idea less than a sure thing. "I happen to like theater," he said, "but honestly I never thought the lease for the floor would get done, so I decided we'd renovate that floor for offices last." And if his pessimism turned out to be warranted, he recalled thinking, "we'd just get on with our lives." 
Martin Kapell, the architect for the interior renovation, donated his services -- a gift that Ms. Louloudes valued about $75,000. 
The renovation was complex and challenging for everyone involved, according to Jonathan Denham, another partner in DenhamWolf Real Estate Services. "It was essential from the beginning," he said, "that we centralize the process with the architect and the construction company." He added that Ms. Louloudes made it clear to tenants that A.R.T/New York's mission is to serve the community and the only way it could succeed was to maintain the same design criteria and decision-making schedule for all the subtenants. She also promised that tenants would receive proportionate shares of the construction dollars and equal access to the architectural team.
The offices on the third floor at 520 Eighth Avenue come in various sizes, ranging from a handful that are between 100 and 200 square feet; the most recent tenant is the People's Theater Company, with 100 square feet. About a half-dozen offices range from 1,300 to 2,500 square feet, and the biggest office is the 5,000-square-foot space occupied by the Arts Connection, a nonprofit arts-in-education program. 
During the previous 10 years, the Arts Connection occupied 3,000 square feet in the basement and first floor of the Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis High School for International Business (formerly the High School for the Performing Arts) on West 46th Street between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue. When executives at the Arts Connection, which has a staff of 28, learned of A.R.T./New York's plans for 520 Eighth Avenue, they could not wait to move in. 
"We were in three separate offices in the school," said Steve Tennen, the Arts Connection's executive director. "So it was almost impossible to get everybody for meetings, and one of the spaces was near the boiler, so in summer we had to turn on the air-conditioning." 
The Arts Connection moved into its current offices last August, and even today, Mr. Tennen said, employees relish the increased space and light. 
THE floor at 520 Eighth Avenue also includes two rehearsal studios, as well as a room that can be used for meetings, conferences or rehearsals. 
While most offices are without frills except for those added by tenants, they are not cookie-cutter spaces. Indeed, before signing a lease, the SITI Company, an ensemble-based theater company, which has a rehearsal hall for actors, had its own architect, Mary O'Connor, create a model of a piece of the floor to demonstrate the soundproofing they would build into their floors to show that it could absorb the shock of the actors' stomping. Ms. Louloudes said that they took the model to Mr. Gural and his son, Eric, senior managing director of Newmark & Company, "and they were comfortable with it." 
This project is not the alliance's first venture in connecting arts groups with modestly priced space. Three years ago this month, A.R.T./New York bought a 19,000-square-foot Beaux-Arts building at 138 South Oxford Street in Brooklyn. Today, it is the home of 20 small companies that rent offices for $12 a square foot, A.R.T./New York supplies a subsidy of about $100,000 a year.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jeffrey Gural, Virginia P. Louloudes and Paul G. Wolf in the Arts Connection's office at 520 Eighth Avenue. (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times)
