HEADLINE: Schools Ending Year Early Among Efforts to Cut Costs 

BYLINE:  By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 10 

 BODY:
Linda Pattison, a fourth-grade teacher here, uses her fingers to check off the lessons that she usually teaches but will skip this spring. Her pupils will not study the metric system in arithmetic, nor electricity in science. Nor will they read Oregon history in social studies.
 Ms. Pattison, who has taught for 28 years, looks a bit shattered as she reviews her recent efforts to gut her classes. 
 "I can only compare this to my divorce," she said, and she is not alone in her stress. Teachers across Oregon are queasily checking lesson plans, deciding what not to teach as half the school districts in the state prepare to slash anywhere from a few days to more than a month from the school year to cut costs.
Thousands of America's districts are grappling with extraordinary midyear budget cuts as state governments face deficits that stem from falling tax revenues. Most are laying off bus drivers and cutting art classes and field trips, and educators say the havoc will be worse next year. 
In California, where the law bars districts from laying off teachers after the year begins, schools are planning mass dismissals of janitors, cooks and other support workers to cope with $700 million in budget cuts.
But nowhere except Oregon have so many districts announced plans to severely shorten the academic year. The superintendent here, James R. Scherzinger, has ordered administrators to prepare to cut 15 days from the calendar, and he said that unless voters approve a tax increase in a referendum on Jan. 28, a prospect pollsters say is quite unlikely, he will urge a cut that totals 24 days.
Educational historians said this would be the first time in 70 years that many districts are closing schools far ahead of schedule. In the Depression, millions of workers lost work, government revenues crashed and thousands of districts shut early, the historians said.
"I find it remarkable to see this happening now, because although economic times are hard, this is nothing like the Great Depression," said Jeffrey E. Mirel, a historian and an associate dean of the University of Michigan School of Education. "To see large numbers of districts cutting weeks off the school year in times of mild but not severe recession is just unprecedented."
Oregon law permits districts to apply for waivers from minimum classroom instruction requirements, which are measured in hours and vary by grade level but are equivalent to 175 days. That has led about half the superintendents to propose cutting days from the calendar. 
In most states, laws require a minimum of 180 instructional days. So hard-pressed districts are saving money in other ways.
"They're cutting personnel through attrition, suspending building plans, eliminating sports and other extracurricular activities, not cleaning their buildings," said David Griffith, a spokesman for the National Association of State Boards of Education.
Oklahoma cut school financing $158 million this year, or more than 8 percent. That left 1,000 students in Oklahoma City without bus service and some schools without custodians, said Carolyn Crowder, president of the Oklahoma Education Association, the teachers' union. If authorities do not find new financing by the middle of April, 5,000 of the 44,000 teachers in the state will be laid off before next fall, Ms. Crowder said.
In Alabama, too, a fiscal crisis has forced authorities to lay off school workers and to pare programs this year. Officials expect deeper cuts in September.
"Next year, we're going to see the worst budget for public education in 30 years," said Susan Salter, a spokeswoman for the Alabama Association of School Boards.
In Oregon, the crisis is unfolding now, partly because districts depend on state aid for a higher proportion of their financing, about 70 percent, than in other states. Because Oregon has no sales tax, it relies almost entirely on an income tax whose revenues have plummeted.
Oregon is in the last semester of a two-year budget that had originally allotted $5.2 billion to public schools. But as revenues have fallen, the 198 districts have reduced spending by $418 million. If voters reject the tax increase on Jan. 28, the districts will lose an additional $95 million, said the Legislative Fiscal Office.
Tim Hibbitts, a pollster here, offered little hope for the tax increase, saying surveys last month showed 55 to 60 percent opposed it. "I expect it to lose," Mr. Hibbitts said. "I would be very surprised if it won."
Whatever the outcome on Jan. 28, officials said, they have no choice but to truncate the school year.
"What we're proposing is extraordinary," Mr. Scherzinger said. "I don't agree with it myself. It's very destructive. But we've run out of alternatives." 
He is negotiating the cuts with the union, which is threatening to strike.
Half the 100 districts that responded to a survey last month reported plans to shorten the school year, and 25 said the cuts would run 10 to 20 days. 
In Portland, the school board has adopted other measures, including dismissing the entire force of 330 unionized janitors in the summer and last month canceling a popular outdoor sixth-grade science camp, as well as all spring athletics. 
Damon Stoudamire, a graduate of the Portland schools who is on the Portland Trail Blazers basketball team, stepped in to donate $200,000. Other sports enthusiasts pledged similar amounts, saving spring athletics for this year, at least.
The crisis has called forth a cottage industry of volunteerism, with parents seeking to scrape together money in bake sales and auctions to restore art and music programs.
Michael E. Rosen, an environmental manager whose son Elias is a fourth grader, said he had helped his PTA collect $30,000 to hire an art instructor for Elias's school. But the news that the school year is being cut at least 15 days led to canceling the art classes, Mr. Rosen said.
"How could we take time for art when math classes are being axed?" he asked.
At Benson High School, a magnet school in the city center, Gail Black was trying to decide last week which novel to cut from her senior English class. "Huckleberry Finn" might have to go, Ms. Black said, or perhaps she would skip Hermann Hesse's "Siddhartha." 
"How do you just eliminate several weeks' class work?" she asked. "I've never faced anything like this."
Cutting 15 days from the calendar would mean a pay cut of $5,000 for the most experienced teachers here, the veterans with master's degrees and other advanced credits whose top salary is $56,700, according to the union.
Sitting in her classroom at Llewellyn Elementary School, Ms. Pattison said she was battling bouts of depression as she watched the schools erode around her.
"It's been death by a thousand cuts," she said.

HEADLINE: India Harvests Fruits of a Diaspora 

BYLINE:  By AMY WALDMAN 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, Jan. 11 

 BODY:
Sir Shridath Ramphal's grandmother left India in rebellion 150 years ago, after refusing to throw herself on her dead husband's funeral pyre. She ended up in indentured servitude in South America, in what was then the British colony of Guiana. When it became a nation, her grandson, Sir Shridath, became its first foreign minister. 
 Dipak C. Jain left India with optimism, heading for Dallas 20 years ago to work on a doctorate in applied mathematics. He became a professor in marketing, a field he had never heard of before leaving India, and then dean of the Kellogg School of Management at Northwestern University. 
 This week both men returned to India as part of what was billed as the largest gathering of the Indian diaspora since independence in 1947. Like most of the nearly 2,000 "nonresident Indians" and "people of Indian origin" who made the journey from 63 countries, they were abundantly successful. Nonetheless, they represented very different strands of one of the world's largest and most productive diasporas. 
The Indian government and the Federation of Indian Chambers of Commerce and Industry, organized the gathering, which ended today, to determine how the resources and achievements of Indians abroad might be used to uplift India. 
While Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee said in his speech opening the conference on Thursday that the government was not seeking the diaspora's riches, but its "richness of experience," the riches could not be ignored. According to a recent report by the consulting firm McKinsey & Company, the 20 million Indians living abroad generate an annual income equal to 35 percent of India's gross domestic product. 
Indians are the largest minority group in Britain and have the highest income among its minority groups. Indian-Americans have a median income 50 percent higher than the national average for the United States. Yet foreign direct investment by Indians abroad is only $1 billion, compared with about $60 billion invested by 55 million overseas Chinese. It is a gap the government hopes to close. 
"We want to create an environment for you so that you can excel in India as much as you could anywhere else in the world," Mr. Vajpayee said. 
To deepen the connection between India and its scattered seed, Mr. Vajpayee announced on Thursday that legislation would be introduced to grant dual citizenship to people of Indian origin living in "certain countries," which officials later tentatively identified as the United States, the United Kingdom, Australia, New Zealand, Canada and Singapore. 
On Friday, Finance Minister Jaswant Singh announced a series of measures to ease investment overseas. The limit on mutual fund investments in overseas stock exchanges was doubled, to $1 billion. 
Those attending the gathering included the prime minister of Mauritius and the former prime minister of Fiji, and two Nobel laureates -- the economist Amartya Sen and the writer V. S. Naipaul. There were politicians, scholars, industrialists and jurists. 
More than simply celebrating the "global Indian family," the conference put India -- the brilliance of its minds, the querulousness of its characters, its perpetual grappling to define its identity -- on display. 
Mr. Sen encouraged India to remember its long history of interaction with other civilizations and not to retreat into cultural isolationism. Mr. Naipaul -- who with typically tart precision observed that the gathering "has the element of the trade fair" -- told India to "stop blaming the British for everything." 
There seemed to be as many opinions as there were participants about what the conference was for, what the meaning of diaspora was, where loyalties should lie, and what India was and should be. 
"We Indian South Africans have had to struggle hard to claim our South Africanness, and that is something we jealously guard," said Fatima Meer, a South African anti-apartheid activist. "We are not a diaspora of India." 
One divide emerged between affluent professionals prospering in Europe or America and the descendants of indentured servants who had provided plantation labor in British colonies across the globe. 
"We must guard against this conference focusing too much on how India can build a relationship with those in the affluent sector of the diaspora, with little concern for those members of the diaspora who are suffering and whose rights are under assault," said Fiji's former prime minister, Mahendra P. Chaudhry, who is of Indian origin. 
Dhundev Bauhadoor, a Mauritian who heads the Global Organization of People of Indian Origin, criticized India for being slow to comment when Mr. Chaudhry was deposed in a coup and held hostage for 28 days in 2000. "This cannot continue," he said. "If India is to play her role as mother, she must protect her children wherever they are." 
Bharatkumar J. Shah, a Dubai businessman, spoke for the three million to four million Indians who have followed the oil boom since the 1970's to work as laborers in the Persian Gulf. They send more than $300 million annually to India, yet, he said, India has done too little to protect their rights and support their families. 
On Friday, Deputy Prime Minister L. K. Advani said all the delegates were of value to India, but he also said India's influence had widened thanks to the "high socioeconomic profile the Indian community now commands in the United States." More than 400 Indian-Americans attended the conference. 
Mr. Advani also waded into the debate, prompted by Hindu-Muslim riots in the state of Gujarat, that has riven India in recent months over its secular character and that seems to have divided the diaspora as well. 
After Mr. Naipaul's wife, Nadira Naipaul, a Muslim from Pakistan, challenged Mr. Advani to explain the place of Muslims and Christians in India he replied, "Secularism is so embedded in our thinking there can be no departure from that." 
Of the Gujarat riots, which left about 1,000 people, mostly Muslims, dead, he said: "We feel sad, we feel ashamed, we only say it's an aberration, it must not be repeated. I only say let's have it behind us." 
Sixty percent of the Indians in America are from Gujarat. Some at the conference said they were tired of attacks on the state because of the riots. "It's high time Gujarat and even the center stop apologizing for what happened in Gujarat," said Suvas G. Desai, a doctor from Lexington, Ky. 
Beyond politics, many of the attendees seemed interested in giving back and frustrated by how difficult India sometimes made it to do so. 
Dr. K. T. Shah, a Texas doctor, said he was harassed at customs when he tried to bring in medical equipment to donate in India. 
Jagadish Shukla, a professor of climate dynamics at George Mason University in Virginia, said he was starting a school in his village in eastern Uttar Pradesh. "In my village, nothing has changed," he said, noting that it took longer to get the village from New Delhi than it did to get to New Delhi from the District of Columbia. 
"Why didn't I do this 25 years ago?" he said of the school. He speculated that much of the complaining about India at the gathering was motivated by guilt at having left India behind.

HEADLINE: In Family Leave Case, Supreme Court Steps Back Into Federalism Debate 

BYLINE:  By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 

 BODY:
Eight years into the Rehnquist court's federalism revolution, it is almost routine for the new year to bring a new Supreme Court test of the limits of federal authority over the states. But there is nothing routine about the federalism case the justices will hear on Wednesday, potentially the most important of the half-dozen cases so far in which the court has shielded the states from the full reach of federal law.
 The new case, an appeal by the State of Nevada seeking immunity from suit under the Family and Medical Leave Act, on the surface resembles others in a series of increasingly caustic 5-to-4 rulings. In 2000, for example, the court held that employees could not sue states for violating the federal law against age discrimination. The next year, it ruled that states were immune from employment discrimination suits under the Americans With Disabilities Act. 
 Now the question is whether state employees can sue for damages under the Family and Medical Leave Act's family leave provision, which gives both men and women the right to take up to 12 weeks off without pay to care for a seriously ill family member. A Nevada state worker, William Hibbs, sued the state after being denied the full 12 weeks he requested to care for his ailing wife. 
There is no doubt that Congress meant the 1993 law to apply to state employers. Congress included language that explicitly removed the immunity from private damage suits that the states would otherwise enjoy under the 11th Amendment, which bars suits in federal court against states that have not given their consent to be sued. As in the earlier cases, the constitutional question is whether Congress acted within the scope of its authority when it removed the states' 11th Amendment shield.
The recent precedents have made this a very complex conceptual issue, and a heavily freighted one in terms of the relationship between the court and Congress. Through a series of incremental and highly technical decisions, the court has placed Congress in an increasingly tight vise. 
The question now is whether in the new case, Nevada Department of Human Resources v. Hibbs, No. 01-1368, the court will put a stranglehold on the ability of Congress to pursue its own constitutional vision.
For that reason, the case has drawn enormous attention not only from civil rights organizations but also from dozens of current and past members of Congress, who signed a brief arguing that Congress acted within the core of its constitutional authority in applying the family leave requirement to the states. In its brief on behalf of Congress, the Bush administration says the implications of a ruling in favor of state immunity would be disturbing for civil rights enforcement generally.
The basis for that assessment lies in the route the court has taken to reach this point. Decisions in the late 1990's held that Congress lacked authority to abrogate the states' immunity when acting within its ordinary power to regulate interstate commerce, the basis for most federal legislation. 
Those cases did not shut the door completely. They left one potential source of Congressional power over the 11th Amendment: Section 5 of the 14th Amendment, which gives Congress authority to "enforce, by appropriate legislation" the amendment's twin guarantees of equal protection and due process.
Both age discrimination and disability discrimination implicate equal protection, and the defense of Congress's application of the Age Discrimination in Employment Act and the Americans With Disabilities Act to the states was that Section 5 empowered Congress to act. But in Kimel v. Florida Board of Regents, the age case, and Board of Trustees of the University of Alabama v. Garrett, the disability case, the court rebuffed that argument. 
The 5-to-4 majority in both cases gave several reasons for its disapproval, essentially concluding that Congress had not come up with enough evidence of unconstitutional discrimination by state employers and so could not justify opening the states to lawsuits by their employees. The legislation was not "appropriate" under Section 5, the court held.
But the Family and Medical Leave Act is different, or at least that is the argument of its defenders. It was passed, after eight years of debate and two presidential vetoes, in an effort to combat the lingering effects of sex discrimination in the workplace by creating a level playing field where the duties of providing care at home were no longer "women's work" that made women less reliable, and therefore less desirable, as employees.
As Solicitor General Theodore B. Olson expressed it in the Bush administration's brief, "Congress aimed to transform family leave from its historic genesis as a 'women's issue' into a routinized, across-the-board employment benefit," no longer "a 'problem' attributed to the presence of women in the work force."
Under the Supreme Court's equal protection doctrine, sex discrimination is in a separate category from age and disability discrimination. Official policies that treat people differently on the basis of age, disability, income and -- unless the court says otherwise in a case that is currently pending -- sexual orientation are presumed to be constitutional, as long as the government presents a "rational basis" for their defense. But sex and race discrimination are presumed to be unconstitutional. Further, Congressional measures to prevent or cure these types of discrimination have traditionally received the court's deference, even if the justices would not themselves have defined the problem as Congress did or designed the remedy it chose.
That history of deference, and of constitutional interpretation as an enterprise to be shared between the court and Congress, is now at stake. The implications are both practical and symbolic. 
The practical impact would be felt by the 4.8 million people who work for state governments. If the states win, there would be no direct impact on private-sector workers. Even if the court finds that the Family and Medical Leave Act is not valid under Section 5 of the 14th Amendment, the law would remain unquestionably valid as legislation under the Commerce Clause, binding on private employers.
But a ruling that the act was not "appropriate" 14th Amendment legislation would entail the court's rejection of Congress's vision of what equal protection means. It would import into the core constitutional area of civil rights enforcement the muscular approach to judicial review displayed in recent cases: that the Constitution is only what the Supreme Court says it is.
To hold that civil rights laws could be justified only as economic measures under the Commerce Clause, rather than the Equal Protection Clause, "would be a huge symbolic turn in American politics," Prof. Robert C. Post of the University of California at Berkeley said in an interview. 
"Nothing could be more symbolic of this court's hostility to civil rights than to strip these laws of their constitutional resonance," Professor Post said.
The states are of two minds about the case. Fourteen have joined Nevada's brief, while Connecticut and four others have joined a brief filed by New York's attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, in defense of the law.
Nevada maintains that application of the law would be nothing less than a constitutional insult.
"States maintain the dignity of a co-equal in our system of dual sovereignty," Nevada's brief says, "and immunity is central to that dignity."

HEADLINE: FOLLOWING UP 

BYLINE:  By Joseph P. Fried 

 BODY:
The Velvet Rope Meets the U.S. Border
The headlines dubbed him "Club King" and "Mega-Club Mogul." 
 In the 1980's and 90's, Peter Gatien was a leading nightclub owner in Manhattan, whose cavernous, high-decibel, high-energy spots drew packs of young revelers and stacks of publicity. 
 The publicity was not always welcome. In 1996, federal prosecutors charged that Mr. Gatien had turned two of the clubs, Limelight and the Tunnel, into virtual drug supermarkets by authorizing and even financing drug dealing and drug use on the premises, in order to increase patronage and profitability. Mr. Gatien said any drug activity occurred despite his efforts to combat it. A jury acquitted him.
But in 1999 he pleaded guilty to state tax-evasion charges. He served 60 days in jail and agreed to pay $1.88 million in back taxes and fines.
Community groups and the authorities pressed to have the two clubs closed. They said noise and drunken and drugged patrons made Limelight's neighbors in Chelsea miserable, and they attributed violent incidents near the Tunnel to its patrons.
There were also economic problems, and in 2001 Limelight was sold in bankruptcy court to an operator whose club on the site is called called Estate. The Tunnel closed.
These days, Mr. Gatien, 50, is balancing between hopeful ups and one big down. The upside is twofold, he said last week: working with Spike Lee's production company to develop a fictional television series that is set in a nightclub, and working separately on a movie script "largely based on my life."
The downside is the effort by American immigration authorities to deport him to his native Canada. Though he has lived in the United States for 25 years, Mr. Gatien has never sought American citizenship. The authorities say his deportation is required because he is a noncitizen convicted of an "aggravated felony" -- tax evasion.
His lawyers dispute that his crime was an aggravated felony. One lawyer, Benjamin Brafman, said Mr. Gatien was "desperately hopeful" that he would not be deported. A hearing is scheduled before an immigration judge tomorrow.
Mr. Gatien said he wanted to remain in the United States because his family was rooted here -- his wife and three of his four children are American citizens -- and because "America and New York are the hub of lots of things that interest me."
"I'm anxious," he said. "Scared. There are knots in my stomach."

Next Stop, Trade Center. Yes, You Heard It Right.
The signs on the E trains still say its last stop in Manhattan is the World Trade Center. Conductors often announce that you are boarding the "E to the World Trade Center." At the terminal, "Chambers WTC" signs remain on some platform pillars, though they have been removed from other pillars without any replacement signs.
Sixteen months after the trade center disappeared in the terrorist attack, are we talking here about an oversight, lethargy or a policy decision in favor or the status quo? 
"A policy decision," said a spokesman for New York City Transit, which operates the subway.
"Until a decision is made on what that site will be, it doesn't behoove us to change the name of the destination," the spokesman, Paul Fleuranges, said. "For us to decide unilaterally what to call it would not be working in partnership" with the agencies planning the redevelopment of the trade center site.
About the signs removed from the terminal pillars: "It could have been for maintenance or cleaning" and signifies nothing more, he said.

HEADLINE: Lawmakers Seek a Routine in the Capitol Maze 

BYLINE:  By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 

 BODY:
As snow dusted the Capitol last Sunday afternoon, Candice Miller, no longer Michigan's secretary of state but not quite an official member of the House of Representatives, arrived at her new suite in the Cannon Building to meet her staff and do a little unpacking. Dressed casually in sweatshirt and khakis, Mrs. Miller strode through the door, stopping as she spotted her new nameplate.
 "Jamie," she said to her chief of staff, Jamie Roe, "my name's on the door." 
 "That's what happens when you win," Mr. Roe replied dryly. 
Next door in the Longworth Building, much the same scene was playing out in the office of Raul M. Grijalva, newly elected from Tucson. "They have to put a little accent mark here," said Mr. Grijalva, gesturing toward the U in his first name. "I'll do that myself, with a little Wite-Out." 
By week's end, Mrs. Miller and Mr. Grijalva had already cast their first votes, on House rules, unemployment benefits, a stopgap spending measure and what seemed like endless procedural concerns. But first, there were pictures to hang, voting cards and identification pins to pick up, swearing-in parties to attend, television interviews to do, lobbyists to meet, kinks to work out. 
The first time Mrs. Miller pulled open the drawer of her standard-issue mahogany desk, she discovered she had no paper or pens. Mr. Grijalva's discovery was even worse: the computers he ordered had not arrived. "They're coming," said his chief of staff, Ana Ma, her frustration with the federal bureaucracy evident behind her frozen smile.
For Mr. Grijalva, a liberal Democrat with deep roots in Tucson's Hispanic community, and Mrs. Miller, who calls herself a "George W. Bush Republican" and represents Macomb County outside Detroit, the months ahead will be filled with discussions of domestic security, Medicare reform, tax cuts and other weighty matters. But in this first week, Mrs. Miller, 48, and Mr. Grijalva (pronounced gree-HAHL-va), 52, were consumed not so much by politics and policy as by the practical realities of their new lives.
From the clocks whose electronic bells alert them to a vote -- "I thought it might be a fire alarm," Mr. Grijalva confessed -- to their House-issued Blackberry pagers, to the underground tunnels that connect their offices to the Capitol, these freshmen had much to learn.
Mrs. Miller, a creature of organization who worried she would be late to the House chamber for votes, insisted that she and her staff make practice runs through the subterranean maze. "The first time, we got lost," she said. She timed the route at 15 minutes, although she said a Michigan colleague, Representative Dave Camp, assured her that she would eventually need only five.
Mr. Grijalva simply gave up on the tunnels, preferring to walk outside with the huge Capitol dome as his guide. "I like the fresh air," he said. 
Being a member of Congress can mean long, unpredictable hours. On Wednesday, as the House voted late into the night, Mr. Grijalva attended a reception for Hispanic leaders and then rushed back to the Capitol to vote, ferried by a taxi driver who dropped him off near the Senate, not the House. Mrs. Miller, afraid to stray too far from the Capitol, found herself eating take-out Chinese food for dinner in the office of Representative Tom DeLay, the majority leader.
It is also physical work. By Thursday, Mrs. Miller -- who races sailboats as a hobby -- said her feet were killing her from rushing around on the Capitol's unforgiving tile and marble floors. "I bought several pair of these Hush Puppies," she said, showing off some very sensible flat shoes.
Mr. Grijalva and Mrs. Miller were eager to set up shop early, so they took advantage of a House rule that permits freshmen to move into their offices a few days before they are officially sworn in. 
To make himself feel at home, Mr. Grijalva brought some artwork, including a picture of the Sonoran Desert (he is an ardent environmentalist), some Yaqui masks (the Yaqui tribe is one of several in his district, which stretches across two-thirds of Arizona's border with Mexico) and a framed sepia-tone photograph of his father, a Mexican immigrant who was once a ranch hand. The picture hangs behind his desk.
Mrs. Miller brought her favorite photograph, of herself and Laura Bush, as well as her favorite award, a bronze statue of a Revolutionary War Minuteman, given by the Michigan National Guard in recognition of her efforts to spare the Selfridge Air National Guard base, in her district, from being closed. Right after the election, Mrs. Miller began lobbying Republican leaders for a seat on the House Armed Services Committee. At the end of the week, she learned she had it.
"Can you believe it?" she exclaimed, beaming. "I am thrilled, absolutely thrilled."
By Tuesday, Opening Day, Mrs. Miller was hosting a pre-swearing-in open house, with coffee, fruit and pastries for whoever cared to drop in. Wearing a brown knit suit that she chose because it was "sort of conservative-looking, Republican-looking," she greeted a steady stream of visitors, among them Representative John D. Dingell, the Michigan Democrat who is the longest-serving member of the House. A handful of lobbyists, including those representing an anti-abortion group, came by, looking to make new friends. They left lapel pins in the shape of baby footprints on Mrs. Miller's desk.
At Mr. Grijalva's office, the computers had still not arrived, and the staff was making do with a handful of old machines and a couple of borrowed laptops.
As an aide prepared the congressman's first official act, a letter asking Attorney General John Ashcroft to investigate vigilantes who are patrolling the southern Arizona border, Mr. Grijalva paced about. He sifted through his papers, including a letter from Representative Nancy Pelosi, the House Democratic leader, urging him to vote against changes to House rules that she said would give Republicans a procedural edge.
"Might as well get off to a good start and vote no on something," Mr. Grijalva said. Later that day, he did.
All House members need an electronic voting card, which resembles a driver's license, and a member's pin that permits them to move swiftly past security. So on Tuesday morning, Mr. Grijalva took a walk to the Speaker's Lobby, the portrait-lined corridor that runs alongside the House chamber, to pick up these essential items. Back at the office, a staff member took a photograph of his wife, Ramona, affixing a blue oval pin to his lapel. But when he arrived on the House floor to take the oath of office, Mr. Grijalva learned he had made a mistake common to freshmen: he put on the spouse's pin. The member's pin is round and white.
For Mrs. Miller and Mr. Grijalva, adding the title "Representative" to their names was a highlight of the week. So, too, was casting their first votes.
Mr. Grijalva was surprised to learn that, despite the image projected by C-Span, very few members actually sit in the House chamber to listen to colleagues debate. Entranced, he stayed put as his fellow Democrat, Representative David R. Obey of Wisconsin, argued passionately for a more generous unemployment benefits package than the 13-week extension the House ultimately passed. 
"I liked his style," Mr. Grijalva said of Mr. Obey. Although he voted with other Democrats in favor of the 13-week extension, Mr. Grijalva was not particularly happy about it. "Half a loaf," he said with a frown.
Mrs. Miller, reflecting the glow of Republicans' newfound political prowess, said that with 85,000 people unemployed in her home state, she felt terrific about the vote. "I felt," she said, "that I was doing what I came here to do."
Articles in this series will periodically observe two Congressional newcomers as they take on their new roles.

HEADLINE: City Sidewalks, Packed in Holiday Style, Hint at End to a Lingering Slump in Tourism 

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY DePALMA 

 BODY:
People lined up for hours on the sidewalk in front of the Empire State Building during the holiday season just past. Ground zero was packed. Crowds spilled out the entrance of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and even if the guy holding a yellow cobra had not been standing in front of the Virgin Megastore in Times Square on the Monday afternoon before New Year's Eve, the sidewalks would have been as congested as, well, Times Square on New Year's Eve.
 It is still too early for official figures, but the monumental crowds that clogged Midtown and downtown offer clues to how the city's $25 billion tourism industry did over the holidays. 
 In a sidewalk census during 15 late-afternoon minutes on Dec. 30, 2,432 people shuffled by the Virgin store, a staggering rate of nearly 10,000 people an hour. That exceeds by a good 12 percent the count from the summer season's peak, in late August, according to officials of the local business improvement district, which conducted the count. 
The sheer number of bodies amassing in the cold is no absolute indicator that tourism -- one of the city's most important moneymakers -- has recovered from the disaster of the 2001 holiday season, which took place in the post-Sept. 11 gloom. And lackluster retail sales suggest that most of the tourists did not break their banks while they were here.
But tourism experts and city officials say the sheer size of the crowds on the sidewalks of New York during the holidays is the most visible sign that hotels, restaurants and tourist attractions had a season with visitors and revenues that resembled the banner year of 2000 more than the troubled times of 2001. 
"Being on the streets felt very much like it was the New York of old," said Dr. Lalia Rach, dean of the Tisch Center for Hospitality and Tourism at New York University. Almost a year and a half after the attack on the World Trade Center, much of the fear of coming to New York seems to have been replaced, she said, by a desire to witness the city's recovery firsthand. "There is a tremendous pent-up demand." 
But there are some dark notes: International tourists have not returned to New York in anything like the numbers before Sept. 11, and city tourism officials do not expect them back anytime soon, although there have been some successful efforts to lure back small groups of international travelers. 
Still, hotel occupancy rates were higher than expected during the holidays. Many of those rooms rented for reduced rates, or on special packages; many rooms were filled with visitors from the region and west of the Appalachians, and not the foreign tourists of days past. 
"There were more tourists overall in New York City this season, but they were mostly domestic tourists," said Cristyne L. Nicholas, president of NYC & Company, the city's tourism bureau. While American hotel guests spend only a fraction of what international tourists do during vacation, keeping the hotels close to average occupancy "means a lot to the economy," said Ms. Nicholas, because hotels account for about 40 percent of all tourist dollars.
Occupancy for all New York hotels was 81 percent in December, about 7 percent higher than for the same month in 2001, according to preliminary figures from Smith Travel Research, a company that tracks the national hotel industry. 
Average room rates in New York, though still down substantially from the record highs of 2000, were 15 percent higher than in 2001 during December, according to Smith. The rooms needed to be cleaned, the towels washed, and so there was work for many of those who were jobless last year. The leaders of hotel workers' unions said that during the holidays all their members worked, except for about 1,000 who worked at two downtown hotels until Sept. 11.
City tourism officials believe that many people visited New York for the first time during the holidays. But there also are signs that many tourists had been here before. The number of people who stopped by the information center run by the Times Square Business Improvement District to ask for directions or to find out how to see a Broadway show dropped in December by 20 percent from the previous year. 
But there is evidence that newcomers were here too. Tourists stopped the uniformed safety officers hired by the Times Square district to ask for directions 74,523 times in December, an increase of more than 10 percent over the same month in 2001.
For much of December, every day seemed like matinee day, Wednesday, when theater traffic jams the Times Square theater district. "It really got crazy about the 10th of December and continued right through to the 2nd of January," said Bill O'Connor, a disabled Marine veteran who scoots around Times Square most days on a motorized cart. Mr. O'Connor, 67, said he had to ride in the street because sidewalks were just too jammed, with the crowds the biggest he ad seen since the mid-1980's. 
Mr. O'Connor was not the only person squeezed off the sidewalks. Daniella Eidelberg, a planner with the Times Square improvement district who helped count the crowds in December, said she also did a census of people forced into the street because they couldn't find a way through the crowds. In one 15-minute period, she said, 520 people jumped the curb in front of the Toys "R" Us store in Times Square.
Formidable crowds were not limited to Times Square. "I was downtown the week before Christmas, and I couldn't believe the number of people there," said Fred Kent, who as president of the Project for Public Spaces has been keeping track of sidewalk traffic for more than 20 years. What he saw drove him close to committing blasphemy, in certain urban planning circles. 
"It was almost too crowded," Mr. Kent said.
Lee Armstrong, director of public safety for the Downtown Alliance, which promotes the financial district, said his red-coated public safety officers reported a 49 percent increase in interactions with the public in December compared with the same month last year. 
Many, of course, were looking for ground zero. But they also asked for directions to the Statue of Liberty ferry and a few new museums. Downtown hotels, which had such a devastating season in 2001, did better than expected, in most cases meeting or exceeding the city's 81.3 percent December occupancy.
Kate M. Harth, director of sales and marketing at the Ritz-Carlton New York, which delayed its opening because of Sept. 11, said December was the new hotel's best month of the year, with occupancy just shy of 82 percent. 
Overall, the city's hotels had a mixed season. "It looks like things were pretty strong right up to Christmas, but then they dropped substantially," said John A. Fox, senior vice president of PKF Consulting, which tracks hotels. Mr. Fox said that based on preliminary data, hotel revenues were up 30 percent for the first three weeks of December, despite bargain rates. While revenues for the final week of the month still exceeded the same week in 2001, they were ahead by only about 10 percent. 
Mr. Fox also pointed out that because Thanksgiving came so late it shortened by about a week one of the hotels' most important periods of the year. 
Still, some hotels did very well. The Waldorf-Astoria had more rooms filled in December than for any December in its history, said Eric O. Long, general manager. "It was a record-breaker, and by a good margin," Mr. Long said. The hotel's restaurants recorded their highest revenues on record, perhaps because reduced room rates made visitors feel like splurging on something else.
Whatever the reason, and whatever the rate, rooms at the hotel were full or nearly so from Thanksgiving through the end of the year, and holiday tourists had clearly decided to come back to New York.
"We've got a lot to be thankful for," Mr. Long said.

HEADLINE: For State, at Least, Public Safety Seems Safe From the Ax 

BYLINE:  By AL BAKER 

 BODY:
One of the concrete promises Gov. George E. Pataki made on Wednesday in his annual speech to legislators in Albany was to protect spending on public security from the kind of cuts he is likely to impose on other areas of the state budget.
 His overarching statement signaled politically that he would hold true to his law-and-order priorities -- a 2003 version of the message he sent out in 1995. At that time, with street crime was more pervasive than it is now, he signed a death penalty bill into law, using two pens that belonged to slain New York Police Department officers. 
 But if any local law enforcement officials are seeking a sign that the pledge means they will get more state aid than usual as they try to grapple with their own budget shortfalls, they are likely to be disappointed. Administration officials said the governor's intent was to protect state spending on public security -- and he was silent about any money spent by localities to protect the public.
The governor's promise, though not specific, was of interest to law enforcers of all stripes because, in the post-9/11 world of many threats and a weak economy, security and the money to pay for it are priorities this year across New York.
"The budget plan I will put forward in three weeks will spend less money than we did last year," Mr. Pataki said in his speech. "With the exception of public security, no segment of the budget will be exempt."
Many in and out of state government cautioned that the exact details of how funds will be allocated would not be clear until Mr. Pataki issues his executive budget on Jan. 29. Mr. Pataki said that the budget would reduce spending as the state manages a gap of $2 billion to $2.5 billion this fiscal year and at least $10 billion next year.
But, administration officials said, by "public security," Mr. Pataki was referring narrowly to the state's security operations, core services, and its responsibilities to use the National Guard, for example, to protect various facilities and the state police to protect the borders. It was not a broader reference to local and state police departments, or other agencies throughout the state, they said.
Mr. Pataki "wants to maintain efforts at the state level which protect New Yorkers, such as bolstering security at our borders, combating terror and supporting the state police,"
Lynn Rasic, a spokeswoman for the governor, said Friday. The governor has already committed to funding for 120 additional state troopers, who will be used to protect the state's borders, the state officials said. He also will not lay off prison guards, they said, or seek to change criminal justice laws to give prisoners emergency early releases, as has been done or considered in other states to reduce huge budget deficits.
In addition, he will continue to lobby in Washington in an effort to secure more federal assistance for the New York Police Department, one aide said. In the current state budget, about $200 million was expected to cover estimated security costs through April 1, including the growing needs identified by the state's new Office of Public Security.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is already facing such a severe budget gap of his own that police officers may be laid off; at least 1,000 officers are now devoted to antiterrorism-related duties. But city officials took comfort in Mr. Pataki's vow to leave public service funds unscathed. Even though money that flows from the state into the Police Department budget is minimal, losing any funds would likely be painful, considering the city's current budget woes. Of the department's $3.48 billion budget this year, the city provides $3.13 billion and the state provides $12 million, only $2.4 million of which comes in the form of grants, the official said. The Police Department is much more reliant on federal funds: this year they comprise $210 million of its budget. Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly has been trying to persuade Congress and the Bush administration to give New York $261 million of the roughly $3.5 billion originally earmarked for local authorities for domestic security counterterrorism. The city, having been struck twice by international terrorists, has proven vulnerable and, the argument goes, by protecting itself it protects the nation.
Senator Charles E. Schumer, who has met with Mr. Kelly on the issue, said he was sympathetic to the city's plight and confident that some of the homeland security money now being divided up in Washington will make its way to Mr. Kelly's department.
"He is hit from three sides," the senator, who has fought for federal funding, said. "He has the new post-9/11 responsibilities, he has to keep up the war on crime, and he has less city money to do it."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: INSIDE BASEBALL; 
Teams Are Playing Musical Chairs in Bullpens

BYLINE:  By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Relief pitchers are a breed unto themselves. They are a squad unto themselves, too, stationed apart from their teammates in distant outposts beyond the outfield fences. To pass the time before they are summoned into games, they often create games that they play among themselves. This winter, teams have created a game for the relievers. It is called musical bullpens.
 With teams releasing them, not tendering them contracts or not re-signing them so they become free agents, relievers have moved around the major leagues as teams have made decisions that range from filling a hole to replacing a closer to constructing a new relief corps. 
 The movement has been so rampant that six relievers who led their teams in saves last season are no longer with those teams: Billy Koch, traded from Oakland to the Chicago White Sox; Ugueth Urbina, gone from Boston to Texas as a free agent; Roberto Hernandez, an unsigned free agent; Esteban Yan, signed by Texas after not getting a contract offer from Tampa Bay; Hideki Irabu, released by Texas and gone home to Japan; and Keith Foulke, traded to replace Koch in Oakland. 
The Red Sox, the Rangers and the Chicago Cubs have acted most aggressively in reconfiguring their bullpens. The Red Sox, in fact, not only have new relievers but also a new concept. The Rangers, forever seeking pitchers, have made major bullpen moves for the second successive off-season.
Last year, the Rangers acted as if they were signing the Alex Rodriguez of relievers, giving Jay Powell a three-year, $9 million contract and Todd Van Poppel a three-year, $7.5 million deal. This time around, chastened by the reality of baseball's economics, the Rangers signed Urbina for one year at $4.5 million, Yan for one year at $1.5 million and Aaron Fultz for one year at $600,000.
After last season's poor bullpen performance, the Rangers had to do something. They squandered as many saves as they earned, 33, and they had 38 losses by relievers, the most ever by a major league team. The three newcomers are expected to join Powell, Van Poppel and Francisco Cordero in the bullpen.
The Red Sox did not want to keep Urbina as their closer, despite his 40 saves. They made him an offer he could refuse. 
"We made Urbina a multiyear contract offer, but it was probably less in line with what closers make and more in line with what is made by the pitchers we brought in," Boston General Manager Theo Epstein said. "We chose to bring in several relievers for what it would have cost us to sign one closer. They provide the depth we lacked last year."
Ramiro Mendoza (two years, $6.5 million) and Mike Timlin (one year, $1.85 million) are the primary additions to the relief corps. Chad Fox and Ryan Rupe are also newcomers. The four will join Alan Embree and Bob Howry in a setup that some might call closer by committee.
"That's not my choice of words," Epstein said. Instead, he calls it "a deep, versatile, flexible bullpen with six quality options to attack opposing lineups and game situations."
Teams that win pennants and World Series usually have dominant closers. Mariano Rivera, for example, was instrumental in the Yankees' three consecutive World Series championships from 1998 to 2000. No one in the past few decades has developed a revolutionary way of creating a successful bullpen plan.
"We're trying something that's a little different," Epstein said. "It's about allocating our resources in the bullpen. We want six quality options. We have six guys we're confident will go out and get outs for us. We believe the most critical outs in a game aren't necessarily in the ninth. 
"We want our best pitcher, whoever he is at the time, to get the most critical outs of the game. That may be in the seventh inning with the bases loaded, not in the ninth with a three-run lead. We might have a situation where you need a sinkerball pitcher. Or a left-hander with three left-handed hitters coming up in the eighth. We'd rather make our bullpen fit situations."
The plan is not something the Red Sox concocted on the spur of the moment this off-season. Epstein said club officials spoke with Manager Grady Little about it during the second half of last season.
"The save statistic was invented by a sportswriter fairly recently in baseball history," Epstein said. "It dictated a certain pattern of usage. We decided to try something new." But, he acknowledged, "It's also born out of necessity." 
The Cubs were aggressive early in the signing season, luring Mike Remlinger from Atlanta with a three-year, $10.65 million contract. They also added Dave Veres and last week signed Rod Beck, who in 1998 had 51 saves for the Cubs but who missed all of last season after elbow ligament transplant surgery.
"In 2001 we were in the race most of the year and our bullpen was one of our strengths," General Manager Jim Hendry said. "Last year it became obvious early on that it was a weakness. Our main goal was to strengthen it, even if it meant overloading it. We may not be done yet."
Interestingly, in all of the moves involving relievers, the Braves and the Yankees have lost the most, though in the Yankees' case they let Mendoza and Mike Stanton (Mets) leave as free agents. The Braves had no interest in coming close to what the Cubs gave Remlinger or what the Yankees gave Chris Hammond. They also traded Tim Spooneybarger for Mike Hampton and did not offer Kerry Ligtenberg a contract.

Words Are All They Have
When Larry Lucchino, chief executive of the Red Sox, referred to the Yankees a few weeks ago as the evil empire after their signing of Jose Contreras, he triggered a war of words with George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner. 
The two men have long viewed each other with animosity, but there was a time when Steinbrenner actually spoke kindly of Lucchino. It was in July 1993, a few weeks before the Baltimore Orioles were to be sold at auction, and Steinbrenner was in Baltimore for a luncheon. Lucchino was president of the Orioles, and Steinbrenner said he hoped Lucchino would be involved with one of the groups bidding for the team in bankruptcy court.
"He and I have been on opposite sides of the fence sometimes, but he's a very bright guy and I think it would be nice if he were in the picture because that would give us the continuity," Steinbrenner told The Baltimore Sun. "We need that right now with all the things that are going on."
Peter Angelos won the bidding, and Lucchino remained with the team briefly, then moved on.

Guys Down the Hall
From the results of this year's Hall of Fame voting, it would seem highly unlikely that any of the also-rans will gain election next year. Of the 15 players who were on the ballot last year and did not make it this year, 10 players had their percentage of votes fall. The five whose percentages rose did not make significant gains. No first-timer received 50 percent this year.
Critics were quick to question the voters on some of the players they failed to elect, like Bruce Sutter, Rich Gossage, Andre Dawson, Bert Blyleven, Jim Rice and Ryne Sandberg. Little has been heard in support of Jack Morris, whose percentage rose slightly, from 20.6 to 22.8, but he deserves a closer look.
Morris has most likely suffered in the eyes of many voters because he never won the Cy Young award and three pitchers on the ballot won more games and had lower earned run averages. But his .577 winning percentage (254-186) was significantly better than the percentages of Tommy John, Blyleven and Jim Kaat, who will no longer be on the writers' ballot.
Moreover, Morris led all pitchers in the 1980's in victories, complete games, starts and innings, and he was virtually always his team's No. 1 winner. More intriguing, in the two seasons after his 14-year career with Detroit, 1991 and 1992, he pitched for Minnesota and Toronto, and led both in victories and to World Series championships, giving him a ring with three different teams.
Pitching for the Tigers in 1984, Morris, a take-no-prisoners right-hander, won all three of his postseason starts, against Kansas City and San Diego, completing two and compiling a 1.80 E.R.A. Moving to Minnesota in 1991, he won all four of his postseason decisions, against Toronto and Atlanta, including the classic, unforgettable 10-inning 1-0 defeat of Atlanta in Game 7.
He did not match those performances in the 1992 postseason, but he led the Blue Jays during the regular season with 21 victories.
As a sign of his endurance, Morris held the American League record for successive starts (515) before Roger Clemens surpassed him in 2001.
As for the other also-rans, the Yankees' Don Mattingly suffered the steepest decline in percentage of votes, plunging from 20.3 to 13.7.

HEADLINE: UP FRONT: WORTH NOTING; 
Fees for Surfcasters? The State Puts Its Toe In

BYLINE:  By Jeremy Pearce 

 BODY:
While the economy still twitches and flounders, the price of fish in New Jersey just seems to keep rising.
 For the first time, state wildlife officials are considering charging a license fee for saltwater fishermen, a move that could spawn $5 million in revenue. 
At the moment, only anglers on inland lakes and rivers pay to cast -- $22.50 for a basic annual license plus $10.50 for residents who pursue the prized trout. 
 Fishermen are of two minds. There are the weekend warriors who see the end of a tradition: either a day at the shore in search of stripers in the surf or a lazy afternoon spent on a party boat lining for bluefish. They believe a fee will only scare off casual sportsmen.
Others contend that small license fees -- if dedicated solely to fish programs and research -- could pose a boon.
"The money should not go to paving roads, for example," said Capt. Andy Bulakowski, who skippers his 38-foot charter vessel, Mission Bound, out of Cape May. "You are going to lose some people. You are going to disturb a few family vacations. But this could be very good for the fish."
State officials, of course, like to hear that. Bradley M. Campbell, commissioner of the Department of Environmental Protection, has not yet mentioned a cost for saltwater licenses, but he has acknowledged that such a system could be crucial in a time of declining state budgets.
Captain Bulakowski sees another advantage. "It would finally get the number of New Jersey's sport fishermen on paper," he said. "With those numbers comes the politicians' loyalty." Jeremy Pearce

BENEFITS FOR JOBLESS

 BODY:
 Congress went back to work, and Republican leaders of the House and Senate, eager to take a political weapon away from Democrats, moved quickly to help Americans who have lost their jobs.

HEADLINE: Word for Word/Preppies and Hipsters; 
Taxonomies of Style: It Takes More Than Scoots and Berries to Be Deck

BYLINE:  By TOM ZELLER 

 BODY:
IT could be argued that classifying the various social subspecies in Western culture used to be a more simple task. Nobles were nobles, serfs were serfs, and even the most well-to-do would go thirsty if they insisted on drinking only microbrewed grog. 
 Times have changed. The birth of the bourgeoisie brought access and pretensions of taste to a much larger swath of humanity. This in turn created demand for documentation of the various emerging types. 
 The most famous recent example of such a field guide was Lisa Birnbach's, "The Official Preppy Handbook" (Workman Publishing, 1980), which codified the pink-and-green habits of Missy, Corkie and Biff. Tack on a couple of decades of Nirvana, CK-1 and a nostalgic (if uninformed) reverence for all things Kerouac, and you've got a new specimen: the Hipster. 
 What follows is a comparison of text and image excerpts from the "Preppy Handbook" and its modern progeny "The Hipster Handbook" (Anchor Books). The latter guide, written by Robert Lanham and illustrated by Bret Nicely and Jeff Bechtel, is scheduled for publication in mid-February, and it proves that behind every goatee, shaggy hairdo and baggy blouse, there's still a lot of preening. TOM ZELLER

COMPARISON OF THE SPECIES
Both groups share a powerful need to belong.

The Preppy
"Preppies inherit from Mummy and Daddy, in addition to loopy handwriting and old furniture, the legacy of Proper Breeding. Preppies soon learn that any deviation from the prescribed style of life is bound to bring disaster. Attending a declasse school, marrying wrong, selecting uncharted neighborhoods, choosing demanding vocations, or simply taking up bowling can unravel the tightly woven social fabric that binds the comfortable Preppy community."

The Hipster
"Hipsters are always very conscious of what they are wearing and distinguish themselves by dressing creatively. . . . They possess an innate contempt for franchises, strip malls and the corporate world in general, . . . believe that irony has more resonance than reason . . . and enjoy declaring random things, like vodka martinis or exercise, passe.
Underneath their apparent individualism, Hipsters conform just like everyone else."

MALE PLUMAGE
The need to attract a suitable mate governs the male grooming regimen in both Preppy and Hipster culture, although the details differ slightly.

The Preppy
"Clean shaven --no sideburns, beard or mustache. The hair should be cut conservatively short, but not freakishly so. Straight hair may be either slicked back in a rakish, 1930's gloss, or deftly windblown in a just-back-from-the-regatta tousle."

The Hipster
CHOPS
"Hipsters who have chops should avoid hanging out together."

NEO-PANTHER
CASABLANCA

CLASSIC DISPLAYS
Although Preppies and Hipsters might seem to be easily identifiable, there is tremendous variation within each species. Here are some of the type variations from each handbook. All Hipster styles below are deck (cool); all Preppy styles are cool (deck).

The Cute Boy
"Pepsodent smile; moderate muscles; early James Franciscus look."

The Maxwell
"Gay . . . Hipsters who . . . purchase the latest Prada and Diesel wear."

The Aesthete
"Tortoise-shell glasses; absence of body hair; abundance of freckles."

The Polit
"Thick-looking skin and a mole or two on their neck or face. . . . Accessorizes with . . . wire-rimmed glasses."

The Cute Girl
"Slim hips, small bust. Pretty but never voluptuous. Quote: 'How many colors does it come in?"'

The UTF
"Unemployed Trust-Funder. . . . Knows the value of a musky armpit."

ALPHA SPECIMENS
Preppies in history abound, as do forebears for every wally (guy) and tassel (girl) among today's Hipsters. A selection from each pantheon:

Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr. (Preppy)
"Boston Brahmin. Did not achieve divine status until the age of 60, when he became a Supreme Court justice and sported a mustache that looked swell in portraits."

Marcel Duchamp (Hipster)
"Entered a urinal signed 'R. Mutt' into an exhibition in 1917. It got rejected, but for six bucks (the price it cost Duchamp to submit the piece) he went into the history books as the founder of conceptual art, and Andy Warhol was provided a career. Duchamp was the quintessential Hipster."

F. Scott Fitzgerald (Preppy)
"Chronicled the Jazz Age. Wrote 'The Great Gatsby.' Blew the Prep cover on hopes and disillusion. Said it all."

Sitting Bull (Hipster)
"Loved to chill out. His nickname, Hunkesi, literally means 'slow.' Though he loved to take it easy, he always managed to kick some expletive when he needed to. During one early battle, he walked into enemy fire, sat down, and casually smoked a phatty. He walked away unharmed. He was one deck wally."

Caroline Kennedy (Preppy)
"During four years at Harvard Square, an unnatural fiber never went near her body (except for the shell of her L. L. Bean down vest). Her lacrosse game was ruthless, her brunch technique dazzling (smoked heavily and sat with the descendants of three presidents)."

Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis (Hipster)
"The tassels would still be dressing like June Cleaver.

Mata Hari (Hipster)
"She started her career as a nude dancer, then worked as a spy against the British, Germans and French during the First World War. She was executed by firing squad and never revealed who she was working for. Plus she was hot."

George Herbert Walker Bush (Preppy)
"Businessman, congressman, U.S. envoy to Peking, U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, candidate for vice-president of the U.S. qualified for Prep Pantheon because of impeccable breeding and manners. Described by Ronald Reagan as 'a Preppy, a Yalie, a sissy.' "

HEADLINE: Much Is at Stake In Decision on TV Tower 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 What's really at stake in the proposed Bayonne/Jersey City television broadcast tower (Briefing, Dec. 22) is the restoration of next-generation digital television broadcasting and access to network and local channel HDTV programming that was destroyed by the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center. 
The New York area is the only large population center without such a broadcast facility (although CBS and Fox broadcast analog and digital from atop the Empire State Building). 
 Digital broadcasting and high-quality widescreen HDTV transmission will spur billions of dollars in retail sales of HDTV's and home theater peripherals. This affects local manufacturing, wholesale distribution and retail. It impacts jobs and a whole host of other economic factors. Clearly the decision that Bradley Campbell, the New Jersey commissioner of environmental protection, will soon make regarding the new tower will affect a great deal more than "700,000 homes without cable access."

MICHAEL FREMER
Wyckoff

The writer is a contributing editor of Stereophile Guide to Home Theater.
